CYNTHIA NIXON (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, NEW YORK: Can you stop lying?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Oh, the other (INAUDIBLE) from last night's debate straight ahead. And President Trump heads to Indiana. Jeff Flock is there and he's going to talk to some real folks. Hey, Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Oh, you know, Dagen they say the imitation is the sincerest form of flattery. I don't know. The person not supposed to be here for another 12 hours but he might already be here. We'll have an exclusive interview with that fellow right there in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, August 30th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Breaking news, we just got initial jobless claims, they came in at 213,000. We are watching that -- we were expecting 214,000. We also got a look at personal income and spending for the month of July. Personal spending up four- tenths of a percent in line with expectations. Same story with personal income, it was right in line with what economists were looking for, gaining three-tenths of one percent. We also look at these, the personals consumption, expenditures. This is the Federal Reserve's most important gauge of inflation, gaining 2.3 percent. The core there up two percent. So, inflation based on that in check, wages still growing faster than inflation.

Futures are showing this this morning, 57-point gain -- no, excuse me, 57- point loss on the Dow Futures. Losses in Europe, to tell you about, those markets lower as well, ever so slightly looking at England, France, and Germany down about half of one percent. In Asia overnight, there was a single gainer there, the Nikkei up not even one-tenth of a percent in overnight trading.

The deadline approaches, trade talks with Canada kicking off again this morning, President Trump optimistic that Canada will join the new trade deal with Mexico before tomorrow's deadline.

Spat in the city, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and primary rival Cynthia Nixon kicking it up a notch in last night's gubernatorial debate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CUOMO: My opponent lives in the world of fiction, I live in world of facts. Can you stop you interrupting? Can you stop interrupting?

NIXON: Can you stop lying?

CUOMO: Yes. As soon as you do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Wait until you hear what else they said to one another. California Senate making it harder for young people to buy guns, we have the latest details on the vote to change the legal age, coming up.

It's an Apple acquisition, the iPhone maker just bought a company that makes lenses for augmented reality. We'll find out what new device might be coming out of the House of Jobs. And tragedy on the highway, many lobsters were killed in a truck cash in Maine. Now, the seafaring victims may get a memorial from their friends at PETA.

To our top story this half hour, President Trump heading to Evansville, Indiana for a rally tonight. Jeff Flock already on the ground this morning where he's talking to diners at the Merry Go Round Restaurant ahead of the President's visit. Hey, Jeff.

FLOCK: You can't make this stuff up, Dagen. You know, if you don't wonder whether this is Trump country or not, I don't know. Maybe a picture tells a thousand words here. Although, I tell you, it's interesting, you know, you talk to people, we sometimes come into town before these rallies just to get a sense of the people of what they're about. A lot of people like the President's policies, not of them -- all of them are crazy about the President himself, although this girl, I think is. Now, you look like somebody I might know.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, I'm going to be in town a little bit later in and out of the Ford Center.

FLOCK: There you go. I don't know if that's real but there you go. And you're a supporter of the President.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

FLOCK: A farmer?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

FLOCK: Why?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just believe that he's going to do good for the markets eventually. Going to take a while to get the instability out of him, but --

FLOCK: If he raising corn and soybeans, and of course, those prices are pretty far down. Yes, go ahead.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I don't think Indiana is no longer a flyover state because Donald has been here twice down the last two years. He cares about Midwest.

FLOCK: There you go. I hear you, sir. I hear you. I want to represent everything fair and balanced over there, I got a table full of Democrats, too, and we want to get a sense from them, too. These guys meet here frequently -- boy, man, they can eat, too. Hey, Larry, I'm sorry to interrupt you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No problem.

FLOCK: Lifelong democrat.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, sir.

FLOCK: A schoolteacher, you support the President right now.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: oh, I'm a convert, for sure.

FLOCK: What happened?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, I saw back when Clinton was in office, and what happened with the things he did in office, so a big change in the attitude of kids.

FLOCK: Teachers, school tearchers?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, I mean, when we catch somebody red-handed, they're doing something they deny, deny, deny.

FLOCK: But now, wait a minute, what about this president here?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, I've changed my philosophy a little bit. I'm voting for policy not people. And I -- I'm impressed with what Trump has done and capable of doing with his hands tied.

FLOCK: With the -- not so impressed with the tariffs?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, I'm not. But if you look at history, there has been a lot of Presidents have been questionable.

FLOCK: I guess you're right on that one.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There it comes a point in time where, yes, you want America to be better than it is, and I can't understand the Democrats --

FLOCK: I got you --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Open walls and higher taxes.

FLOCK: Larry, I appreciate it. You can tell, Larry, is actually democrat, because if you look down there, Kyl, he may be wearing overalls but he got a pair of flip-flops on, that's a dead giveaway right there. Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Is that how we judge somebody's political affiliation now, Jeff Flock, I really don't think that's fair. And those folks in Indiana sound a lot like me.

FLOCK: The father of superficiality.

MCDOWELL: No, I said those folks in --

FLOCK: We're pretty far south here. We're pretty far south. You know, these folks from Indiana, this is Southern Indiana, and we're south of Louisville here, so pretty amazing.

MCDOWELL: Pretty amazing. You tell that fellow I said that on the air, earlier, it's policy not personality, so you tell him I said that.

FLOCK: I think it makes a lot of sense to a lot more people these days.

MCDOWELL: It does. Jeff Flock, thank you so much for that. James Freeman, your reaction to what you heard. I love that line about Indiana is not a flyover state anymore because the President has been here twice recently.

FREEMAN: And I'm not sure how representative that crew is but suggests maybe there are -- there is some patience on the part of farmers. They don't like these tariffs but they feel like we're generally heading in a good direction, and I would say, Robert, you might have a better sense of the incumbent Democratic Senator Joe Donnelly, looks like he's going to have his hands full this November with Mike Braun.

WOLF: Yes, I think -- listen, Joe Donnelly is a -- you know, he's a blue collar guy, he fits incredibly well with police and fire, and the farmers, and a popular guy in Indiana. That being said, Trump is incredibly popular in Indiana and there's going to be a real battle on the swing states in the Senate whether it's here or Montana, or Missouri, and there's a slew of them where it's I think a strong Democratic incumbent who's good locally against an incredibly popular national President in those -- in those states. And then also, that's why right now most of them are flipping.

ORTAGUS: Will he -- will he vote for Kavanaugh?

WOLF: I think that -- my gut tells me that Kavanaugh will, you know, be on the Supreme Court. And that some of the swing state candidates will likely vote for Kavanaugh. You know, I can't say I love the process, obviously, I think there's -- there was better ways to go about it, especially, based on the past. But I think right now, the Democratic Party has to realize that they're in a battle in these swing states in the Senate.

MCDOWELL: There are 10 -- there are 10 democratic senators who are up for re-election in states that Trump won. 10.

WOLF: And I would say some of them. I look at someone like Manchin and Casey (ph). They're probably in pretty good shape in West Virginia and Pennsylvania look at someone like Kyrsten Sinema and the fellow running, Phil Bredesen in Tennessee and Arizona. They probably have a better chance. And then, you have a real group of us toss-ups I think it's going to be quite interesting, you know, what happens, and a lot will be based on what the economy does, you know, right into the midterms.

MCDOWELL: Well, part of the problem for some Democrats and you'll -- we can talk about the language that we used to describe them, was kind of highlighted in New York. Things got heated. There was the gubernatorial debate between Governor Andrew Cuomo, and Cynthia Nixo, the actresss political new comment. Just listed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CUOMO: My opponent lives in a world of fiction, I live in the world of fact. Can you stop interrupting? Can you stop interrupting?

NIXON: Can you stop lying?

CUOMO: Yes. As soon as you do.

NIXON: We already have a corrupt corporate Republican in the White House, we don't need a corrupt corporate Democrat in Albany as his main opposition.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: A lot of what you heard when you talk about abolishing ICE, she tosses that out there like it's a foregone conclusion, and what did the governor call members of ICE? He took a shot -- he took a shot at basically members of law enforcement in this country. This is -- these

WOLF: Thugs.

MCDOWELL: Thugs -- these individuals are pushing people left. Do you agree or not? You don't even want to call him Democrat.

WOLF: Listen, I -- (INAUDIBLE) you know I'm not part of the populous left. I'm definitely, you know, socially to the left and probably more physically conservative than most Republicans are today.

MCDOWELL: He's talking about trade.

FREEMAN: When I -- when I look at that debate, that doesn't make me feel good living in the State of New York. I think actually Governor Cuomo will do a really good job for the State of New York. I think that when we're debating whether ICE is important or not, I don't think that's a debate we should be having. I think the debate should be more about the economy and what they can do policy, not whether the air condition should be at 76, 76 or 68.

MCDOWELL: That's how petty it is.

FREEMAN: And so, you know, that's -- it is disappointing for me but as someone in New York and as a Democrat, I think Governor Cuomo will be the right guy, and I don't think we should be pushed left as a party. I like people like Tim Ryan out of Ohio who actually is a pro-growth democrat. That's someone that's taking about not that $15.00 minimum wage is important, but that a little wage is important. There is -- sorry, go ahead.

MCDOWELL: No, but I was going to say, here's the problem, that these loudmouths in the major cities, in California and in New York, they drive the messaging for a lot of Democrats and this is what people across the country hear if they turn on other television networks. And I've spend so much time down helping taking care of my mother, down in Rural Virginia. And people who live in these big cities, who live in these blue state bay are missing what is going on in this country, and they are missing out people feel about the economy and about President Trump, again, policy over personality.

FREEMAN: Well, I think a lot of people in Upstate New York watching that debate were disappointed thinking it was like watching a fight for mayor of New York City, where was -- they wanted to hear a lot more about how you revive growth in the cities, outside of New York City, upstate New York, and I don't think they got too much on that last night.

MCDOWELL: And you know what, you loosen up those dairy restrictions of exports going into Canada you know that helps upstate New York big time. Coming up, eye on retail earnings we break down the numbers next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Amazon may soon join the trillion-dollar club. Gerri Willis on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more. Hey, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, Dagen, that's right. So, pretty exciting stuff. We've been watching Amazon shares here all morning trading just below that 2000, level 1997.50 not far to go from here, and, of course, to join that 2,000 -- to join the trillion-dollar club with Apple, they'd have to hit 2050.57. So, that will be the benchmark for that. Very exciting stuff. We'll keep an eye on it. Meanwhile, if you are getting used to these retailers coming back, the brick-and-mortar retailers doing really well. Think about it again, Abercrombie and Fitch missing on same-store sales three percent versus 3.7. A disappointment there, the shares trading lower, as you can see, down 10 percent. Also, Dollar General same-store sales beat estimates 3.7 percent but the full- year profit outlook was disappointing. Interesting there, mix of business, went to low margin consumable items like toothpaste, not good, Dollar Tree also missing same-store estimates. That stock down as well. So, these brick-and-mortar stores, not doing so well here. Back to you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Gerri, thank you so much for that. Turning to politics, Newt Gingrich was talking about this earlier, California Gubernatorial Candidate Gavin Newsom is now backing universal health care for illegally immigrants. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GAVIN NEWSOM, LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR OF CALIFORNIA: I did universal health care when I was mayor, fully implemented regardless of pre-existing conditions (INAUDIBLE) and regardless of your immigration status. (INAUDIBLE) is the only universal health care plan for all undocumented residents very proud of that and we proved it can be done without bankrupting the city. I'd like to see that we can extend that to the rest of the state.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Mr. Varney, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY."

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Forgive me for rolling my eyes, but that is final lunacy. It looks like, to me, the socialists are having an increasingly important role to play within the Democrat Party. Just put California aside for a moment, look at Florida, a socialist -- an avowed socialist has made it to the gubernatorial final in Florida. In New York, last night, the avowed socialist Cynthia Nixon, I think she won the debate against Governor Andrew Cuomo.

And now, you've got California where Gavin Newsom as we just heard is going for universal health care for all illegals in the state. Who's going to pay for that? Well, business and the rich. Can you imagine the exodus of businesses and relatively wealthy people from California if they put this kind of thing in place? Can you imagine the welcome sign that he's hanging out for everybody, anybody who's sick anywhere in the world, all you got to do is get one foot in California and you are home free! Financial lunacy!

MCDOWELL: Nine minutes away, more of Stuart. We love you. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: -- sent to Democratic Governor Jerry Brown for his signature. Well, Apple is setting its sights on Augmented Reality, the company confirming it's acquired a Akonia Holographics, it's a start-up that makes lenses for Augmented Reality glasses. The term is not disclosed. Apple won't discuss what it plans to do with Akonia, but the deal could help the company develop an augmented reality headset. Apple shares are slightly higher ahead of the opening bell.

And then, there is this, animal rights group PETA is trying to erect a 5- foot tall granite tombstone at the site of a lobster truck crash that happened in Brunswick, Maine. About 7,000 pounds of lobster were destroyed last week in the wreck. So, the average size for a lobster was a pound and half, that means about 4500 lobsters died in this crash. Well, I mean, it died before but you know what I'm saying. Maine's Department of Transportation is currently reviewing the tombstone that PETA wants to put up in their memory. PETA says it hopes the tombstone will, quote, remind everybody that the best way to prevent such tragedies is to go vegan. Yes. I will send that back to you. You just chew on that one for a minute.

MCDOWELL: You know, rather than scolding people who choose to eat meat and seafood, they're trying to use a little bit of humor and trying to be light about it, PETA. I would just -- James is still laughing, he's been laughing --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: That's what -- I wasn't sure if it was a gag from PETA or --

MCDOWELL: Well, it's not really a -- it's sort of a gag -- no, I -- you know what, I don't -- I'm not going to lecture anybody about what they eat, but that means meat eaters shouldn't lecture me about eating vegetable.

FREEMAN: Well, OK.

MCDOWELL: Meantime, Jared Kushner arriving moments ago for the latest round of trade talks with Canada. Those talks set to begin in less than four minutes. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Robert Wolf, James freeman, and Morgan Ortagus. You get five seconds Morgan, and you're the only other lady here, so --

ORTAGUS: Thank you. I just want to say, Dagen, yesterday, you and I watched the processional for Senator McCain. We're all going to be watching over the weekend and honoring a great man.

MCDOWELL: This afternoon, 1:00 p.m. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: I certainly will, and good morning, Dagen. Good morning, everyone.

END

urn:contentItem:5T52-RVY1-JB20-G1M4-00000-00U.S.-Canada Trade Talks; Harley-Davidson Weigh in on Trump's Tariff Fight; Wall Street Rally; New Discussion Over Trump Administration Regulating Tech; Cuomo Versus Nixon; Cuomo: ICE Is A Bunch of "Thugs" And New York Is Suing Donald Trump; California Law Would Require Women To Be Names To Company Boards; Capsized Boat Rescue; Spicing Up Stadiums2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTSam StovallNEWSFinancial083001cb.231U.S.-Canada Trade Talks; Harley-Davidson Weigh in on Trump's Tariff Fight; Wall Street Rally; New Discussion Over Trump Administration Regulating Tech; Cuomo Versus Nixon; Cuomo: ICE Is A Bunch of "Thugs" And New York Is Suing Donald Trump; California Law Would Require Women To Be Names To Company Boards; Capsized Boat Rescue; Spicing Up StadiumsDagen McDowell, Robert Wolf, Cheryl Casone, Morgan Ortagus, James Freeman, Ari Fleischer, Jared Max

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And Dagen McDowell knows all of this very well because she's watching the numbers for us. Hello.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I am. They were pushing me - - my chair forward. So --

CASONE: You got to get right in the spot Dagen, right on.

MCDOWELL: It's one of those mornings and I wasn't even late. So --

CASONE: You never are.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I got like four new bruises this morning. Ladies, thank you so much, great to see you both. And I've already made James Freeman laugh and it's 5:59 in the morning.

Hey everybody, I'm giving it away who's on the show this morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, August 30th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Looking good as we inch closer to the deadline tomorrow, officials from the U.S. and Canada optimistic that a trade deal will be reached.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Canada very much wants to make the deal and I think it's going to be obviously very good for Canada if they do and I think it's probably not going to be good at all if they don't.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau saying a deal could be reached only if it's good for Canada.

Investors are still worried about trade but we have had day-after-day of new all-time highs on the S&P500, NASDAQ, and the Russell2000. This morning we have a picture that's lower to the downside, Dow Futures off by 844 points at the moment.

As I pointed out, we had record highs yesterday for your broad market gauges hitting their fourth consecutive record close.

In Europe take a look at England, France, and Germany. We have losses across the board to tell you about. The biggest loser at the moment is the DAX in Germany, down about one percent.

Trade tensions between China and the U.S. weighing on the Asian markets, we have slight gain on the Nikkei but Hong Kong, Shanghai and South Korea all lower on the day.

A new round of U.S. tariffs on $200 billion worth of goods imported from China set to hit later next month.

Trump versus Google, the president of United States criticizing the search giant for bias against conservative voices. We'll show you the evidence that Trump posted to back it up and we do have Google's response.

Salesforce selloff, shares of Salesforce sliding after the company's earnings report we break down those numbers.

And one for the books, the Green Bay Packers Quarterback Aaron Rodgers signing a mega deal making him the highest paid NFL player. We have the details of the incredible deal.

Duck and cover, the world's biggest food fight, you won't believe how many people were there to chuck tomatoes at one another.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, National Security Analyst Morgan Ortagus. Borrowed Time Co-Author James Freeman. Actually, that's on my reading list.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good.

MCDOWELL: I bought it on my Kindle. And 32Advisors Founder and CEO, Fox Business Contributor Robert Wolf.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Great.

MCDOWELL: Has clearly been on the golf course a lot.

WOLF: Yes. A little -- a little bit. I mean, if you call my hacking golf. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Well as much as your -- as much as you play, your game should be good and better.

WOLF: Yes, it's not. But I'm fun to play with. I mean -- but the game is not getting much better.

MCDOWELL: And you were fun to spend a morning with us.

WOLF: I'm glad to be here with James and Morgan and You.

MCDOWELL: And glad -- thanks for the --

FREEMAN: Likewise.

MCDOWELL: Right. Thank you. Thank you, Ari. You know what, if you want privacy, don't walk the city streets nowadays because everybody's got a camera phone. You better be careful about cursing at somebody. Not you. I'm just saying in general.

ORTAGUS: Are you serious, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: You can't yell, you can't -- you can't yell anymore, not in the street. Speaking of New York and people yelling at each other, there was this bizarre back and forth between New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and candidate Cynthia Nixon in the first New York gubernatorial debate, just watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW CUOMO (D), GOVERNOR OF NEW YORK: My opponent lives in the world of fiction. I live in the world of fact. Can you stop interrupting? Can you stop interrupting?

CYNTHIA NIXON (D), GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE, NEW YORK: Can you stop lying?

CUOMO: Yes, as soon as you do.

NIXON: We already have a corrupt corporate Republican in the White House. We don't need a corrupt corporate Democrat in Albany, as his main opposition.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Cuomo also doubling down on the Democratic talking point of abolishing immigration and customs enforcement, ICE. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CUOMO: New York State is the state that is suing Donald Trump for ripping babies from the arms of their mother. New York State is the state that says we will not cooperate with ICE, they're a bunch of thugs. He politicized ICE. They're a bunch of thugs. We said we will sue them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That's the left going further left, Ari. What did you make of that?

FLEISCHER: I think if I'm a law enforcement officer anywhere, local cop, sheriff, state police trooper, I'm offended, thugs, because they're enforcing the law and doing their jobs? I hate politicians who talk like this. It is so offensive to the people who protect us.

MCDOWELL: But Cynthia Nixon has pushed him further left on this, don't you think?

FLEISCHER: Well, that's the problem, and he's caving. Cynthia Nixon says she wants to abolish ICE. So, Cuomo has to act tough too, so he says they're thugs, wrong.

ORTAGUS: Cynthia Nixon is right about one thing. She said that air conditioning is sexist. And considering Dagen and I are always freezing (INAUDIBLE) Cynthia Nixon is right, air conditioning is sexist.

FREEMAN: Politics is local.

MCDOWELL: What about a dose of what it's like to be in front of a live audience and there were supporters of Cynthia Nixon when he was bringing up like you live in the world of fiction, basically making fun of her television and acting career, that they booed him. You would hear it.

FLEISCHER: Can I go back to what you said? Can I make you wear this tie? I mean, it's terrible. We need a colder studio.

MCDOWELL: Yes, and we need -- we need better leadership in New York State. And I know -- we didn't see it last night. Coming up -- thank you, Ari Fleischer, thank you for the humor, so early in the morning.

We tell you which state may soon become the first to mandate women on corporate boards.

And then, this shirt on shirt on jacket on sweatshirt, how much it will cost you.

MCDOWELL: California lawmakers taking a step to bring diversity to boardrooms, more chicks, they say, they mandate by law. Cheryl Casone has more. Hey, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. You know, interesting -- I mean, certainly you may see more females in the boardroom or CEO, but lawmakers in California is taking this all a step further. They may soon require major companies that are headquartered in California have to put female directors on the board. Under this proposed law, boards will need to have at least one woman by the end of next year and at least two or three by the end of 2021. Those who don't will be fined. The law recently passed the state assembly and now heads back to the state senate and then the desk of Governor Jerry Brown. We'll keep you posted.

And then there is this, a dramatic rescue off of a Florida's coast.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Is everybody accounted for? I want to get everybody on the boat. Can you swim?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Grab the life ring.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes, that boat capsized. Police on Miami Beach released this body cam footage that shows three brothers that were rescued after their boat capsized. They had no life jackets on, by the way. Police believe that the boat was flipped by rough waters.

And then, a little n nostalgia for you, Dagen. Remember this scene from "Friends""

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK, buddy boy, here it is. You hide my clothes, I'm wearing everything you own.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes. Well, it seems that fashion designer Balenciaga has taken inspiration from Joey of all people. At Paris fashion week, the company debuted this heavily layered jacket. If it is for you, it's $9,000. As you can see, it's got an outer coat, it's got layers, it's got a hoodie, it's like five different jackets. And then they also released this, this is kind of strange, red squared shoes. So, people on social media say it looks like a carton of McDonald's French fries. These are $545. I mean, you can't make this stuff up. That jacket reminds me, Dagen, of a guy that tried to go through TSA security wearing all of these clothes so he wouldn't have to check a bag. Remember that? This is what it reminds me of.

MCDOWELL: But this is increasingly -- particularly what these fashion houses and women's fashion designers, it's like they're playing a joke on women. They're trying to see how foolish people will be with their money. It's literally $1,000 ripped gray sweatshirt.

ORTAGUS: Well, I was just thinking that because air conditioning is sexist, I need this jacket.

FREEMAN: I think they're playing a joke on men too, aren't they? That looks like the derelict campaign.

WOLF: Listen, Steve Bannon was wearing that outfit for a year and no one said -- he had like four layers. He had the shirt, the under shirt, the --

MCDOWELL: That officially -- you saying that will end that trend. It ended right now because --

WOLF: I'm telling you, Bannon was wearing five or six layers.

MCDOWELL: Sister, sister. Serena and Venus set to square off in round three of the U.S. Open. We've got the preview.

MCDOWELL: Green Bay Packers Quarterback Aaron Rodgers has a lot of green coming his way. Jared Max has information on a record-setting contract extension. Hey, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Dagen, suffice to day, it's a beautiful day in Mr. Rodgers neighborhood. Set to begin his 14th season of the NFL. Rodgers signs a four-year extension that reportedly could be worth in the Mr. Rodgers neighborhood of $180 million. The breakdown, $134 million in base salary. $103 million of which is guaranteed an NFL record and a league high annual average of $33.5 million.

We're going to see something tomorrow at the U.S. Open that we have not seen in over 20 years. Serena Williams won her second-round match at the U.S. Open on Wednesday in straight sets, 6-2, 6-2. Earlier, Serena's older sister Venus won her second-round match also in straight sets. And so, it will be an all sister affair. Tomorrow in flushing meadows not since January of 98, had the Williams sisters met this early in a grand slam tournament. Serena has won 17 of her 29 head to head matchups.

MCDOWELL: Go, Williams sisters. My favorite athletes of all time. Continue.

MAX: Defending Champion Rafael Nadal moved into the third round with a straight sets win, Wednesday night. However, 2012 champ, Andy Murray is done. He was eliminated in four sets by Fernando Verdasco.

All right, let's cycle over to Major League Baseball. The operative word here is "cycle." When a player hits for a single, a double, a triple and home run of the same game, he hits for the cycle. Which is what the Brewers' Christian Yelich did against the Reds. He homered for the sixth time in his many games, and Milwaukee beat Cincinnati in 13 innings -- 13- 12 or 10 innings, I should say.

Last in national league attendance for likely 13th time in 14 years, the Miami Marlins promise more noise at games next season. The team encourages its fans to get loud, bring musical instruments, bells, and whistles, and flags to games next year. The team says it offers the region's diverse Latin American culture to show pride, get loud an in one section of the ballpark. It will be called communidad tres, sero, cinco -- Community 305.

Baseball and Budweiser, how about baseball and wine? Yes. Partnering with City Winery, the New York Yankees have opened a wine bar at Yankee stadium, which in addition to other wines and (INAUDIBLE) will offer Yankees' branded wines. City Winery's first permanent winery at sports stadium.

MCDOWELL: I love it. Jared, thank you so much. And I'll shout out to the Williams sisters again. Jared Max with us. Straight ahead, Uber now looking to drone for food delivery. We'll tell you about it. That's on the next hour of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Thursday, August 30th, your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern. Almost there. As tomorrow's deadline looms, President Trump --

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T5K-KY81-DY0W-422F-00000-00U.S.-Canada Trade Talks; Harley-Davidson Weigh in on Trump's Tariff Fight; Wall Street Rally; New Discussion Over Trump Administration Regulating Tech; Cuomo Versus Nixon; Cuomo: ICE Is A Bunch of 'Thugs' And New York Is Suing Donald Trump; California Law Would Require Women To Be Names To Company Boards; Capsized Boat Rescue; Spicing Up Stadiums2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-Canada Trade Talks; Harley-Davidson Weigh in on Trump's Tariff Fight; Wall Street Rally; New Discussion Over Trump Administration Regulating Tech; Cuomo Versus Nixon; Cuomo: ICE Is A Bunch of 'Thugs' And New York Is Suing Donald Trump; California Law Would Require Women To Be Names To Company Boards; Capsized Boat Rescue; Spicing Up StadiumsLanhamFULL TEXT

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And Dagen McDowell knows all of this very well because she's watching the numbers for us. Hello.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I am. They were pushing me - - my chair forward. So --

CASONE: You got to get right in the spot Dagen, right on.

MCDOWELL: It's one of those mornings and I wasn't even late. So --

CASONE: You never are.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I got like four new bruises this morning. Ladies, thank you so much, great to see you both. And I've already made James Freeman laugh and it's 5:59 in the morning.

Hey everybody, I'm giving it away who's on the show this morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, August 30th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Looking good as we inch closer to the deadline tomorrow, officials from the U.S. and Canada optimistic that a trade deal will be reached.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Canada very much wants to make the deal and I think it's going to be obviously very good for Canada if they do and I think it's probably not going to be good at all if they don't.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau saying a deal could be reached only if it's good for Canada.

Investors are still worried about trade but we have had day-after-day of new all-time highs on the S&P500, NASDAQ, and the Russell2000. This morning we have a picture that's lower to the downside, Dow Futures off by 844 points at the moment.

As I pointed out, we had record highs yesterday for your broad market gauges hitting their fourth consecutive record close.

In Europe take a look at England, France, and Germany. We have losses across the board to tell you about. The biggest loser at the moment is the DAX in Germany, down about one percent.

Trade tensions between China and the U.S. weighing on the Asian markets, we have slight gain on the Nikkei but Hong Kong, Shanghai and South Korea all lower on the day.

A new round of U.S. tariffs on $200 billion worth of goods imported from China set to hit later next month.

Trump versus Google, the president of United States criticizing the search giant for bias against conservative voices. We'll show you the evidence that Trump posted to back it up and we do have Google's response.

Salesforce selloff, shares of Salesforce sliding after the company's earnings report we break down those numbers.

And one for the books, the Green Bay Packers Quarterback Aaron Rodgers signing a mega deal making him the highest paid NFL player. We have the details of the incredible deal.

Duck and cover, the world's biggest food fight, you won't believe how many people were there to chuck tomatoes at one another.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, National Security Analyst Morgan Ortagus. Borrowed Time Co-Author James Freeman. Actually, that's on my reading list.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good.

MCDOWELL: I bought it on my Kindle. And 32Advisors Founder and CEO, Fox Business Contributor Robert Wolf.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Great.

MCDOWELL: Has clearly been on the golf course a lot.

WOLF: Yes. A little -- a little bit. I mean, if you call my hacking golf. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Well as much as your -- as much as you play, your game should be good and better.

WOLF: Yes, it's not. But I'm fun to play with. I mean -- but the game is not getting much better.

MCDOWELL: And you were fun to spend a morning with us.

WOLF: I'm glad to be here with James and Morgan and You.

MCDOWELL: And glad -- thanks for the --

FREEMAN: Likewise.

MCDOWELL: Thanks for the courtesy laugh at 5:58 in the morning.

FREEMAN: I got to thank you for the book plug. So you realize you don't have to read it as long as you buy it.

WOLF: Yes. I'm reading it too. I'm going to just say I'm reading it too because I want to plug it.

MCDOWELL: I am reading --

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I haven't bought it or read it but I'll buy it.

MCDOWELL: It is about Citi Group.

FREEMAN: Yes, that's right.

MCDOWELL: It is about the bubblelicious Citi Group, the rise and fall.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: The rise and fall.

FREEMAN: You're wondering their history and really strong bank before the government was standing behind it. Then once the government got behind it, not such a good history.

WOLF: Well as a former Salomon Brothers guy that was bought by Citi Group that's now run by a former Salomon Brothers guy, I'm rooting for them. So I hope the book is rooting for them.

MCDOWELL: Well we're here --

FREEMAN: Well, it's topped with fate.

WOLF: How about that?

MCDOWELL: As we will be all morning long and everything that we talk about whether it's trade, the market, there was that debate last night between the candidates for the governor of New York.

And also coming this morning, CFRA Investment -- Chief Investment Strategist Sam Stovall. Former White House Press Secretary, Fox News Contributor, Ari Fleischer. Senate Finance Committee Member, the Senator one of two, from Pennsylvania, Pat Toomey. Former Speaker of the House, Fox News Contributor Newt Gingrich. And SAPAmerica's President Jen Morgan.

We have some incredible guests coming up. But right here right now, optimism on trade, both President Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sounding optimistic about reaching a trade agreement by tomorrow's deadline. The commander-in-chief commenting on the negotiation yesterday at the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think Canada very much wants to make the deal and I think it's going to be obviously very good for Canada if they do and I think it's probably not going to be good at all if they don't. We have a very good relationship.

They came yesterday to the White House and we negotiated late into the evening, they're in the White House right now, we're negotiating with them right now and they want to be part of a deal. And we gave until Friday and I think we're probably on track. We'll see what happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Do we get a deal by tomorrow James Freeman? Here's my quote that I wrote down from President Trump, "I love Canada. I love Mexico." So there you go. If he's sounding positive that way, it can't be bad.

FREEMAN: Yes. That is progress, isn't it? And, yes, I think they get a deal. Remember, they don't have to agree on every phrase, every comma, and period right now. They just have to basically agree on where they're going and they've got this timeline to move it through the various legislatures.

But I think they will get a deal because although consumers aren't going to necessarily like it to buy autos, the Canadian government likes what the U.S. did with Mexico. They liked these new efforts to keep manufacturing in the U.S. and Canada versus Mexico. So I think there's a lot of reason for Canada to cut a deal and we buy 75 percent of their exports.

MCDOWELL: To get into the ways because we love doing that Morgan, the two sticking points for Canada -- the United States wants more access to the -- to selling dairy into Canada and then Canada wants to keep these existing dispute resolution panels that are used to resolve conflicts about tariffs among the three countries.

But that sounds like in the grand scheme of things, ideas that can be resolved or problems that can be resolved.

ORTAGUS: I think you're right. I think something else that this administration has said that they want to resolve with Canada is I.P. protections and that was -- that has been written into the new agreement, the new proposed agreement with Mexico.

And the USTR has been actually quite tough on Canada's position on I.P. and that's been a real sticking point for them in addition to dairy farmers. The real challenge I see with all of this Dagen is that no matter what comes -- no matter what happens whether it's just a deal with Mexico or whether it's fully renegotiated NAFTA, this is going to slip into 2019.

For congressional approval you'll need -- they'll need approval from both the House and the Senate. Clearly there's a chance that we're looking at least the Democrat House. So the strategy there, you know, will the -- will the democrats especially someone like Bernie Sanders who supported a trade agenda similar to the president, will they support this or leading up to 2020? Are they going to oppose this deal just simply because it's something that Donald Trump negotiated?

MCDOWELL: Well let's ask this big old democrat.

WOLF: Well listen, I think I've been to the right of the conservative party on trade because I've been for TPP, I've been for iterating NAFTA. So I don't mind as a former advisor to the president on export counsel, I'm a supporter of this.

I think the president trying to do NAFTA2.0 is a good thing. If we can iterate, OK, where there's better labor standards in Mexico that brings the pricing up, so we're not -- cheap labor is not the beneficiary of kind of the detriment to the U.S., those are good things.

That being said, whether it's tomorrow or a week from tomorrow, or a month away, I think we should just make sure we get the best possible deal, OK, for both sides. That can, you know, stand the time. That being said, we should also, you know, make changes throughout.

One of the problems with NAFTA1.0 is we haven't really changed it in over two decades. So this is important to have the right changes, it seems like it's in the right trajectory, and it certainly seems with Chrystia Freeland their trade minister flying back immediately to try to do something is a good sign.

MCDOWELL: Right. She was scheduled to go to Europe to --

WOLF: She -- right.

MCDOWELL: -- this week and she said, "Hey, I'm staying in North America and head south."

WOLF: And as far as the dems, you know, what I would say is that if it's a -- if it's a good agreement between Canada and Mexico, just not bilateral with Mexico, I actually think it will pass both the House and the Senate.

MCDOWELL: Well they need that for fast-track status.

WOLF: I think it will pass the boat.

ORTAGUS: That's true.

MCDOWELL: They need that for fast-track status.

ORTAGUS: In addition to what Robert said about labor, there's also new rules on the environment, also on I.P. protection as we talked about. So I think there's some positive things that both parties could look to but the Journal did criticize this as, you know, Dagen, they called it, "Politically managed trade."

MCDOWELL: Yes, James.

FREEMAN: Yes.

ORTAGUS: "The economic logic is the opposite of Mr. Trump's domestic deregulation agenda."

MCDOWELL: Well the headline was --

FREEMAN: True. Yes.

GOV. DOUG DUCEY (R), ARIZONA: He fought like hell for causes he believed in. He plowed through election after election with the energy and focus of a warrior. But along the way, he did it with humor and humanity. And without compromising the principles he healed so dear.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Senator McCain will be escorted by his family from the Capitol at 9:00 a.m. local time this morning. They will make their way here to the North Phoenix Baptist Church for memorial service. Along the way they expect thousands to stand along the motorcade route at the ceremony here. Former Vice President Joe Biden will give an address along with Governor Doug Ducey who will be in attendance.

Over 22 sitting Senators will also be here at the church for the memorial service along with staff and players from the Arizona Cardinals and also the Arizona Diamondbacks which McCain was a very big fan of, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: It was every person, every speaker, every song, every detail planned over a period of several months by Senator John McCain. And it's an incredible way watching it yesterday, the people lining up to pay their respects and look forward to watching it later today of what he meant to the people of Arizona and how much that state and it's incredible breathtaking beauty and the people how much it meant to him. Thank you so much, Hillary Vaughn.

We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: Eyeing progress on trade. The next round of talks with Canada, they start in less than an hour. The uncertainty over deals weighing on business across industries. Joining us now, SAP Americas and Asia Pacific Japan President, Jennifer Morgan. Jennifer, SAP is one of the worldwide leaders in business software applications clients in over 180 countries. How are these trade disputes impacting customers and businesses as you see it right now?

JENNIFER MORGAN, PRESIDENT, SAP AMERICAS AND ASIA PACIFIC JAPAN: What's interesting, I was -- I was with a big CPG company yesterday, I was with an aerospace company the day before and one of them said, every morning when I wake up, I look at the news to understand what do I need to think about in my supply chain. How do I need to think differently and what do I need to pivot?

And this is exactly what we do. This is our bread and butter. Helping customers understand how to have most agile supply chain and how to pivot and how use technology to your advantage. So in times of uncertainty this is where we can really help our customers.

MCDOWELL: So you would actually benefiting from the uncertainty.

MORGAN: We're helping customers work through it.

MCDOWELL: But have you seen in terms of businesses making big changes or holding off on investment decisions, holding off on decision-making because they don't know what's going to happen with these trade negotiations?

MORGAN: I see them really leaning into technology because the only way to really cope with -- to cope with the change is through technology. And it's -- we're in a real time economy, and so these companies have to think in very different ways. So, now I see really leaning in.

WOLF: Jennifer you and your company had an amazing kind of past year.

MORGAN: Yes.

WOLF: Talk about, you know, the growth of your cloud business. I heard it's like up over 40 percent and what's making you grow, you know, literally at a better pace in the market?

MORGAN: Yes. We had great growth in K2, we have 40 percent revenue growth in the cloud. Really (INAUDIBLE) across all of our regions and industries. Digital transformation is obviously front and center. A lot of M&A activity that we see out there, companies have to think about how they can very quickly embrace those companies, get the synergies that they need. I'd say the other trend is around companies thinking about the consumer experience.

Companies right now, the companies that will really thrive are the ones who are really thinking what is the experience that my consumer wants to have with my brand. It's not just about the buying experience but it's about the entire experience and companies who want to get direct to the consumer have to also make sure they got the right planning in place, supply chain, inventory so that you get the experience that you want.

Not upfront but across the whole time for that customer.

FREEMAN: So you've been -- sounds like seeing good results everywhere but the larger picture seems to be the U.S. doing really well, rest of the world not so great. Are you kind of thinking maybe the rest of the world is perking up, going to be growing faster based on what you've seen?

MORGAN: Yes. I was -- I spent most of summer in both Europe and Asia and for us that's a really strong part of our business. Europe is a big part of our business. We saw great growth in our European businesses and in Asia you really -- the CEOs are leaning in, we had a big CEO event in Tokyo and that was great because these CEOs are leaning into the direct to consumer to really by the digital transformation.

So our business has done very, very well, you know, across all the different regions. Mexico last week interesting, I was down in Mexico meeting with some of our largest retail customers as well. Same thing, same thing down there, moving to the cloud trying to get the cost down.

WOLF: The President also said he loves Mexico.

WOLF: No. I just want to give them those --

MORGAN: So, I would -- I think most women, I know myself included, I silt onboard of Bank of New York Mellon. I want to be recognized and put in positions based on my accomplishments and I think most women, most underrepresented minorities feel the same ways. I think it comes down to leadership, right? CEOs have it in their power to put women and underrepresented minorities in leadership positions.

Boards have the ability to do this. I look at our board at the bank, we got 25 percent women on that board. It's a leadership issue. I think it's all of the above. I don't think it can be solved with just a quota.

Extracts.SummaryText: now get about five times as much of their revenue from financial activities such as offering credit to customers, tax "optimisation," and trading, as they did in the 80s. Big tech companies underwrite corporate bond offerings the way banks do. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JW3-HW61-JCJY-G2GJ-00000-00US capitalism in crisis while most Americans lose out;The inequality that is feeding the bitter, divisive and populist politics now sweeping the west2016-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisOPINIONUS capitalism in crisis while most Americans lose outThe inequality that is feeding the bitter, divisive and populist politics now sweeping the westRana Foroohar

Crisis always brings opportunity. And right now, we are having a crisis of capitalism unlike anything experienced during the last four decades, if not longer. The evidence is everywhere - in rising inequality, in the division of fortunes between companies and workers, and in lethargic economic growth despite unprecedented infusions of monetary stimulus by the world's governments (a huge $29tn in total since 2008). Eight years on from the financial crisis and great recession, the US, UK and many other countries are still experiencing the longest, slowest economic recoveries in memory.

This has, of course, diametrically shifted the political climate, creating a paradigm of insiders versus outsiders. In the US, Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders are different sides of the same coin; in Britain, Jeremy Corbyn is an equally dramatic response to establishment politics. The challenges to the political and economic status quo are not going away anytime soon. A recent Harvard study shows that only 19% of American millennials call themselves capitalist, and only 30% support the system as a whole. Perhaps more shocking, the numbers are not much better among the over-30 set. A mere half of Americans believe in the system of capitalism as practised today in the US, which is quite something for a nation that brought us the "greed is good" culture.

In some ways that is no surprise because, as I explore in my new book, Makers and Takers: The Rise of Finance and the Fall of American Business, the system of market capitalism as envisioned by Adam Smith is broken - the markets no longer support the economy, as a wealth of academic research shows. Market capitalism was set up to funnel worker savings into new businesses via the financial system. But only 15% of the capital in the financial institutions today goes towards that goal - the rest exists in a closed loop of trading and speculation.

The result is much slower than normal growth, which holds true not just in the US but in most advanced economies and many emerging ones. The politics of the day - populist, angry, divisive - reflect this, in the US, Europe and many parts of the developing world as well.

But the bifurcation of our economy and the resulting fractiousness in politics has become so extreme that we are now at a tipping point. And as a result, we have a rare, second chance to change the economic paradigm - to rewrite the rules of capitalism and create a more inclusive, sustainable economic growth.

Doing so will require a series of both technocratic and existential changes - everything from rethinking the nature of how companies are run (and for whom), crafting smarter national growth strategies and rewriting the narrative of trickle- down economics, which is now so clearly broken yet continues to guide the majority of economic policy decisions taken by our leaders.

But before we can do all these things, we need to understand where we are and how we got here. Our economic illness has a name: financialisation. It's a term for the trend by which Wall Street and its way of thinking have come to reign supreme in America, permeating not just Wall Street but all American business. It includes everything from the growth in size and scope of finance and financial activity in our economy to the rise of debt-fuelled speculation over productive lending, to the ascendancy of shareholder value as a model for corporate governance, to the proliferation of risky, selfish thinking in both our private and public sectors, to the increasing political power of financiers and the chief executives they enrich. All of which have led to a false sense of prosperity driven by market highs rather than real Main Street growth.

We speak about social "capital" and securitise everything from education to critical infrastructure to prison terms

It's a shift that has even affected our language, our civic life, and our way of relating to one another. We speak about human or social "capital" and securitise everything from education to critical infrastructure to prison terms, a mark of our burgeoning "portfolio society".

Although the American financial sector dwarfs any other by sheer size, the UK is in some ways even more financialised than America, given the City of London's outsized role in the national economy. It's perhaps no surprise then that much of the most cutting-edge thinking on the topic is being done by Britons such as Sir Paul Tucker, the former deputy governor of the Bank of England, the current Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane, and former FSA chair Lord (Adair) Turner. "The trend varies slightly country by country but the broad direction is clear: across all advanced economies, and the US and the UK in particular, the role of the capital markets and the banking sector in funding new investment is decreasing. Most of the money in the system is being used for lending against existing assets," says Turner, whose recent book, Between Debt and the Devil, explains the phenomenon in detail.

In simple terms, what this means is that rather than funding the new ideas and projects that create jobs and raise wages, finance has shifted its attention to securitising existing assets (such as homes, stocks, bonds and such), turning them into tradeable products that can be spliced and diced and sold as many times as possible - that is, until things blow up, as they did in 2008. In the US, finance has doubled in size since the 1970s, and now makes up 7% of the economy and takes a quarter of all corporate profits, more than double what it did back then. Yet it creates only 4 % of all jobs. Similar numbers hold true in the UK.

How did this sector, which was once meant to merely facilitate business, manage to get such a stranglehold over it? Bankers themselves are often blamed but in truth the trend of financialisation was enabled by policymakers and the decisions they took from the 70s onwards, as postwar growth began to slow. In the US, interest rate deregulation under the Jimmy Carter administration, which was supported by a coalition of left and right political interests, led to the possibility of financial "innovations" such as the spliced and diced securities that blew up the world economy in 2008.

Reagan era shifts allowed banks and corporations alike to become larger and more financialised, and further Bill Clinton era deregulation threw kerosene on the fire. The legacy of her husband's laissez-faire economic policies is one reason Hillary Clinton isn't gaining more political traction. One of the most perverse effects of financialisation is that companies across all industries have come to emulate finance. It's no wonder - profit margins in finance tend to be much higher than in other industries, and the Copernican shift towards the markets has led us to revere the industry as the top of an economic hierarchy of services that we graduate to after passing through the lower phases of agrarian and manufacturing economies.

American corporations now get about five times as much of their revenue from financial activities such as offering credit to customers, tax "optimisation," and trading, as they did in the 80s. Big tech companies underwrite corporate bond offerings the way banks do. Traditional hedging by energy and transport firms has been overtaken by profit-boosting speculation in oil futures, a shift that actually undermines their core business by creating more price volatility. The amount of trading done by these organisations now far exceeds the value of their own real-world investments, a sure sign of financialisation)

British firms are very much a part of this trend. The recent history of BP (British Petroleum) is a perfect example not only of the rise of financial activities as a percentage of business but also of the perverse effect that financialisation can have on corporate culture: a focus on trading can lead to excessive risk-taking, and an overemphasis on short-term profit can undermine a company's financial future. BP was, from the 90s, an extremely balance-sheet focused company, becoming one of the most aggressive corporate costcutters of the era. This ultimately led whistleblowers to accuse the company of skimping on maintenance and using outdated equipment, even as it encouraged traders in its burgeoning US office to take bigger risks in search of trading-desk profits.

The strategy exploded in 2005 and 2006 when BP suffered a number of back-to-back disasters, including a refinery explosion in Texas City, Texas, an oil spill at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, and accusations of manipulating energy markets via its US trading arm. In a move that echoed the manipulation of the California energy markets a few years earlier, Houston-based traders for BP US had used company resources to purchase a large quantity of propane gas, which they later sold to other market players for inflated prices, costing consumers $53m in overcharges. The company eventually had to pay back that amount, as well as a criminal penalty of $100m, and another $125m in civil charges to the CFTC (the Commodity Futures Trading Commission). The environmental disasters resulting from the explosion and Alaskan leaks cost tens of millions of dollars more in criminal and civil payments.

Since then, BP's Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 became the largest marine oil spill in the history of the world, costing the company more than $50bn in legal fees, penalties and cleanup charges. You would think that all of this would have caused a serious crisis of conscience within the company. Yet far from pulling back and focusing on the core business, BP has charged full steam ahead into trading, becoming one of the largest non-financial players in the field. The firm now obtains at least 20% of its income from dealing in swaps, futures, and other financial instruments, up from 10% in 2005, the last time it disclosed profitability figures for its trading division. So where do we go from here? How do we curb the 40-year trend of financialisation and its perverse effects on business and society? Some people, such as the British economic journalist Paul Mason, are relatively optimistic. His new book, Postcapitalism, argues that we are at a tipping point in the process of financialisation, which has allowed capitalism to grow, like a virus, beyond its useful life span. He thinks that the technology-driven "sharing economy" in which information is freer and capital is less important will empower workers to fight financial capitalists in a new and more powerful way.

I'm less optimistic. In my own reporting experience, I've found Silicon Valley titans at the heart of the technology revolution to be just as rapacious and arguably even more tribal than many financiers. Uber looks to outsource, downsize and liquidate formal employees as much as possible. Apple, once one of the most admired companies on earth, is now one of the most financialised - over the last few years, Apple has issued billions of debt and made commitments to issue nearly as much as it has sitting in overseas bank accounts (some $200bn) to avoid paying more US taxes, and used the money to do buybacks that artificially jack up the price of its sagging stock. I think that changes in our current dysfunctional economic paradigm won't just happen but will require several shifts, both practical and existential. There is plenty of low hanging fruit to be plucked in the form of tax code changes that would incentivise savings and investment rather than debt - which is the lifeblood of finance.

We should reform business education to focus more on industry rather than finance (amazingly, given what we have been through in the last eight years, "efficient" markets theory is still the core of most MBA curriculums). We should rethink for whom companies should be run - workers, consumers and civic society as well as shareholders (many top performing firms already have that mandate). And we should certainly reform the financial system itself, reducing leverage, increasing capital holdings, and ending the culture of "experts" in finance.

Indeed, we should open the conversation about how and for whom the financial system should work to a much broader group of people - far beyond the small priesthood of financiers, politicians, and regulators who tend to share the same finance-centric view of the economy. "We need to stop treating banking as if it's a business unlike any other," says Stanford professor Anat Admati, whose book The Bankers' New Clothes, suggests a number of smart ways to reform and simplify the financial sector.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, we need a new narrative about our financial system and its place in our economy and society. As the crisis of 2008 and its continuing aftermath have surely shown us, we are at the end of what financialisation can do for growth. We need a new model, one that will enrich the many rather than the few, in a more sustainable way. We need markets that are structured fairly, with the kind of equal access that Adam Smith described in The Wealth of Nations. We need a political economy that isn't captured by moneyed interests. And we need a financial sector that supports, rather than hinders, our economy.

Even if we don't understand the particulars of Wall Street, we all know at gut level that the current system isn't working. How could it be when 1% of the population takes most of the world's wealth, and a single industry that creates only 4% of jobs takes nearly 25% of US corporate profits? If we don't think hard about how to change things, the politics of the next four years may be far uglier than what we have seen so far.

Rana Foroohar is Time magazine's economic columnist, global economic analyst for CNN, and the author of Makers and Takers: The Rise of Finance and the Fall of American Business ( Crown Business )

How do we curb the 40-year trend of financialisation and its perverse effects on business and society?

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y2B-VDY1-DYX2-035C-00000-00US Chamber, tech, health care lead K Street spending in 20192020-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisUS Chamber, tech, health care lead K Street spending in 2019

Big business, big tech and medical interests were K Street's top players last year as those industries spent millions of dollars on federal lobbying in the final months of 2019, while lawmakers and the administration wrapped up spending and trade measures.

With the 2020 elections expected to consume lawmakers' attention this summer and fall, lobbyists say they're looking at a post-impeachment crunch on major 2020 priorities. Some clients already are gaming out a possible lame-duck session as well as a potentially revamped federal government in 2021.

"The dynamics of the elections are likely, if not certain, to compel House Democrats to continue to act on legislation, like infrastructure," said lobbyist Stephanie Silverman of Venn Strategies.

Other hot issues this year may include discussions on cybersecurity and data privacy and trade matters, among others.

Loading...

Last year, Facebook, under pressure on the Hill and from the executive branch, spent more on federal lobbying, $16.7 million, than ever before -- more than 30 percent above 2018's $12.6 million. Ditto for Amazon, which increased its federal lobbying tab to $16.1 million in 2019, up from $14.2 million in 2018.

Major business lobbies, the Business Roundtable (whose members are corporate CEOs) and National Association of Manufacturers among them, reported big increases in federal lobbying expenditures in the last quarter of the year, fueled largely by trade matters including the renegotiated pact between the United States, Mexico, and Canada.

The roundtable disclosed spending $8.5 million, of its $20 million total, in just the fourth quarter. NAM, too, disclosed some $8.4 million on lobbying in October through December, more than it reported spending in the first three quarters of the year combined.

One outlier in the top spenders is the liberal organization Open Society Policy Center, which lobbies in its own right and also funds lobbying efforts by other groups. Open Society, which has ties to the liberal donor George Soros, disclosed spending more than $24 million on lobbying in the fourth quarter of 2019 on such issues as national defense, national security powers and appropriations.

Groups representing hospitals, doctors and pharmaceutical concerns also were among the biggest spenders in 2019, as lawmakers debated prescription drug pricing and surprise medical billing measures.

Trade policy and administration efforts to roll back environmental regulations were among some of the biggest issues, said lobbyist Rich Gold of Holland & Knight. Those issues will continue to be front and center this year, he added.

The 2020 elections, and specifically the possible changes they may bring in 2021, already are fueling some business.

"A lot of the business community is already doing active planning for some of the issues that would occur in a Democratic administration, like climate change and health care," said Gold, whose firm's lobbying revenue, as reported under the Lobbying Disclosure Act, was up slightly in 2019 to about $24.6 million. "There are a lot of people that are spending money already on those activities."

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Realtors continued to outpace much of K Street but disclosed spending less in 2019 than in 2018. The chamber spent $76.1 million in 2019 and the realtors spent $41.1 million. A chamber spokeswoman declined comment. The Realtors' group spent last year lobbying for the elimination of the home loan cap for veterans' mortgages and the seven-year reauthorization of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program, among others.

"In 2020 we are focused on working toward these and other policies that address housing affordability constraints plaguing markets across the country, secure needed infrastructure reforms and improve data privacy laws," said the group's president, Vince Malta, in a statement to CQ Roll Call.

Tech giant Google reported a 44 percent slide in its spending on federal lobbying, as it restructured its K Street operation, with $11.8 million in 2019, down from $21.2 million in 2018.

Still, big tech has supplanted the nation's largest defense and aviation contractors among the 10 largest spenders. Boeing Co. reported spending $13.8 million in 2019, a year of crisis for the company whose 737 Max jets remain grounded worldwide after high-profile crashes. Northrop Grumman disclosed spending $13.3 million, while Lockheed Martin reported shelling out $12.9 million on federal lobbying last year.

Source: CQ News
