Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TYN-5M91-F0JP-W1HF-00000-00US-China clash bares ideals lost in cyberspace2018-12-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisINQUIRERPg. 18US-China clash bares ideals lost in cyberspaceAlan Dupont, Contributing National Security Editor

Virtual conflict may well spark the next hot war

Welcome to the tech wars. Despite her release on bail, the arrest of senior Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou has ratcheted up simmering tensions between China and the US in a global contest for technological supremacy between the leaders of competing and increasingly incompatible systems of governance. This quest for information dominance is a driver of global cyber conflict, a shadowy undeclared war that is intensifying and becoming a serious security concern for Australia.

Control of three key enabling technologies - semiconductors, quantum computing and artificial intelligence - would give the pre-eminent cyber nation a decisive advantage in this high-stakes competition. Technological excellence has always underpinned economic and military capability and is a powerful catalyst for change in the international system. No longer is the internet dominated by the US and the West, as other states seek a more prominent role in shaping the rules of the digital age.

Two other dimensions of the emerging tech wars have equally profound consequences. They are the growing tension between security and privacy in cyberspace, exemplified by the furious debate that accompanied the passage of encryption legislation, and protecting consumer and media rights from unethical practices by tech titans, recently highlighted by the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission's warning about discriminatory conduct by Google and Facebook.

Few would dispute the need for security agencies to access the encrypted communications of suspected terrorists, criminals and paedophiles. But this is difficult to achieve in practice without undermining the same encryption systems that protect our personal data. It's unclear how technical assistance and technical capabilities notices can be made to work without technology companies having to modify their apps or systems to allow government agencies access to encrypted private data.

Finding the right regulatory balance in the coming crackdown on digital platforms won't be easy either. Corporations such as Google have resisted regulation, arguing they are technology, not media, companies and that protecting the security of their users "has long been an essential part of our mission" - claims disputed by their critics. Regulating the activities of Chinese digital giants Alibaba and Tencent is an even more challenging problem because of China's techno-nationalism.

These disagreements are unlikely to be resolved quickly because they are central to a more fundamental contest of ideas and beliefs about the rules and architecture of the information highway. This pits democrats against autocrats, big tech against government, big tech against consumers, and sometimes governments against their own people. It encompasses just about every aspect of modern life, from banking and health to industry, business, recreation and national security.

The internet was conceived in hope and optimism that it would create a better world. Established and championed by the US, the early internet was based on the principles of openness and self-regulation. That openness is being lost as authoritarian states impede or block the free flow of information in their own countries while exploiting the system's openness to weaken democracies. A report last year by Freedom House found that internet freedom had declined for seven consecutive years, largely because of restrictive practices by China, Russia and Middle Eastern autocracies. Their tools include outright censorship, proscribing virtual private networks and banning the use of encrypted messaging apps such as Telegram and WhatsApp.

For democracies, this raises the troubling question of what an internet dominated by China may look like as Beijing pulls out all stops to shape fifth-generation mobile network technology and its associated rules and architecture. Turbocharged by artificial intelligence, 5G promises to be transformational. The technology will incorporate the emerging internet of things, where machines can talk to one another, and will be critical to the development of smart utility grids, autonomous robots, drones and electric vehicles.

Countries that provide the technology and set global standards will reap enormous rewards in royalties, fees and innovation, giving them pole position in the race to develop the cyber-physical systems of the fourth industrial revolution.

In an insightful analysis for the US journal Foreign Affairs, Adam Segal argues that the US has ceded leadership in cyberspace to China. President Xi Jinping has set his country on the path to cyber dominance by integrating domestic regulations, tech-nological innovation and foreign policy. His aim is to build an "impregnable" cyber defence system, foster more world-class companies, lead the world in advanced technologies and give China a bigger voice in -internet governance. If this happens, says Segal, "the internet will be less global and less open". Xi promotes the virtues of cyber sovereignty as the primary organising principle of internet governance in direct opposition to US support for an open internet. Segal says the Xi era will be remembered for "putting an end to the West's naive optimism about the liberalising potential of the internet".

He may be right. Xi has moved resolutely to cocoon his people inside the "great firewall of China" and is busily constructing a comprehensive surveillance system that would be impossible in a democracy because of privacy provisions and human rights constraints. As a rule setter and key technology provider, Beijing would be well placed to bar un-approved content domestically while holding the master keys to foreign secrets and personal data.

China sees Huawei as the embodiment of its aspirations for technological leadership. But other countries see it as a stalking horse for the Chinese state.

The liberalising potential of the internet is also threatened by companies that have become the standard bearers of the information revolution and the darlings of tech-savvy millennials. Alphabet (Google's parent company), Amazon, Apple and Facebook have all been tarnished by revelations that they collected personal data without the knowledge of customers and sold it for commercial gain.

In arguing the Australian government's case for encryption legislation, national cyber security adviser Alastair MacGibbon effectively accused his big-tech critics of hypocrisy. He says smart home devices such as Google's Home and Amazon's Echo are "always on, always listening, and unregulated international tech companies are hoovering up our personal data as they have done for years and will target advertising at us". We "are already their product".

The threat to security is that tech giants have allowed their platforms and messaging apps to be manipulated by bad actors. Russia interfered in the 2016 US presidential election by creating an array of Twitter accounts of ostensible Trump supporters and went on a Facebook ad-buying spree. Islamic State pioneered online recruitment and propaganda outreach using YouTube, Telegram and WhatsApp. The digital platforms we use for news, information, shopping, social contact and entertainment also are being used to weaponise cyberspace.

To be fair, tech companies have begun to address these problems; Twitter deleted 70 million suspicious accounts between May and June. But they are still dragging their heels on transparency because their competitive edge derives from the personal databases they have compiled across many years, much of it without the knowledge or consent of users. Internal emails obtained by British parliamentarians show Facebook sought to collect the texts and calls of millions of users secretly, fearing that gathering the data openly would attract criticism.

American cryptographer and privacy specialist Bruce Schneier has a grim view of where all this is taking us. Technology "is being used to control what we see, what we can do and, ultimately, what we say. It makes us less safe. It makes us less free." Others are more optimistic, but users are beginning to lose trust in an -internet that once seemed synonymous with freedom of expression, engagement and the search for unalloyed knowledge. Big tech and dictatorships are both complicit. In fact the internet can im-poverish as well as enrich lives. As digital policy expert Karen Kornbluh observes, a technology that "promised to give power to the powerless has ended up hurting the very people it was supposed to help".

In democracies the idealistic vis-ion of a free and open internet is giving way to acceptance that some regulation is necessary to protect human rights and personal data. The internet cannot fix itself as free marketers like to argue. "There must be intervention on behalf of openness," says Kornbluh. But finding the right balance is difficult because of the rapidity of technological change, marked differences in attitudes to the use of encryption, and confusion over what constitutes personal data.

These problems are compounded by the lack of international agreement about the rules, standards and norms that will govern cyberspace and the possibility that the world could split into two separate information worlds, one led by the US and the other by China, if no consensus emerges, which seems likely.

Even on fundamental concepts such as the definition of cyberspace there are serious divisions. The US regards the domain as the technology (hardware, software) that enables free access. China and Russia define it as the content and interactions (speech, expression) between users, reflecting their determination to shield their netizens from information regarded as subversive, corrupting or inimical to national security.

Many countries are incorporating cyber tools into their military arsenals and strategies without clear rules governing their use or a full understanding of the consequences. Science commentator Anjana Ahuja characterises cyber conflict as "a virtual free-for-all" because there are no set rules. This free-for-all could become even more anarchical once AI becomes embedded in cyber weapons, cutting humans out of the decision-making loop and raising the possibility that machines could tip nations into a conflict that escalates into military confrontation.

The US military successfully has conducted field trials of micro drones that can attack their targets in autonomous swarms without the need for direct human control. Even the most carefully designed, modern weapons systems are vulnerable to hacking and sabotage. In October, the Pentagon tested computerised weapons systems by submitting them to hacking tests and found that many could be infiltrated and even taken over within hours. Some operators became aware their weapons had been compromised only when a screen pop-up instructed them to insert coins if they wished to continue.

In his book The Perfect Weapon: War, Sabotage, and Fear in the Cyber Age, veteran New York Times correspondent David E. Sanger concludes that "no modern military can live without cyber capabilities just as no nation could imagine, after 1918, living without airpower". Cyber weapons empower states to fight war by other means. And they are particularly suited to the grey zone between peace and war where much modern conflict plays out, because they are scalable, deniable and relatively cheap to develop.

Militaries are building up their offensive cyber capabilities at a rapid rate and testing them on adversaries in potentially dangerous ways. The best estimates are that there have been upward of 200 known state-on-state attacks during the past decade, including many that have targeted company secrets and critical infrastructure such as electricity grids, nuclear facilities and industrial operating systems. Civilians may be collateral damage or deliberately targeted, as they were when large numbers of Estonians were forced offline by patriotic Russian hackers in 2007.

There is no hard evidence that civilians have died from a cyber attack, but former US defence policymakers Michele Flournoy and Michael Sulmeyer contend this may change as our societies become increasingly wired. Cars are connecting to Wi-Fi and the internet of things is becoming more pervasive. The internet of bodies is next in line, with more medical devices being implanted and networked. These devices all risk becoming targets. US vice-president Dick Cheney had his heart defibrillator modified in 2007 so it couldn't be hacked by terrorists. Surgical robots were first hacked in 2015.

Without an international covenant and with AI on the threshold of automating computer weapons, chances are the next hot war will begin in cyberspace. A digital "Pearl Harbor" strike on a country's infrastructure is unlikely. The threat is "more corrosive than explosive", say Flournoy and Sulmeyer, but no less serious because cyber war is undermining the foundation of the internet: trust.

Restoring trust won't be possible without internationally agreed cyberspace rules. The challenges are formidable and many. China and Russia are reluctant to have their activities curtailed by international law, especially the laws of armed conflict. Smaller nations see cyberspace as an equalising and empowering domain where they can offset the inherent advantages enjoyed by more powerful countries. Big corporations and technology leaders don't want to cede their advantage. Terrorists and criminals thrive on anarchy and will exploit or ignore whatever rules are put in place.

To protect all states from cyber attack, reverse the steady erosion of privacy and prevent the misuse of data, enforceable norms and rules are essential, underpinned by two guiding principles: accountability and a light regulatory touch that preserves openness.

Australia should lend its diplomatic support to international efforts to outlaw cyber attacks aimed at sabotaging critical infrastructure and interfering in elections. Alliances should be broadened to include protection against digital attack. And consideration should be given to crafting mutual cyber defence pacts with other democracies in which members agree to assist each other in the event of a serious attack.

Domestically, the government should welcome and support a recommendation from the ACCC to establish a regulatory authority with the power of investigation to monitor the activities of tech companies. It also should explore laws that go beyond the recent encryption legislation to emulate the best aspects of Europe's General Data Protection Regulation. Although far from perfect, the GDPR is the first serious attempt to legislate a set of laws that pushes back against the steady erosion of privacy by powerful technology firms.

Our thinking must change, too. We live in a cyber realm that affects almost everything we do, touch and see. Soon it will be an inseparable physical part of us as the internet of the body becomes a wider reality. The approach of most governments has been grounded in the siloed, analog world of the 20th century and not the interconnected digital world of the present. Our laws, norms and governance arrangements need to be linked across portfolios.

And there must be a judicious balance between the legitimate needs of government, big tech and the fundamental right of individuals to protect their private data.Alan Dupont is chief executive of political and strategic risk consultancy the Cognoscenti Group and a non-resident fellow at the Lowy Institute.

urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D02C-00000-00U.S., China Quietly Seek Trade Solutions After Days of Loud Threats; Easing Trade Tensions; Support For Economic Vision; Hillary's Disrespect2018-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S., China Quietly Seek Trade Solutions After Days of Loud Threats; Easing Trade Tensions; Support For Economic Vision; Hillary's DisrespectLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, March 26th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Averting a trade war. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that the White House and China have held behind-the-scenes negotiations in an effort to ease rising tensions following the administration's move to impose strict tariffs. Futures are jumping on the story. Take a look. Dow Industrials up almost 300 points. White House Trade Advisor Peter Navarro weighed in on the President's trade strategy yesterday with me on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: President's vision here, it's stunningly brilliant. What he's trying to bring about is a fundamental reordering of the global trading system in a way which focuses on free markets, fair trade and reciprocal trade. It's really important to understand that everything the President does every morning that he goes to work is all centered around driving economic growth and creating jobs. Not just here in America but around the world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The news coming after a rough week for stocks. The Dow closed down yet again on Friday, capping a week which saw all three major indices down about six percent. In Europe this morning we're seeing gains across the board even if just fractional. FT-100, CAC quarante up a half of a percent. DAX Index up two-thirds of a percent. And in Asia overnight, stocks were mostly higher with the exception of China. All the majors up almost one percent. Supporting history, new Fox polls say that the majority of Americans are in favor of President Trump's plans to meet with North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un. Netflix banned, the big blow to the streaming service as it is told it cannot compete at the Cannes Film Festival. And another celebrity disappears from Snapchat. The details as model Chrissy Teigen becomes the latest to ditch the app. Then Sister Jean meets the Wolverines and number ones square off. More on their road to the final four coming up.

Plus, shifting gears, one student driver hits the gas straight into the driving school. Oh, we are breaking down that accident coming up this morning. Nobody was hurt. Wow. All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle, and pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter is here. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: That was a bad driving test.

(CROSSTALK)

MITCH ROSCHELLE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Full disclosure, not a member of my family.

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: Can you imagine that poor kid?

(CROSSTALK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It's usually some old person darting for the handicapped space in front of the golden corral. (INAUDIBLE) it happens all the time. My father saw a woman jump the railroad tracks in her truck in a car once, an elderly woman, Mrs. (Niece), may she rest in piece, jumped the railroad tracks right in the middle of Brookneal, hitting the gas, rather than the brakes. It was something from a Steve McQueen movie.

BARTIROMO: Oh, that's crazy. We got a lot on top this morning. Joining the conversation, former U .S. Ambassador to China and former Commerce Secretary Gary Locke is joining us momentarily. The host of "VARNEY & VARNEY", Stuart Varney weighs in as well. And then award-winning record producer, Harvey Mason Jr. is here. Wait until you see some of the shows and music he has produced. Big interview coming up. And we kick it off right here with this hour. And a look at Futures, markets on a scare right now, the Wall Street Journal is reporting that Washington and Beijing have begun negotiations on improving U.S. access to Chinese market. Adam Shapiro has live at the White House right now with the details. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. And we know that whether the things the Trump administration wants the Chinese to do is buy more semiconductors. As well as the President last week he said he wants reciprocal trades in which the tariffs against U.S. autos exports which is 25 percent in China get dropped down to -- he says the two percent it's about 2-1/2 percent when we import automobiles from China into the United States. But the President this morning also has a bit of a victory because it's been announced that the United States in its negotiations with South Korea have concluded and there are changes to the trade agreement with South Korea. So the President this morning has tweeted "The economy is looking really good, it has been many years that we have -- that we have seen these kind of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better." And Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury Secretary was on Fox News Sunday yesterday in which he talked about the discussions with China and what the administration is trying to you achieve. Here is what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: We're working on a pathway to see if we can reach an agreement as to what fair trade is for them to open up their markets, reduce their tariffs, stop forced technology transfer. These are all the things we want to do. But in a negotiation, have you to be prepared to take action and that's President Trump is doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: The administration not afraid of a trade war, nor are the Chinese for that matter but as you pointed out, Maria, the markets are seeming to be calmer and liking the fact that both sides are talking. Real quick on the South Korea deal, it will allow U.S. auto manufacturers to double the number of cars they export to South Korea. It will also make permanent, the exemption for South Korea from the current steel tariff. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching that. Adam, thank you. Adam Shapiro. Joining me right now to talk more about it is former U.S. ambassador to China, former Commerce Secretary, former governor of Washington State, now senior advisor and consultant at Davis Wright trimming, Gary Locke is with us right now. Good to see you, sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

GARY LOCKE, ADVISOR AND CONSULTANT, DAVIS WRIGHT TREMAINE: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think this is about? How do you think the U.S. can make a dent in that $375 billion deficit with the Chinese? What would you like to see?

LOCKE: We certainly have legitimate concerns about China's trade practices. China requires technology transfer. In many cases, so many parts of the Chinese economy are off limits to foreign and U.S. investment whereas there are virtually no impediments to Chinese investment here in America. So that's an unlevel playing field. And when American companies do invest in China oftentimes they have to have a local partner which means transferring your knowledge, sharing your knowledge or intellectual property or trade secrets with those partners which then ultimately overtime will take it and run with it and hurt U.S. companies. So there's been for long an unlevel playing field against U.S. and foreign companies. That's what we need to target. I'm concerned that these tariffs, these surcharges on Chinese goods coming into the United States will not help us achieve that purpose of leveling the playing field. Instead, it's just going to raise the prices that American consumers pay, whether it's at Target, Macy's, Costco, Home Depot, you name it. And in many cases, mane of these products that are coming from China, that's the only place where you can get them. I mean, no one in America makes microwave ovens anymore. They're all coming from China. Electronic goods, clothing, toys. So, ultimately it's just going to raise the price of -- that Americans face which means less money in their pockets for buying a car, vacation, college tuition.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I know. I understand. So then what is the answer, Gary? I mean, you know, we know that China is trying to transfer technology from the United States to China and they're doing it in the very industries that are supposed to be the industries of tomorrow, like robotics, like A.I., biotech, all these very important leadership industries. So, if it's not tariffs, what other restrictions should be in place against China? Because I know like if you're a Ford motor, for example and you want to sell in China to the 1.3 billion person population, the first thing you have to do according to the Chinese government is give them all your technology. You have to basically say, OK, here's how we do the cars, here's how we have inserted technology all over the cars and then maybe you can get a foothold in China but you certainly won't get more than 49 percent of any joint venture, even then.

LOCKE: Well, that's why I think that United States has to work with all of our allies around the world and the E.U. and elsewhere that have been subjected to these same unfair treatment and rules and regulations and together we impose basically the same restrictions on China. China very much wants to invest and buy companies and partner with U.S. companies and other foreign companies around the world. We need to put restrictions on their ability to invest and go abroad as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes. How much of this is also about a national security concern, Gary? Because I think most people and certainly businesses in the United States, big businesses who have tried to get a foothold in China, they understand this. They know that they haven't been given a fair shake. They will only be allowed to own 49 percent of a joint venture. They have to give up all their technology secrets. But in terms of national security, the chairman of the House Intel Committee, Devin Nunes was with me yesterday and he right now told me he's investigating Chinese practices over intellectual property theft but he also says China's manipulation goes beyond that to military and infrastructure. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: The Chinese just opened up a base, a military base in Jaboti, Jaboti is at the entrance of the Red Sea in the heart of the Middle East at the -- at --in the Indian Ocean, a long way away from China. We believe that they are looking at investing in ports and infrastructure around the globe, not just for military capabilities but also to control those governments to have -- to have the ability to lobby and manipulate governments.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That's a big deal, Ambassador.

LOCKE: It is. And that's why you had so many members of the U.S. military saying that the state department needs to invest more in terms of its soft power, it's diplomatic outreach and programs all around the world so that we build up the brand of America that we create allies and partners. I mean, China is really stepping into the vacuum created by the United States. And long ago we used to have programs to help people farm, to bring water, clean water and hospitals and build bridges and roads. We're not doing that anymore. Who is? China. And China's creating that favorable political strategic climate all around the world to our detriment. Getting back to the issue of intellectual property and technology, America really needs to put more money into supporting basic R&D in things like robotics and Artificial Intelligence. China is throwing billions of dollars at the world's premier foremost scientists and researchers in this area, creating laboratories for them, paying for all their staff. They're enticing people from around the world to set up their laboratories in China. Where is America? That's how we need to really confront some of these technological challenges facing them.

BARTIROMO: Yes. These are -- these are big issues. And by the way, the President yesterday said that he wants to cut the trade imbalance by $100 billion. Do you think he'll be able to do that? Get it down to 275 versus the current 375 billion?

LOCKE: I don't know if he will or not. I don't think that tariffs, surcharges on taxes, imposed on Chinese goods coming into the United States will do that because so much of what we're facing is as we said an unlevel playing field for U.S. and foreign companies in China where they're limited in what they can invest in, where they have to have a partner. UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This endeavor is unique. It's a broadway show, it's a concert, it's a television show, it's kind of the best of all of these worlds.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That is awesome. I can't wait to see that one. Tell us why, what attracted you to that project?

MASON: Well, the story, the music, the cast. It's just this -- it's an epic story and we've got an incredible cast. The music is amazing. Andrew Lloyd Webber, iconic music, iconic story so --

BARTIROMO: Sure. But does -- did the challenges change with live T.V.?

MASON: Totally. We've got over 30-piece band and orchestra, full strings, and everybody is singing live. Nothing is recorded, nothing is pre-done, all the musicians are playing. So, it's going to be exciting.

MCDOWELL: Have you worked with Lloyd Webber, has he been involved in this production at all?

MASON: He has.

MCDOWELL: And how has he contributed? Because I know that having met him before, he is so focused on the music and the musicians, like he is a composer's composer.

MASON: He is. And it's amazing music. So, he's handling it in very, very great -- it's a great way that he approaches his music and he interacts with the cast, and working with me, a lot of details, specifics, this baseline, this vocal part. But I mean, it's iconic music. You can't go the wrong way with it. You have to address it very carefully.

CARTER: Do you have one piece in the show that you're most excited about?

MASON: Sara Bareilles and John Legend sing a couple things where they're interacting on a couple numbers that are really special and both of them have such great voices. So, it's really hard to hard to pick one but those two going back and forth is special.

MCDOWELL: I followed both of them on Instagram --

MASON: So, do I.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Well, there's an array of talent, right? There's John Legend is out, Alice Cooper. So, what it's like working with such a wide-ranging cast?

MASON: It's great. But that's what makes it so special is the variety and different genres they all come from and the different skillsets they bring to the table. But I've been doing that my whole career and I've been fortunate to work with some great, great people.

BARTIROMO: I bet.

ROSCHELLE: Do you think having contemporary performers performing something that's I guess from the 70s, Jesus Christ Superstar, can sort of bring some of that sort of classic broadway to a younger demographic?

MASON: Yes. And I think that's the goal with casting the right people, you want people who can obviously carry the songs and really pull it off, but you're using some great music along with these new talents to bring the audiences together. And that's what we're trying to do with the music, we try and present it in a new and fresh way, but we're very respectful of the way that it was originally conceived. You don't want to offend the original fans. We want to reintroduce it to new --

BARTIROMO: How do you -- how do you carry the songs from Aretha Franklin? I mean, you're also producing the upcoming Aretha Franklin biopic called "Respect" starting Jennifer Hudson. That's going to be hot.

MASON: It is. That's another amazing project. Again, I'm very fortunate I'm working on some great things.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about Jennifer Hudson, how she -- how she's doing for, you know --

MASON: Well, that project is early on. We haven't moved past the script yet but we do have her excited about the project and we've been working together for almost 11 years on different projects. We did "Dreamgirls" together, so I'm a huge Jennifer Hudson fan.

MCDOWELL: But the idea of it gives me chills.

BARTIROMO: I know, it's great.

MCDOWELL: Thinking about just Aretha and her catalog and her voice and her achievements and Jennifer, too.

MASON: And it's a great story. A lot of people don't know the story and the depth of the things that went on with her, so it's going to be really an empowering story.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I'll be there watching that one. Harvey, great to see you.

MASON: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Best of luck with all of these projects. Harvey Mason, Jr. Stay with us. More MORNINGS WITH MARIA, next.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Monday to you. And it is Monday, March 26.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Averting a trade war -- "The Wall Street Journal" this morning is reporting that the White House and China have held behind the scenes negotiations in an effort to ease rising tensions following the administration's move to impose strict tariffs.

As a result markets are rallying. Dow industrials expected to be up almost 300 points right at the start of trading this morning. That's better than 1 percent. Nasdaq up 1.5 percent right now, 97 points higher. And the S&P is up 31; that's 1.25 percent.

The news comes after a rough week at the office last week. Dow Industrials down yet again Friday capping a week which saw all three major indices fall roughly 6 percent.

In Europe this morning, slight gains across the board -- take a look. The FT 100 is up half a percent. The CAC 40 up a third of a percent. And the DAX index up two thirds of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, stocks were mostly higher with the exception of China. Best performers there Kospi index in Korea up almost 1 percent.

Well, apology status -- Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg taking out a full-page ad in newspapers across the globe promising to do better following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Is it enough? The very latest and the new questions over the company's access to your data.

And then gaining ground, new Fox News poll show Republicans are tightening the gap with Democrats. What you need to know ahead of the important 2018 midterm elections.

After more than 200 years in business, America's oldest gun maker has filed for bankruptcy -- the details behind Remington's decision.

Plus a good move ore tunnel vision -- Elon Musk debuting the boring company's latest swag -- life-sized Legos. Why he plans to build on the company's flame thrower success.

All those stories this morning coming up and joining me to talk all about it -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; PWC partner Mitch Roschelle; and pollster and the president of Maslansky and Partners Lee Carter.

Great to see everybody.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning -- every Monday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNERS: We've got a lot of news.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we do. We see a market that's completely turning around this morning.

ROSCHELLE: And the market did a complete reversal from where it was Thursday and Friday.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: No, it's so interesting. Last week initially we were talking about the China tariffs. We're saying I wonder if this is a negotiating strategy, if he's going to throw this out and then China connects on the cable and that's what we are seeing maybe it's happening.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And trying to maybe into the table the whole time but backdoor negotiations.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you -- after looking at this subject I have learned so much about what China is doing. It's not just about transferring technology to China and acquiring some of the best and most important sectors that we are or trying to acquire, the most important sectors like robotics and AI that China is doing.

They are also trying hard to be number one in terms of military. They're acquiring infrastructure all across the world, owning that infrastructure and then getting a spot on the sea level -- on the sea lane in different parts of the world and setting up military bases there.

Very interesting. That's what Devin Nunes from the intel committee told me yesterday.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: But that's one of the reasons that the spending bill in the runaway spending and the debt dovetails with what we're trying to do with China because we lose some valuable ammunition the more that we run up our national debt and the more that we basically are running $1 trillion budget deficits every year because then we have to lien on China even more to continue to buy that debt. And surely not sell what they already own being the largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasury.

BARTIROMO: Which is why every time we hear a rumor that China's starting to sell treasuries or buying lesser than what people expect -- you see massive selloff in the stock market.

MCDOWELL: And quite -- my opinion, but if you wanted to really have your allies lock arms with you to take on in China, it's not just the United States intellectual property and abuse and its motives. We need to lock arms with our allies so then you don't throw on those steel and aluminum tariffs and basically kind of shock those very allies ahead of wanting to take a harder stance with China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: The 10 industries that they want to, by 2025 be the world leader in --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: -- aerospace, next gen technology, robotics, agriculture, rail advancements --

BARTIROMO: -- shipping and bio-tech.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. These are things that we also want to be leaders in.

BARTIROMO: I love that list and I will focus on that list. We're going to talk about that list coming up this morning.

And joining the conversation Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano is here; Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred making an appearance today, he will be in studio with us; former U.S. Ambassador to China and former Commerce Secretary Gary Locke is with us as well. A lot to talk about with him.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off right now with this. Markets -- futures are indicating a big rally at the start of trading this morning. Markets are on a tear as "The Journal" is reporting that Washington and Beijing has begun negotiations on improving U.S. access to Chinese markets.

This comes as House intel committee chairman Devin Nunes told me yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", "congressional investigators have been looking into Chinese practices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: They are stealing our intellectual property. So either it's through the internet or it's through investing in educational systems here or think tanks. They are bringing people here. I believe that they are still in Silicon Valley blind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the chairman of the Republican Study Committee and North Carolina Congressman Mark Walker. Chairman Walker -- good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

REP. MARK WALKER (R-NC), REPUBLICAN STUDY COMMITTEE: Thanks-- Maria.

BARTIROMO: So Devin Nunes just said that his committee is investigating this. What should be investigated?

They are the biggest stealers of our intellectual property and have been doing it for decades.

So the Trump body language and the movement to throw down some for warning shots I think is very important and sends a very clear message.

BARTIROMO: So you like what the President has done here then?

WALKER: I do. Obviously we want to make sure that the tariffs ultimately do not get to the place where there is an increase in consumer costs or ultimately even jobs. But I believe going after bad actors and communicating very clearly what the Chinese have been doing, specifically their leadership, I think is a very educational moment for Americans.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell -- though if China retaliates, they've already started talking about tariffs on pork but then what about hogs. That would hammer the very people in your state. And if they do retaliate, they will go after those states in those places who voted for President Trump.

WALKER: Absolutely. There's no question. And this will just impact theirs, even has ties to the E.U. the F Corp located here in Greensboro, very concerned, even things about Wrangler jeans -- a 25 percent hike across Europe.

WALKER: I think at this point, Maria, that is correct. Maybe more a gesture than anything else but ultimately, as most of your panelists would know, we certainly don't want to let it devolve into a trade war.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BARTIROMO: Well, ok. You said that. That's what we were talking about all morning but fiscal has an order $1.3 trillion spending bill, I don't know. It doesn't add up, sir.

Democrats had have a five-point lead over the GOP but this comes as Republican Pennsylvania Congressman Ryan Costello confirmed yesterday that he will drop his bid for reelection and retire at the end of his term.

Do I believe that we have much to run off in 2017? We do -- ANWR, regulatory relief, tax reform, pro-life legislation. But if Republicans get to the mindset that we can spend like the Democrats do and not doing anything from here to November, I think that would be cataclysmic.

I think it's very important to continue to build on those promises. The Republican Study Committee is coming back with the great fervor pushing for a balanced budget amendment. We'll also develop our own Republican Study Committee budget that's going to be much more in tune in balancing intense come elected and very important we communicate. Hopefully in 10 and 11 -- at the most 12 years, it's very important that we communicate these principles to the American public --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: -- if Republicans want to keep the majority.

BARTIROMO: Well, we want to talk about this because we all have problems with the spending bill -- sir. I mean the economy will obviously be a big issue in the midterms and the President is tweeting about this, this morning.

Here's what the President said just a few minutes ago. "The economy is looking really good. It has been many years that we have seen these kinds of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better."

Do you agree with that? And do you believe that if we keep running up all of this deficit, that that is going to cut into the growth?

WALKER: I believe temporarily we are seeing some wonderful economic recovery news. However, if you look out just a few years, our mandatory spending had gone from about a third of our budget to closing in to 75 percent, 76 percent of our budget. We simply can't sustain that.

In this specific omnibus, it increased nondiscretionary spending -- or discretionary spending 13 percent in one year. As a fiscal conservative, some people like to say a fiscal hawk. Sometimes we feel like we're the adults in the room trying to say or trying to put out some warning signs. We are the only group that doesn't have a special interest that we are advocating for.

Where Defense needs massive, they were out, stood in the empty silos in Alaska where this previous administration depleted our military defense. But at the same time we have to understand that unless we're willing to go after this mandatory reforms, we will not leave the next generation very much to work with.

CARTER: So Congressman -- you guys have the House, you have the Senate, you have the White House. And if you can't get this through now, when are you going to get it through and how is it going to be different eight months from now than it is right now.

Because it seems to me, that if you couldn't have gotten it done this time, how are you going to get it done?

WALKER: That's a very fair question. I remember sitting in the room with the Majority Leader when Congressman Tom Graves came up with the idea almost a year ago that we would get all 12 appropriations bills done through the house for the first time in 13 years.

We have met that goal, sent it to the Senate. The senate never took up a single appropriation. We then tried again in package 4 props bills, budgetary bills and put into one particular piece of legislation. They still didn't take it up.

So there has been some talk. Does the Senate eventually move to a 51 simple majority when it comes to any kind of budgeting idea or appropriations? I don't know the solution, but we're going to keep the pressure, keep the press on, really exposing those who are putting a stop in the progress.

MCDOWELL: And clearly there's some politicking going on with the pushback on President Trump signing the spending bill on Friday because Secretary Mnuchin of the Treasury Department was on with Chris Wallace yesterday. And Chris Wallace had to remind him well, that was ruled some years ago unconstitutional.

BARTIROMO: There will be a constitutional amendment.

MCDOWELL: So again, you know, you can pass a constitutional amendment but that requires a two-thirds vote in the House and Senate.

WALKER: It does -- Dagen. But let's not just talk about the policy. Let's talk about the process of getting a nearly 2,300 page bill on the evening of the next day you're supposed to be voting for it.

We have eight full-time people, staffers on the Republican Study Committee. Two stayed up all night, trying to get through the bill. They weren't able to complete. I think it is preposterous to ask us to vote on something so lengthy with the amount of pork and level that was in the specific piece of legislation.

BARTIROMO: But YOU did it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, this is an important point that you bring up. You voted against it so you weren't one of those people who said all right, look, I'm just going to throw in the towel here just to get the spending for the military.

WALKER: Well, this bill should've never reached the President's desk. It did not even have some of the specifics that he had asked for, for wall funding. I think we acquiesced a little bit too much. I've got to give the speaker a little bit of props here because I understood some of the talks and some of the battles that he was facing trying to get at least some of the things across the finish line.

But this bill is really not good. You're talking about an increase of 13 percent in one year in discretionary funding. That is ridiculous.

I believe it's very important that not just 90 of us but more and more members of Congress have to draw the line somewhere when it comes to being fiscally conscious.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: This is preposterous that we would increase this kind of debt. We are now matching levels -- think about this - -we are now matching levels if not even more of a deficit than Obama's last three, maybe four years in office.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

WALKER: We promise to do better and I hope that -- I hope more members will wake up to that cause.

WALKER: Thank you.

ROSCHELLE: Larry -- looking more broadly at the tech sector and the fact that the big run-up in the market, a lot of it was the big tech names in terms of the S&P. How -- does this really impact the broader technology sector, investors are going to start shying away a bit?

MCDOWELL: And somebody needs to train media train him to say I'm sorry and actually look like you're sorry, can you teach that?

SIMONETTI: Well, pivotal research -- suspending fish management, we'll see if anything happens.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll watch that. Lauren, thank you. Lauren Simonetti there. Coming up, virtual handyman service, Handy, inking a dead with Wal-Mart. Why this pairing may hit the nail on the head in the battle against Amazon, back in a minute.

DANI KLUPENGER, TENNIS CHANNEL PRESENTER: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel COURT REPORT, a special presentation for Fox Business, I'm Dani Klupenger. Venus Williams first listed the trophy at the Miami Open 20 years ago. Sunday, she needed all of her experience to reach the round of 16.

The three-time champion saved three match point against (INAUDIBLE) report, eventually closing out the win 7-5 in the decider, after almost three hours on court. Venus, moving on to phase to defending champion, Johanna Konta for a spot in the elite eight.

On the men's side, the winner at Indian Wells, Juan Martinez, continued his quest for back to back tour titles in style as he dispatched (INAUDIBLE) in straight sets. The popular Argentine has looked fit and sharp all week in his game and is now on a 13-match win streak.

And don't forget Tennis Channel's extensive live coverage of the Miami open hits air daily at 10:30 a.m. Eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the handyman for digital age -- one company is making it easier than ever to recruit help around the house whether it's cleaning or putting together that new piece of furniture. Handy, lets you book top-rated home service professional at touch of a button. And now, it is teaming up with Wal-Mart. Joining us right now to talk more about that and first on Fox Business interview is: Oisin Hanrahan, he is Handy's Co-Founder and CEO. Oishin, I love this idea.

OISHIN HANRAHAN, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, HANDY'S: It's great to be here. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic, thank you for joining us. First, tell us how it works and about your partnership for Wal-Mart?

HANRAHAN: So, Handy is the easiest ways to get things done inside your home; you think about everything from cleaners, to handyman, plumbers, electricians, and it's the easiest way to book services, you just go to handy.com or Handy mobile app, put in a zip code, you put more you'd like do. You could instantly check out in about 30 seconds.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but how do we know these are reputable people that we want inside the house?

HANRAHAN: So, we've got out and we've done a lot of work to background check, social security screen, and put a lot of effort into screening every professional we put in the platform. We've had over two million people apply to join the platform, we've had only about 100,000 of them activated and doing work and that's why Wal-Mart decided to partner with us because that's the experience they want to deliver to their customers.

CARTER: Now, are people rated?

HANRAHAN: Of course, yes, so we rate every professional that on the platform. And if you go to a Wal-Mart store, so we partner to do T.V. mounting, and furniture assembling, today you can go to any 2,000 Wal- Mart's right there on the T.V. aisle or in a furniture assembly aisle, and the furniture -- you can buy a cart right off the shelf to purchase in- store.

ROSCHELLE: What if not that this happens, but we've all had bad experiences with contractors, what if there ends up a bad experience is handy on the hook or get to deal with this privately with the contractors?

HANRAHAN: I think that's a great question because you're not going to get services to the same level of perfection as products, and that's just a hard problem to solve. We take 100 percent responsibility for every transaction on the platform; we get $5 million of insurance and Handy happiness guarantee to make sure that we make the customer happy.

CARTER: I've got to say I have found -- I've used your service when I had an apartment here in the city and it's amazingly convenient. How -- and I just kind of assumed because I was in New York City that I was able to get this level of -- you know, there a hundred of different people that I can choose from; how does that work in the rest of the country.

HANRAHAN: So, we've rolled out now to about 90 percent of the country to make sure that we've got 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. availability, but half of the country it's next day, the other half, it's two-day availability. And it's one of the reasons why we built so much technology that power this platform at scale.

MCDOWELL: Is this like, well, I think it's called pro-referral at Home Depot. It's similar, because I know on of the guys, Ethen Anderson, who founded that company and they sold in to the -- again, I was a start-up, then they eventually turn around and sold the Home Depot.

HANRAHAN: So, what we don't is we focus right on the transaction. We don't what you to have to go through any referral process, we don't want to have to, you know, ask you to take on any of the clunkiness of scheduling or negotiation on price or availability or scope of work. So, we've got all the way to transaction, and that's one of the reasons why Wal-Mart, and Wayfair, and others have decided to partner with us because we need biproducts today, we can offer you services in the same sort of purchase flow. So, there's no price variability or price negotiations, we just turn services into products and that's a little different from anyone who's come before.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you make money? Do you take a piece, a cut from every transaction then?

HANRAHAN: We take a little bit from every transaction.

BARTIROMO: Amazon offers similar services to Handy, right? Like furniture assembly, do you see your company's partnership with Wal-Mart as response to the competition? What does that do for the competitive landscape out there?

HANRAHAN: Yes. I think there's a lot going on right now in retail. So, if you look at what Amazon is doing, obviously they're pushing the boundary on what customers expect, customers used to expect free returns, then free shipping, then free two-day. And now, I think more and more people are expecting to figure out how to deliver an amazing experience to customers at scale, and Amazon has obviously done a great job here. We internally have pushed our folks to think about how to step back from Amazon; we've launched something internally called the Amazon challenge, which is to not buy from any Amazon property for four weeks. So, no Kindle, no Amazon Echo, no Prime, no Amazon video, to try and emphasize: look, this is the kind of experience and this is how pervasive Amazon has become in your life. So, we've been going the opposite direction --

BARTIROMO: That's amazing.

HANRAHAN: -- in trying to educate folks how competitive the market really is.

BARTIROMO: That's great. Oishin, great to see you, thanks so much. We'll check out Handy. Oishin Hanrahan, we'll be right back

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Monday to you, and it is Monday, March 26th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast --

END

urn:contentItem:5RYY-BND1-JBHT-D01W-00000-00U.S., China Quietly Seek Trade Solutions After Days of Loud Threats; Easing Trade Tensions; Support For Economic Vision; Hillary's Disrespect2018-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S., China Quietly Seek Trade Solutions After Days of Loud Threats; Easing Trade Tensions; Support For Economic Vision; Hillary's DisrespectLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, March 26th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Averting a trade war. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that the White House and China have held behind-the-scenes negotiations in an effort to ease rising tensions following the administration's move to impose strict tariffs. Futures are jumping on the story. Take a look. Dow Industrials up almost 300 points. White House Trade Advisor Peter Navarro weighed in on the President's trade strategy yesterday with me on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: President's vision here, it's stunningly brilliant. What he's trying to bring about is a fundamental reordering of the global trading system in a way which focuses on free markets, fair trade and reciprocal trade. It's really important to understand that everything the President does every morning that he goes to work is all centered around driving economic growth and creating jobs. Not just here in America but around the world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The news coming after a rough week for stocks. The Dow closed down yet again on Friday, capping a week which saw all three major indices down about six percent. In Europe this morning we're seeing gains across the board even if just fractional. FT-100, CAC quarante up a half of a percent. DAX Index up two-thirds of a percent. And in Asia overnight, stocks were mostly higher with the exception of China. All the majors up almost one percent. Supporting history, new Fox polls say that the majority of Americans are in favor of President Trump's plans to meet with North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un. Netflix banned, the big blow to the streaming service as it is told it cannot compete at the Cannes Film Festival. And another celebrity disappears from Snapchat. The details as model Chrissy Teigen becomes the latest to ditch the app. Then Sister Jean meets the Wolverines and number ones square off. More on their road to the final four coming up.

Plus, shifting gears, one student driver hits the gas straight into the driving school. Oh, we are breaking down that accident coming up this morning. Nobody was hurt. Wow. All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle, and pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter is here. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: That was a bad driving test.

(CROSSTALK)

MITCH ROSCHELLE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Full disclosure, not a member of my family.

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: Can you imagine that poor kid?

(CROSSTALK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It's usually some old person darting for the handicapped space in front of the golden corral. (INAUDIBLE) it happens all the time. My father saw a woman jump the railroad tracks in her truck in a car once, an elderly woman, Mrs. (Niece), may she rest in piece, jumped the railroad tracks right in the middle of Brookneal, hitting the gas, rather than the brakes. It was something from a Steve McQueen movie.

BARTIROMO: Oh, that's crazy. We got a lot on top this morning. Joining the conversation, former U .S. Ambassador to China and former Commerce Secretary Gary Locke is joining us momentarily. The host of "VARNEY & VARNEY", Stuart Varney weighs in as well. And then award-winning record producer, Harvey Mason Jr. is here. Wait until you see some of the shows and music he has produced. Big interview coming up. And we kick it off right here with this hour. And a look at Futures, markets on a scare right now, the Wall Street Journal is reporting that Washington and Beijing have begun negotiations on improving U.S. access to Chinese market. Adam Shapiro has live at the White House right now with the details. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. And we know that whether the things the Trump administration wants the Chinese to do is buy more semiconductors. As well as the President last week he said he wants reciprocal trades in which the tariffs against U.S. autos exports which is 25 percent in China get dropped down to -- he says the two percent it's about 2-1/2 percent when we import automobiles from China into the United States. But the President this morning also has a bit of a victory because it's been announced that the United States in its negotiations with South Korea have concluded and there are changes to the trade agreement with South Korea. So the President this morning has tweeted "The economy is looking really good, it has been many years that we have -- that we have seen these kind of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better." And Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury Secretary was on Fox News Sunday yesterday in which he talked about the discussions with China and what the administration is trying to you achieve. Here is what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: We're working on a pathway to see if we can reach an agreement as to what fair trade is for them to open up their markets, reduce their tariffs, stop forced technology transfer. These are all the things we want to do. But in a negotiation, have you to be prepared to take action and that's President Trump is doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: The administration not afraid of a trade war, nor are the Chinese for that matter but as you pointed out, Maria, the markets are seeming to be calmer and liking the fact that both sides are talking. Real quick on the South Korea deal, it will allow U.S. auto manufacturers to double the number of cars they export to South Korea. It will also make permanent, the exemption for South Korea from the current steel tariff. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching that. Adam, thank you. Adam Shapiro. Joining me right now to talk more about it is former U.S. ambassador to China, former Commerce Secretary, former governor of Washington State, now senior advisor and consultant at Davis Wright trimming, Gary Locke is with us right now. Good to see you, sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

GARY LOCKE, ADVISOR AND CONSULTANT, DAVIS WRIGHT TREMAINE: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think this is about? How do you think the U.S. can make a dent in that $375 billion deficit with the Chinese? What would you like to see?

LOCKE: We certainly have legitimate concerns about China's trade practices. China requires technology transfer. In many cases, so many parts of the Chinese economy are off limits to foreign and U.S. investment whereas there are virtually no impediments to Chinese investment here in America. So that's an unlevel playing field. And when American companies do invest in China oftentimes they have to have a local partner which means transferring your knowledge, sharing your knowledge or intellectual property or trade secrets with those partners which then ultimately overtime will take it and run with it and hurt U.S. companies. So there's been for long an unlevel playing field against U.S. and foreign companies. That's what we need to target. I'm concerned that these tariffs, these surcharges on Chinese goods coming into the United States will not help us achieve that purpose of leveling the playing field. Instead, it's just going to raise the prices that American consumers pay, whether it's at Target, Macy's, Costco, Home Depot, you name it. And in many cases, mane of these products that are coming from China, that's the only place where you can get them. I mean, no one in America makes microwave ovens anymore. They're all coming from China. Electronic goods, clothing, toys. So, ultimately it's just going to raise the price of -- that Americans face which means less money in their pockets for buying a car, vacation, college tuition.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I know. I understand. So then what is the answer, Gary? I mean, you know, we know that China is trying to transfer technology from the United States to China and they're doing it in the very industries that are supposed to be the industries of tomorrow, like robotics, like A.I., biotech, all these very important leadership industries. So, if it's not tariffs, what other restrictions should be in place against China? Because I know like if you're a Ford motor, for example and you want to sell in China to the 1.3 billion person population, the first thing you have to do according to the Chinese government is give them all your technology. You have to basically say, OK, here's how we do the cars, here's how we have inserted technology all over the cars and then maybe you can get a foothold in China but you certainly won't get more than 49 percent of any joint venture, even then.

LOCKE: Well, that's why I think that United States has to work with all of our allies around the world and the E.U. and elsewhere that have been subjected to these same unfair treatment and rules and regulations and together we impose basically the same restrictions on China. China very much wants to invest and buy companies and partner with U.S. companies and other foreign companies around the world. We need to put restrictions on their ability to invest and go abroad as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes. How much of this is also about a national security concern, Gary? Because I think most people and certainly businesses in the United States, big businesses who have tried to get a foothold in China, they understand this. They know that they haven't been given a fair shake. They will only be allowed to own 49 percent of a joint venture. They have to give up all their technology secrets. But in terms of national security, the chairman of the House Intel Committee, Devin Nunes was with me yesterday and he right now told me he's investigating Chinese practices over intellectual property theft but he also says China's manipulation goes beyond that to military and infrastructure. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: The Chinese just opened up a base, a military base in Jaboti, Jaboti is at the entrance of the Red Sea in the heart of the Middle East at the -- at --in the Indian Ocean, a long way away from China. We believe that they are looking at investing in ports and infrastructure around the globe, not just for military capabilities but also to control those governments to have -- to have the ability to lobby and manipulate governments.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That's a big deal, Ambassador.

LOCKE: It is. And that's why you had so many members of the U.S. military saying that the state department needs to invest more in terms of its soft power, it's diplomatic outreach and programs all around the world so that we build up the brand of America that we create allies and partners. I mean, China is really stepping into the vacuum created by the United States. And long ago we used to have programs to help people farm, to bring water, clean water and hospitals and build bridges and roads. We're not doing that anymore. Who is? China. And China's creating that favorable political strategic climate all around the world to our detriment. Getting back to the issue of intellectual property and technology, America really needs to put more money into supporting basic R&D in things like robotics and Artificial Intelligence. China is throwing billions of dollars at the world's premier foremost scientists and researchers in this area, creating laboratories for them, paying for all their staff. They're enticing people from around the world to set up their laboratories in China. Where is America? That's how we need to really confront some of these technological challenges facing them.

BARTIROMO: Yes. These are -- these are big issues. And by the way, the President yesterday said that he wants to cut the trade imbalance by $100 billion. Do you think he'll be able to do that? Get it down to 275 versus the current 375 billion?

LOCKE: I don't know if he will or not. I don't think that tariffs, surcharges on taxes, imposed on Chinese goods coming into the United States will do that because so much of what we're facing is as we said an unlevel playing field for U.S. and foreign companies in China where they're limited in what they can invest in, where they have to have a partner. Raising the prices of Chinese goods coming into the United States will slow down the Chinese economy to a bit, not much, because so much of what we buy is only made in China. So, Americans are going to continue buying things from China. They're just going to pay more which means less money in their pockets for other things. So, we've got to stop this trade war.

BARTIROMO: You want something done but you don't think the current tariff story is the way to do it. Let me get your take on North Korea because then there's that as well. The President made a surprise decision earlier this month to accept an invitation to meet with North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un in May. Now a new Fox News poll finds a majority of voters approve of that decision by a margin of 63 to 30 percent. What are your thoughts on this bilateral meeting and will China be involved?

LOCKE: Well, I think it's always good that we have talks as opposed to confrontation and bluster and so we need to lower the temperature and get the size sides talking. MCDOWELL: And how has he contributed? Because I know that having met him before, he is so focused on the music and the musicians, like he is a composer's composer.

MASON: He is. And it's amazing music. So, he's handling it in very, very great -- it's a great way that he approaches his music and he interacts with the cast, and working with me, a lot of details, specifics, this baseline, this vocal part. But I mean, it's iconic music. You can't go the wrong way with it. You have to address it very carefully.

CARTER: Do you have one piece in the show that you're most excited about?

MASON: Sara Bareilles and John Legend sing a couple things where they're interacting on a couple numbers that are really special and both of them have such great voices. So, it's really hard to hard to pick one but those two going back and forth is special.

MCDOWELL: I followed both of them on Instagram --

MASON: So, do I.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Well, there's an array of talent, right? There's John Legend is out, Alice Cooper. So, what it's like working with such a wide-ranging cast?

MASON: It's great. But that's what makes it so special is the variety and different genres they all come from and the different skillsets they bring to the table. But I've been doing that my whole career and I've been fortunate to work with some great, great people.

BARTIROMO: I bet.

ROSCHELLE: Do you think having contemporary performers performing something that's I guess from the 70s, Jesus Christ Superstar, can sort of bring some of that sort of classic broadway to a younger demographic?

MASON: Yes. And I think that's the goal with casting the right people, you want people who can obviously carry the songs and really pull it off, but you're using some great music along with these new talents to bring the audiences together. And that's what we're trying to do with the music, we try and present it in a new and fresh way, but we're very respectful of the way that it was originally conceived. You don't want to offend the original fans. We want to reintroduce it to new --

BARTIROMO: How do you -- how do you carry the songs from Aretha Franklin? I mean, you're also producing the upcoming Aretha Franklin biopic called "Respect" starting Jennifer Hudson. That's going to be hot.

MASON: It is. That's another amazing project. Again, I'm very fortunate I'm working on some great things.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about Jennifer Hudson, how she -- how she's doing for, you know --

MASON: Well, that project is early on. We haven't moved past the script yet but we do have her excited about the project and we've been working together for almost 11 years on different projects. We did "Dreamgirls" together, so I'm a huge Jennifer Hudson fan.

MCDOWELL: But the idea of it gives me chills.

BARTIROMO: I know, it's great.

MCDOWELL: Thinking about just Aretha and her catalog and her voice and her achievements and Jennifer, too.

MASON: And it's a great story. A lot of people don't know the story and the depth of the things that went on with her, so it's going to be really an empowering story.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I'll be there watching that one. Harvey, great to see you.

MASON: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Best of luck with all of these projects. Harvey Mason, Jr. Stay with us. More MORNINGS WITH MARIA, next.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Monday to you. And it is Monday, March 26.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Averting a trade war -- "The Wall Street Journal" this morning is reporting that the White House and China have held behind the scenes negotiations in an effort to ease rising tensions following the administration's move to impose strict tariffs.

As a result markets are rallying. Dow industrials expected to be up almost 300 points right at the start of trading this morning. That's better than 1 percent. Nasdaq up 1.5 percent right now, 97 points higher. And the S&P is up 31; that's 1.25 percent.

In Europe this morning, slight gains across the board -- take a look. The FT 100 is up half a percent. The CAC 40 up a third of a percent. And the DAX index up two thirds of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, stocks were mostly higher with the exception of China. Best performers there Kospi index in Korea up almost 1 percent.

Well, apology status -- Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg taking out a full-page ad in newspapers across the globe promising to do better following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Is it enough? The very latest and the new questions over the company's access to your data.

After more than 200 years in business, America's oldest gun maker has filed for bankruptcy -- the details behind Remington's decision.

All those stories this morning coming up and joining me to talk all about it -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; PWC partner Mitch Roschelle; and pollster and the president of Maslansky and Partners Lee Carter.

Great to see everybody.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning -- every Monday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNERS: We've got a lot of news.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we do. We see a market that's completely turning around this morning.

ROSCHELLE: And the market did a complete reversal from where it was Thursday and Friday.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: No, it's so interesting. Last week initially we were talking about the China tariffs. We're saying I wonder if this is a negotiating strategy, if he's going to throw this out and then China connects on the cable and that's what we are seeing maybe it's happening.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And trying to maybe into the table the whole time but backdoor negotiations.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you -- after looking at this subject I have learned so much about what China is doing. They are also trying hard to be number one in terms of military. They're acquiring infrastructure all across the world, owning that infrastructure and then getting a spot on the sea level -- on the sea lane in different parts of the world and setting up military bases there.

Very interesting. That's what Devin Nunes from the intel committee told me yesterday.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: But that's one of the reasons that the spending bill in the runaway spending and the debt dovetails with what we're trying to do with China because we lose some valuable ammunition the more that we run up our national debt and the more that we basically are running $1 trillion budget deficits every year because then we have to lien on China even more to continue to buy that debt. And surely not sell what they already own being the largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasury.

BARTIROMO: Which is why every time we hear a rumor that China's starting to sell treasuries or buying lesser than what people expect -- you see massive selloff in the stock market.

MCDOWELL: And quite -- my opinion, but if you wanted to really have your allies lock arms with you to take on in China, it's not just the United States intellectual property and abuse and its motives. We need to lock arms with our allies so then you don't throw on those steel and aluminum tariffs and basically kind of shock those very allies ahead of wanting to take a harder stance with China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: The 10 industries that they want to, by 2025 be the world leader in --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: -- aerospace, next gen technology, robotics, agriculture, rail advancements --

BARTIROMO: -- shipping and bio-tech.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. These are things that we also want to be leaders in.

BARTIROMO: I love that list and I will focus on that list. We're going to talk about that list coming up this morning.

And joining the conversation Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano is here; Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred making an appearance today, he will be in studio with us; former U.S. Ambassador to China and former Commerce Secretary Gary Locke is with us as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off right now with this. Markets -- futures are indicating a big rally at the start of trading this morning. Markets are on a tear as "The Journal" is reporting that Washington and Beijing has begun negotiations on improving U.S. access to Chinese markets.

This comes as House intel committee chairman Devin Nunes told me yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", "congressional investigators have been looking into Chinese practices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the chairman of the Republican Study Committee and North Carolina Congressman Mark Walker. Chairman Walker -- good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- it's Dagen McDowell -- though if China retaliates, they've already started talking about tariffs on pork but then what about hogs. BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: I believe temporarily we are seeing some wonderful economic recovery news. However, if you look out just a few years, our mandatory spending had gone from about a third of our budget to closing in to 75 percent, 76 percent of our budget. We simply can't sustain that.

In this specific omnibus, it increased nondiscretionary spending -- or discretionary spending 13 percent in one year. As a fiscal conservative, some people like to say a fiscal hawk. Sometimes we feel like we're the adults in the room trying to say or trying to put out some warning signs. We are the only group that doesn't have a special interest that we are advocating for.

Where Defense needs massive, they were out, stood in the empty silos in Alaska where this previous administration depleted our military defense. WALKER: That's a very fair question. I remember sitting in the room with the Majority Leader when Congressman Tom Graves came up with the idea almost a year ago that we would get all 12 appropriations bills done through the house for the first time in 13 years.

So there has been some talk. Does the Senate eventually move to a 51 simple majority when it comes to any kind of budgeting idea or appropriations? I don't know the solution, but we're going to keep the pressure, keep the press on, really exposing those who are putting a stop in the progress.

MCDOWELL: And clearly there's some politicking going on with the pushback on President Trump signing the spending bill on Friday because Secretary Mnuchin of the Treasury Department was on with Chris Wallace yesterday. BARTIROMO: There will be a constitutional amendment.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALKER: This is preposterous that we would increase this kind of debt. We are now matching levels -- think about this - -we are now matching levels if not even more of a deficit than Obama's last three, maybe four years in office.

BARTIROMO: He said if all of the documents requested are not on his desk and Bob Goodlatte's by the time they get back from their Easter break which is in two weeks.
