NAPOLITANO: Well former Attorney General Eric Holder was personally held in contempt of Congress and nothing happened. They didn't prosecute it. They didn't sue him. Now a couple of basics, you can't hold the FBI in contempt. You can hold the Custodian of Documents, who's refusing to surrender them in contempt. You can hold the Director of the FBI, who's stonewalling the surrender, same thing with the DOJ. NAPOLITANO: Absolutely. My view is if you have that attitude you don't belong in the government.

NAPOLITANO: Because the government's job especially the Department Of Justice is to find crimes, examine them, and prosecute them. Not look the other way. So I don't know where this is going to go.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. All right it is that time of the year. America's favorite pastime back. Thursday is Opening Day for baseball. ROB MANFRED, MLB COMMISSIONER: Great to see you, too, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. I got to tell you, I've seen a lot and done a lot of stuff over my career. The most exciting day of my life was when I threw out the first pitch at Yankee Stadium. I mean, it's incredible. Baseball really is exciting and what do you think about this Opening Day with all 30 clubs opening at once?

MANFRED: Well, we're thrilled about the idea. We think getting back to the tradition of everybody playing on Opening Day is an exciting thing for the sport. I think it give and opportunity to own Thursday, make opening day into the national holiday that it should be.

BARTIROMO: Can the Astro's do a repeat?

MANFRED: Hey, look. The Astro's are really talented, but there are a lot of good teams out there, a lot of buzz around the one team here in New York, the Yankees. Same thing with the Cubs. The Dodgers were great last year, so I think we're going to have a really competitive season.

BARTIROMO: Well, you've got a competitive season, but also because of all of these new rule changes, right? Let's talk about that. Speeding up the game is one of them. You're testing new pace of play rules in the minor leagues teams. You'll start with a runner on second base if the game goes into extra innings. Does this expand to the major leagues, and tell me about the rule changes and the impact.

MANFRED: Well the rule changes in the major leagues this year are really speeding up inning breaks. There's a clock. Batters have to be ready to go at 2:05. That should save us about 25 seconds on every inning break, which adds up to be a lot of time. We're limiting mound visits, six per game. The idea there is to take dead time out of the game. We're trying to proceed slowly at the major league level.

We've been more aggressive in the minor leagues. We have pitch clocks. We've had them for a number of years. We feel like they're successful. Those could come to the major leagues. The extra inning rule, I don't see that at the major league level. Some people really like it. It does make for excitement, but I think breaking the tradition of the extra inning game at the big league level is not likely to happen.

BARTIROMO: So the whole idea of speeding up the game and pacing differently, is that to make sure that it doesn't impact engagement, get the engagement (inaudible) because we've watched what has happened at the NFL. BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MANFRED: . there's things to do.

BARTIROMO: It's when you're at home watching.

MANFRED: Home, and every one of those breaks is an opportunity to tune away. We pay a lot of attention to what's going on in other sports. We've been fortunate, however. Our last two World Series have been really successful in terms of our ratings. And during the summer in 25 markets on game days, we're the number one programming on television, so we've been.

BARTIROMO: Still?

MANFRED: . very fortunate in that regard.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

MANFRED: Yes, it's - look, in the summer time, people remember that baseball is a national pastime and they tune into their local team.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point. So a lot of big moves there. The big Yankees move, obviously, the off season. Tell me about that because you've got the Yankees acquiring arguably the two best sluggers, right, Judge and Stanton. How were they able to pull off that trade?

MANFRED: Well, it was, I think, one of those things where the Marlins felt that, with their new ownership, they wanted to go down a slightly different path. The Yankees were there as willing buyers on what's a very large contract, but it's exciting in New York. The two players together last year hit 111 home runs. BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm glad you mentioned the Marlins because you've got the former shortstop, Derek Jeter, now owning the Marlins or part of the Marlins. What does that do for the game? Are former players becoming office executives good for the sport? What's the impact?

MANFRED: Oh, I think it's great for the sport. I'll tell you, it's difficult at the beginning, you take over a team, you haven't been an owner before, it's obviously difficult to get your footing, but I was down and saw an Marlins spring training game recently, talked to a bunch of people in the organization. Derek's done a phenomenal job. The organization is very positive. They've got a lot of great, young talent that they brought back in these trades, and I have every, every expectation that Derek's going to be really successful.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I would imagine when somebody who knows the games, knows the tricks, just knows how to get around the field as an owner, it could be real positive.

MANFRED: Look, I think it's a huge positive to have former players, particularly a player of Derek's stature, involved on the ownership side of the game.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the new tax law because we were talking about this earlier. The new tax law seems to be throwing some of the players and owners a curve ball, if you will. MANFRED: Well, it could really be an impediment to trades taking place.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MANFRED: . particularly trades that happened quickly because of the requirement evaluation. We think it was a mistake, that it really was not intended to apply to trades of baseball players, and we're hopeful that when things get clarified in the technical corrections that we'll deal with that issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because it's not - I mean, you don't think of a trade of a player being the same as capital gains trading stocks.

MANFRED: Well, if you think about the economics of it, right, I'm trading you something in return for something else. There's a very good argument that they should be treated of equal value, otherwise somebody's not acting rationally, which I don't think is the case with most of our clubs.

BARTIROMO: Have you been in touch with lawmakers on this issue?

MANFRED: We have.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MANFRED: We have.

BARTIROMO: So they're looking at it. They're aware that maybe there were unintended consequences.

MANFRED: Yes, there's a large list of things. Obviously, we have a couple of issues in the tax bill that we have been in touch with lawmakers about and hope they get clarified.

MANFRED: Very exciting for us. We feel that Europe's a frontier that we need to get to. We want to get there with our very best. We think a Yankee-Red Sox series will be very exciting and give us a foothold in Europe.

BARTIROMO: What about the streaming deals? This is an important piece of business right now for the league. You've got streaming deals with Twitter, ESPN, Intel, YouTube, Facebook Watch also stepping up to the plate with a deal with the league. The exclusive stream, 25 games. Tell us about this.

MANFRED: Well, being on the cutting edge of technology has been really good for our business on the development of Bantech (ph), the sale of that asset to Disney, and we feel that these streaming deals are really important in terms of capturing the next generation of fans.

BARTIROMO: You have to because that's where a lot of people watch the game, on their phone.

MANFRED: Absolutely. Look, the next generation wants to see their favorite sport, and we hope it's baseball, on a variety of different platforms, and our strategy has been to make the game available on those platforms.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but you said it earlier, you see more people in the stands that before, right? Are you having a hard time getting people in their seats because they're watching it on streaming?

MANFRED: Well, it's amazing. We had 114 million people went to see baseball live last year, minor league and major league baseball. That's a phenomenal number for us. Our ballpark experience is a little different than our broadcast experience. There's a certain commradery to it. There's all the entertainment that goes on in the ballpark, and fortunately our attendance has remained really stable.

BARTIROMO: And lots of giveaways when you're in the field.

MANFRED: That's right. Those promotional nights are very popular with our fans.

BARTIROMO: Rob, it's great to see you. Thanks so much.

MANFRED: It's great to see you, too, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good luck with opening day. We will be watching.

MANFRED: All right, thank you.

BARTIROMO: MLB Commissioner, Rob Manfred, there. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

On the men's side, the winner at Indian Wells, Juan Martinez, continued his quest for back to back tour titles in style as he dispatched (INAUDIBLE) in straight sets. The popular Argentine has looked fit and sharp all week in his game and is now on a 13-match win streak.

And don't forget Tennis Channel's extensive live coverage of the Miami open hits air daily at 10:30 a.m. Eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the handyman for digital age -- one company is making it easier than ever to recruit help around the house whether it's cleaning or putting together that new piece of furniture. Handy, lets you book top-rated home service professional at touch of a button. And now, it is teaming up with Wal-Mart. Joining us right now to talk more about that and first on Fox Business interview is: Oisin Hanrahan, he is Handy's Co-Founder and CEO. Oishin, I love this idea.

OISHIN HANRAHAN, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, HANDY'S: It's great to be here. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic, thank you for joining us. First, tell us how it works and about your partnership for Wal-Mart?

HANRAHAN: So, Handy is the easiest ways to get things done inside your home; you think about everything from cleaners, to handyman, plumbers, electricians, and it's the easiest way to book services, you just go to handy.com or Handy mobile app, put in a zip code, you put more you'd like do. You could instantly check out in about 30 seconds.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but how do we know these are reputable people that we want inside the house?

HANRAHAN: So, we've got out and we've done a lot of work to background check, social security screen, and put a lot of effort into screening every professional we put in the platform. We've had over two million people apply to join the platform, we've had only about 100,000 of them activated and doing work and that's why Wal-Mart decided to partner with us because that's the experience they want to deliver to their customers.

CARTER: Now, are people rated?

HANRAHAN: Of course, yes, so we rate every professional that on the platform. And if you go to a Wal-Mart store, so we partner to do T.V. mounting, and furniture assembling, today you can go to any 2,000 Wal- Mart's right there on the T.V. aisle or in a furniture assembly aisle, and the furniture -- you can buy a cart right off the shelf to purchase in- store.

ROSCHELLE: What if not that this happens, but we've all had bad experiences with contractors, what if there ends up a bad experience is handy on the hook or get to deal with this privately with the contractors?

HANRAHAN: I think that's a great question because you're not going to get services to the same level of perfection as products, and that's just a hard problem to solve. We take 100 percent responsibility for every transaction on the platform; we get $5 million of insurance and Handy happiness guarantee to make sure that we make the customer happy.

CARTER: I've got to say I have found -- I've used your service when I had an apartment here in the city and it's amazingly convenient. How -- and I just kind of assumed because I was in New York City that I was able to get this level of -- you know, there a hundred of different people that I can choose from; how does that work in the rest of the country.

HANRAHAN: So, we've rolled out now to about 90 percent of the country to make sure that we've got 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. availability, but half of the country it's next day, the other half, it's two-day availability. And it's one of the reasons why we built so much technology that power this platform at scale.

MCDOWELL: Is this like, well, I think it's called pro-referral at Home Depot. It's similar, because I know on of the guys, Ethen Anderson, who founded that company and they sold in to the -- again, I was a start-up, then they eventually turn around and sold the Home Depot.

HANRAHAN: So, what we don't is we focus right on the transaction. We don't what you to have to go through any referral process, we don't want to have to, you know, ask you to take on any of the clunkiness of scheduling or negotiation on price or availability or scope of work. So, we've got all the way to transaction, and that's one of the reasons why Wal-Mart, and Wayfair, and others have decided to partner with us because we need biproducts today, we can offer you services in the same sort of purchase flow. So, there's no price variability or price negotiations, we just turn services into products and that's a little different from anyone who's come before.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you make money? Do you take a piece, a cut from every transaction then?

HANRAHAN: We take a little bit from every transaction.

BARTIROMO: Amazon offers similar services to Handy, right? Like furniture assembly, do you see your company's partnership with Wal-Mart as response to the competition? What does that do for the competitive landscape out there?

HANRAHAN: Yes. I think there's a lot going on right now in retail. So, if you look at what Amazon is doing, obviously they're pushing the boundary on what customers expect, customers used to expect free returns, then free shipping, then free two-day. And now, I think more and more people are expecting to figure out how to deliver an amazing experience to customers at scale, and Amazon has obviously done a great job here. We internally have pushed our folks to think about how to step back from Amazon; we've launched something internally called the Amazon challenge, which is to not buy from any Amazon property for four weeks. So, no Kindle, no Amazon Echo, no Prime, no Amazon video, to try and emphasize: look, this is the kind of experience and this is how pervasive Amazon has become in your life. So, we've been going the opposite direction --

BARTIROMO: That's amazing.

HANRAHAN: -- in trying to educate folks how competitive the market really is.

BARTIROMO: That's great. Oishin, great to see you, thanks so much. We'll check out Handy. Oishin Hanrahan, we'll be right back

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Monday to you, and it is Monday, March 26th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast --

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RJ-G3Y1-JCSC-J15M-00000-00US, China should seek a truce in technology Cold War2020-09-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisNEWSUS, China should seek a truce in technology Cold War

It would be easy to dismiss the Trump administration’s campaign against Chinese apps TikTok and WeChat as part of an election strategy to attack China from all angles. The moves, however, as well as China’s counter-response, are contributing to a deeper pr... It would be easy to dismiss the Trump administration’s campaign against Chinese apps TikTok and...

It would be easy to dismiss the Trump administration’s campaign against Chinese apps TikTok and WeChat as part of an election strategy to attack China from all angles. The moves, however, as well as China’s counter-response, are contributing to a deeper pr...

It would be easy to dismiss the Trump administration’s campaign against Chinese apps TikTok and WeChat as part of an election strategy to attack China from all angles. The moves, however, as well as China’s counter-response, are contributing to a deeper problem at the heart of the global economy — one that can’t be resolved unless the world’s two biggest economies work together. Just as oil opened new possibilities for trade in the last century, data has become the lifeblood of trade growth in the 21st century. Trade in digital services, including apps such as TikTok, is booming. Data flows increasingly underpin trade in physical goods, too, supporting complex global value chains and emerging technologies such as blockchain, artificial intelligence and the Internet of things. The amount of cross-border bandwidth in use increased 148 times between 2005 and 2017, according to consultants McKinsey and Co. Meanwhile, however, global trade rules have barely changed since the 1990s. In effect, the world is trying to run a 21st-century, cloud-based economy on the equivalent of Windows 95. In effect, the world is trying to run a 21st-century, cloud-based economy on the equivalent of Windows 95 In the absence of shared global norms on how data flows should be governed, domestic policymakers everywhere are developing their own “patches” to regulate data and protect national security and their citizens’ privacy. The European Union implemented its General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in 2018. China has passed a sweeping cybersecurity law and, like India, is working on a major data protection law. If the US has been slower to regulate data, this is partly because it still dominates the industries and network architecture that handle global digital flows. Yet, given rising concerns about China’s access to Americans’ personal data, the tide of opinion there, too, is turning. Data regulations According to the OECD, the number of data regulations has risen from around 50 worldwide in the early 2000s to just under 250 in 2019. The overall degree of data control, as measured by the European Centre for International Political Economy’s Digital Trade Restrictiveness Index, has doubled in the past decade. The patchwork nature of these rules is creating complexity for firms and friction between nations. Just since the start of July, aside from Trump’s executive orders against TikTok and WeChat, India has banned 59 Chinese apps, and the European court of justice struck down the Privacy Shield mechanism, which US firms such as Facebook and Twitter had been using to handle personal data from the EU. Meanwhile, the US is locked in disputes over digital taxation with several European countries. Different countries naturally have different views, values and capabilities regarding data governance. All should have the right to regulate data as they see fit for purposes of national security. At the same time, the world needs to lay down some common rules for how to manage data, or such conflicts will only proliferate and stifle interoperability, investment and innovation. Some bilateral and regional agreements have begun to forge such common standards. The e-commerce chapter in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement on Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) allows members to regulate data flows in a rules-based way that minimizes barriers to trade. If China were to join the agreement — an idea gaining traction in Chinese policy-making circles — this would help align the country with next-generation data governance norms and support the aspirations of Chinese technology firms to “go global”. What’s really required, though, is a multilateral data governance regime that includes both China and the US. The first step is to complete ongoing World Trade Organisation negotiations on e-commerce. These talks should aim to set global ground rules and exceptions for data, while upholding the centrality of the WTO system. Next, the G20 should build on last year’s Osaka Declaration on Digital Economy, which affirmed the need for international policy discussions to maximise the benefits of digitalisation. A “Digital 20” (D20), comprised of the world’s 20 largest digital companies, should bring together figures from government, industry, academia and non-governmental organisations to develop a workable, fact-based approach that safeguards national security while providing consumers with trust and privacy, and businesses with clarity and predictability. Leaders in both countries should seek industry consensus and best practices that can be used to establish global standards The US and China are home to most of these big tech companies. Rather than treating each other’s firms as national security threats, leaders in both countries should seek industry consensus and best practices that can be used to establish global standards. To reassure security hawks on both sides, the world will need clear standards to judge what constitutes secure data management practice. Countries should be encouraged to use international standards as benchmarks for domestic approaches, such as ISO 27000 information security standards. Rules-based free trade was crucial in helping the global economy recover from the ravages of World War 2. We now face the worst global recession since then. It is time to haul our multilateral trade rules into the 21st century and stem the tide of digital protectionism so that data flows can be a source of growth and opportunity, not discord. — By Wang Huiyao, (c) 2020 Bloomberg LP The writer is founder and president of the Centre for China and Globalisation in Beijing and vice chairman of the China Association for International Economic Cooperation

urn:contentItem:5WMY-CG41-JBHT-D3KX-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England Raids2018-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England RaidsLanhamFULL TEXT

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FBN: Well, Wall Street retracing losses big time. It was down nearly 800 points, and then down about 80 points, doing a major rethink after the initial freak out, panicked attack over the arrest that U.S. request in Canada of the CFO of Huawei, that's China's top tech giant.

That CFO, the daughter of Huawei's founder, a former Chinese military officer. She's arrested on charges that Huawei broke U.S. sanctions by selling U.S. technology to Iran. We've got details on that.

But Wall Streeters now applauding President Trump's tough line in trade talks with China because China is stealing to make China great again. We've got fresh new details on that. And it has to stop.

What's going on we've got an insider who has a front row seat on how China has hollowed out entire U.S. industries and taken U.S. jobs. And why Trump is right to fix the problem that elected officials for years have done nothing about.

The Dow down 8 percent since its October high. But take a breath for some perspective. Historically it is normal to have these kinds of downturns. We bring you what you need to know.

Plus, tech execs at the White House today on how to beat China and more. But the real firework is a fight in D.C. over G.M. getting not just loathes of federal bailout help but state bailout help and tax breaks too, where it hardly pays any taxes as its closing U.S. factories and laying off thousands of people before Christmastime, sending those factory jobs to Mexico. We've got the back story to FBN's exclusive with CEO Mary Barra.

Also, Democrat in-fighting over border wall funding. Nancy Pelosi now saying she will not even accept a decent DACA deal in exchange for border wall funding. People sick and tired of D.C. politics.

This as we bring you two big border scandals now hurting Americans.

Well, thank you for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics. We got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

OK. Let's get to the China outrage over the arrest of Huawei's CFO. They are now demanding her release accusing the U.S. and Canada of quote, "wrongdoing." This is over violating Iran sanctions. But Wall Street analysts point out other countries are saying Huawei is pretty bad.

Australia, New Zealand, Britain's telecom B.T. all kicked out Huawei over fears that Huawei is stealing and spying giving its ties to China's military. And they say President Trump is right. China for years has been hollowing out U.S. jobs and entire U.S. industries, not funding its own R&D, but instead, stealing our research to make China great again.

Our companies pay for that research. China then sells cheaper copycats, undercutting us. We're talking nuclear power generators, solar cells, computer hardware, software, and more.

Let's get to Edward Lawrence in D.C. with more on that Huawei arrest. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Liz. And don't forget, circuit boards. That was a huge thing that Chinese put out. And right now, the arrest of chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou threatens to destabilize the fragile trade negotiations that have been going on between the U.S. and China.

China calling for Canada to release the Huawei CFO. A spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry says, "The detention of a person without giving a clear reason is of course a violation of the human rights to the person, or of the person."

Now China claims they don't know the reason that she was detained. She is being investigated by the U.S. for possible violations for breaking the sanctions related to Iran. Now, the timing of arrest is interesting. She was being detained in Canada the same day President Donald Trump worked out a path forward on trade talks with China.

The national security advisor John Bolton told NPR that he was made aware of the arrest and that it would happen. The White House, though, telling us that the president did not know about it before he met with President Xi. Regardless, some senators applauding the U.S. for sticking to its morals.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MARK WARNER, (D) VIRGINIA: My fear is when the Trump administration is going to crumble on Huawei the same way they crumbled on ZTE. And as we think about particularly we move to the next generation of wireless 5G and that transformation is as big as anything that we've seen in the wireless industry. And my fear is that China could be successful at setting the standards and dominating that market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And national security advisor John Bolton also told NPR that this is a Justice Department matter and they don't always tell the president what they are doing. Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Edward. Thank you so much.

Again, behind closed doors. The transcript will be made public within 24 hours of that sessions. Joe Concha is a media reporter for The Hill. He joins us now. So how are they going to report on it? What do you think, Joe?

JOE CONCHA, MEDIA REPORTER, THE HILL: Well, if it's going to be made public in 24 hours, then I would imagine something because nothing gets slip (ph) in Washington. Everything gets slip (ph) in Washington. Within an hour, somebody is going to have to use the bathroom, there will be a call from some reporter and then you're going to hear about it. But at least everything is going to be out in 24 hours, sometimes that doesn't happen.

I think they got the wrong guy here, Liz. I want to know why Rod Rosenstein isn't being called before Congress. He is the guy just nine weeks ago who said, yeah, you know, I think I'll wear a wire and try to trap the president, try to get him on tape to compel his cabinet to invoke the 25th Amendment. I would have had him on there instead.

But, OK, we have Comey. Here's the thing about Comey. He's an open book. Literally he's an open book. He wrote a book in April. He did a thousand interviews after that. I might be exaggerating. Most probably dozens and dozens. So everything seems to be out there already, Liz.

MACDONALD: I hear what you're saying because -- let's be clear. This is about Trump-hating, pro-Hillary FBI director and there are talks about stopping Trump, impeaching Trump. Really the issue is that FISA warrant to basically surveil Trump campaign aides because it looks like they really did break the regulations in getting that FISA warrant, right?

CONCHA: It appears that way. Absolutely. So, but I wonder, Comey who is a very good public speaker, we could agree on that, when he's done his testimonies, it has been the type of thing where he seems to be pretty measured in his responses. He is ready for whatever question --

MACDONALD: He has got to answer. Did you tell the FISA court that it was funded by the Democrats, partly, you even said it was unverified on salacious. Did you know at the time that it was unverified? Did you tell the court that, right?

CONCHA: Right.

MACDONALD: You got to get that out of him.

CONCHA: And if so, why? Was it because --

MACDONALD: Why you --

CONCHA: -- the president.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

CONCHA: Right, exactly. Why didn't you pursue going down this particular route? I also want to know why he leaked a private conversation or conversations that he had with the president over dinner at the White House, then leaked everything he talked about to a friend at Columbia University, who then gave it too The New York Times, and he admits for the sole purpose of compelling a special counsel to be appointed, and it happened. How is that not illegal?

MACDONALD: OK. We want -- can we have you back on to talk about it?

CONCHA: Absotively (ph).

MACDONALD: Absotively (ph). Joe Concha. That's great. Good to see you, sir. Coming up, we are going to get to that ICE arrest. More than 50 illegals including three wanted for murder in sanctuary city friendly New England. We're going to have Tammy Bruce back on that. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. ICE arresting more than 50 illegal immigrants over the past two days. It happened across Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, and Connecticut. Among those arrested, three immigrants, illegals from Brazil, wanted there for murder.

The ICE raids taking place the very same week that the Massachusetts Republican governor said, you know what, a state judge must temporarily step down after that judge let an undocumented immigrant here basically sneak out a backdoor to avoid ICE agents waiting to take him into custody.

Tammy Bruce is back with us. First on that story, Tammy, great to have you back.

BRUCE: Thank you.

MACDONALD: That illegal that sneaked out (ph) the backdoor had been deported multiple times for multiple drug arrests. And now the judge let him go at the backdoor.

BRUCE: Yeah. It is interesting. During the court proceedings, the judge called them up to the bench, and the judge asked for the recording to stop. And that is when suddenly when that went back on and they resumed, there was suddenly some machinations there to have the charges dropped.

And then somehow, the defense attorney was able to walk the defendant out through a side door back through which would not have been allowed without it being facilitated and being able to avoid as there was also (ph) ICE agents.

Some judges and immigration advocates of course don't want ICE agents to be able to go into courthouses. They have argued that they have to stay outside and that seems to be changing a little bit. There is argument about that. This is one of the reasons why they want that to be able to be in the courthouses to deal with this kind of stuff.

MACDONALD: What a story. And we have seen another courts.

BRUCE: Yes, this judge, understandably, they think the judge should not be hearing any federal cases because if you are really obstructing law enforcement, why should you be on the bench? I mean, as a judge, you are supposed to be implementing the laws.

MACDONALD: Right.

BRUCE: And adjudicating them as opposed to helping a defendant sneak out to get away from federal law enforcement. That's crazy.

MACDONALD: She hears criminal cases. Are you going to let other criminals go?

BRUCE: Right. No matter -- look, they are human beings. We all have opinions on the issues. But if you're willing to skirt the law and allow someone else to do so, what else are you doing that is not fair?

MACDONALD: Let's get to the swifts (ph) in New England. The 50 arrested illegal immigrants selling opioids. You have been talking about that.

BRUCE: Oh, yeah. This is our prior discussion. This is the big deal. Trafficking in heroin. Trafficking in fentanyl. These are not drug users, these are traffickers. And so this is where -- it is also a reminder to people what ICE does. This is inside the country. It's the internal framework.

They do not handle the border. They deal with criminals, the gangs, the drug traffickers, sex traffickers, kidnappers, murderers, getting these three Brazilians who are wanted for murder in that country, that's what ICE does.

This is the organization that many Democrats want to abolish. That would be a mistake because the people that are targeted and affected first and victimized first are the communities of immigrants.

MACDONALD: Right, that's a point.

BRUCE: This is who we are trying to protect here.

MACDONALD: Right. But, you know, here is the other point about the story. Several towns in Massachusetts here, they're sanctuary cities. It's Boston, Cambridge, Lawrence and Newton. These are the cities where these individuals have been detained.

BRUCE: That's right. So the people that were scooped up had been in custody. And then were released. Again, you think, well, was this somebody who was driving under the influence or somebody who made a mistake? No, these are drug traffickers. These are very serious individuals.

MACDONALD: But the victims of the crimes are treated like rounding errors in D.C. There is not a human being behind it that is treated --

BRUCE: Big government, whether it is about health care or even law enforcement. When people become the budget and you become a chit on a piece of paper, you stop being a human being. This is why local law enforcement matters. You know, judges matter.

They are supposed to see the individuals and yet they claim it is because they are sensitive to immigrants, but this kind of action re-victimizes immigrants. Legal immigrants who are playing by the rules and even undocumented people who are also playing by the rules. Those are the people that are protected by ICE.

MACDONALD: Great stuff again from Tammy Bruce. You're going to come back soon.

BRUCE: Thank you.

MACDONALD: I'll look forward to it. Thank you so much for having us in your homes and thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

urn:contentItem:5TXB-5PC1-DY0W-44P3-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England Raids2018-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England RaidsLanhamFULL TEXT

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FBN: Well, Wall Street retracing losses big time. It was down nearly 800 points, and then down about 80 points, doing a major rethink after the initial freak out, panicked attack over the arrest that U.S. request in Canada of the CFO of Huawei, that's China's top tech giant.

That CFO, the daughter of Huawei's founder, a former Chinese military officer. She's arrested on charges that Huawei broke U.S. sanctions by selling U.S. technology to Iran. We've got details on that.

But Wall Streeters now applauding President Trump's tough line in trade talks with China because China is stealing to make China great again. We've got fresh new details on that. And it has to stop.

What's going on we've got an insider who has a front row seat on how China has hollowed out entire U.S. industries and taken U.S. jobs. And why Trump is right to fix the problem that elected officials for years have done nothing about.

The Dow down 8 percent since its October high. But take a breath for some perspective. Historically it is normal to have these kinds of downturns. We bring you what you need to know.

Plus, tech execs at the White House today on how to beat China and more. But the real firework is a fight in D.C. over G.M. getting not just loathes of federal bailout help but state bailout help and tax breaks too, where it hardly pays any taxes as its closing U.S. factories and laying off thousands of people before Christmastime, sending those factory jobs to Mexico. We've got the back story to FBN's exclusive with CEO Mary Barra.

Also, Democrat in-fighting over border wall funding. Nancy Pelosi now saying she will not even accept a decent DACA deal in exchange for border wall funding. People sick and tired of D.C. politics.

This as we bring you two big border scandals now hurting Americans.

Well, thank you for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics. We got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

OK. Let's get to the China outrage over the arrest of Huawei's CFO. They are now demanding her release accusing the U.S. and Canada of quote, "wrongdoing." This is over violating Iran sanctions. But Wall Street analysts point out other countries are saying Huawei is pretty bad.

Australia, New Zealand, Britain's telecom B.T. all kicked out Huawei over fears that Huawei is stealing and spying giving its ties to China's military. And they say President Trump is right. China for years has been hollowing out U.S. jobs and entire U.S. industries, not funding its own R&D, but instead, stealing our research to make China great again.

Our companies pay for that research. China then sells cheaper copycats, undercutting us. We're talking nuclear power generators, solar cells, computer hardware, software, and more.

Let's get to Edward Lawrence in D.C. with more on that Huawei arrest. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Liz. And don't forget, circuit boards. That was a huge thing that Chinese put out. And right now, the arrest of chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou threatens to destabilize the fragile trade negotiations that have been going on between the U.S. and China.

China calling for Canada to release the Huawei CFO. A spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry says, "The detention of a person without giving a clear reason is of course a violation of the human rights to the person, or of the person."

Now China claims they don't know the reason that she was detained. She is being investigated by the U.S. for possible violations for breaking the sanctions related to Iran. Now, the timing of arrest is interesting. She was being detained in Canada the same day President Donald Trump worked out a path forward on trade talks with China.

The national security advisor John Bolton told NPR that he was made aware of the arrest and that it would happen. The White House, though, telling us that the president did not know about it before he met with President Xi. Regardless, some senators applauding the U.S. for sticking to its morals.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MARK WARNER, (D) VIRGINIA: My fear is when the Trump administration is going to crumble on Huawei the same way they crumbled on ZTE. And as we think about particularly we move to the next generation of wireless 5G and that transformation is as big as anything that we've seen in the wireless industry. And my fear is that China could be successful at setting the standards and dominating that market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And national security advisor John Bolton also told NPR that this is a Justice Department matter and they don't always tell the president what they are doing. Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Edward. Thank you so much.

Joining me now is Zach Mottl, he is a top executive at Atlas Tool Works. This is a company that has had a front row seat for years watching China's high-tech theft. We welcome you to the show, sir. Thank you so much.

ZACH MOTTL, CHIEF ALIGNMENT OFFICER, ATLAS TOOL WORKS: Great to be here, Elizabeth.

MACDONALD: OK. Your company makes precision parts for the internet, radar systems, medical devices. What do you guys seeing, is President Trump right about China stealing to make China great again.

MOTTL: He's absolutely right. You know, Huawei has built a $90 billion global enterprise based on commercial espionage, theft of western technology. You know, my customers are offered -- my business has been around for 100 years, and for 90 out of the 100 years we were a vendor in the telecom industry. That was a really important sector for myself and many other manufacturers like me.

And we watched as Chinese manufacturers Huawei ZTE came online, and in 20 years they wiped out every single western competitor. Lucent Technologies, Tellabs, Nortel Networks in Canada. Every one of these companies could not compete against commercial espionage and state subsidized technology.

MACDONALD: Because they're undercutting us taking our jobs, our R&D that we pay for and then making cheaper copycats. Sir, isn't this a big wake-up call to Congress to say, you know a what, knock it off about the media grandstanding before, you know, the D.C. cameras and get on the stick. Because China has a built-in road project that made in China 2025 project.

I mean, Obama, President Obama did try to stop China, but it's really up to Congress to get our trade laws updated to knock it, to get it to knock it off, right?

MOTTL: That's right. This telecom industry was the crown jewel of America and it portray laws and lack of oversight by Congress has allow the Chinese to steal this. Let's not lose one more high-tech industry. And quite frankly, let's bring the telephone manufacturing industry back here.

We're about to have 5G, and you know, we can worry about the security or we can simply make it here and know that it's good. Because what we've learned with this Huawei case and so many other cases, is that we just can't trust the Chinese. They say one thing, but they do something completely different. So, I'm hoping Congress will step up to the plate here.

MACDONALD: We hope so too, because this is got to stop, sir. I mean, this should be hair on fire and break the glass time right now in D.C.

MOTTL: That's right.

MACDONALD: Because to your point, we just cited these other countries worried about Huawei. Also, you mentioned 5G. China is embedding itself and the fears it's going to go into that new 5G rollout worldwide. That's the internet of things. That's wearable fitness trackers. It's robots, taxis and the like.

I mean, if China gets to jump on that and starts embedding itself in 5G, wow, game over.

MOTTL: That's right. And they're counting on, you know, they're taking advantage of the free market. They are going to undercut price and they are going to subsidize it to try to buy the market. We cannot let that happen. We need to put laws in place and we need our other country partners to work with us to shut them out of the market. Because again, we just cannot trust them. And when they say they are not spying I certainly think they are.

MACDONALD: All this breathtakingly tedious grandstanding in D.C. over it, and they are setting aside what really matters and that's what you're talking about. Because, sir, look what happened to U.S. Steel. U.S. Steel spent tons of money to pioneer a new lighter, higher grade steel product for cars and planes, but then China hacked it and hacked its computers, stole the blueprints and started selling copycats steel at way cheaper prices, right?

MOTTL: When profit doesn't matter to these companies and they have a government behind them helping them cheat and steal, how can we compete? We need to do it smarter. And what it comes down to is jobs. It's not just about high-tech and innovation. It's about jobs. It's about national security.

And the employees like mine, you know, when I lost my telecom customers in the early 2000, we have to lay people off. We reinvented ourselves, but a lot of other companies couldn't. Telecom and so many other sectors are really important. We're talking about good jobs for Americans versus growth and good jobs for people in China. I want to see it made here and I want to see it secure and safe so we can trust what's going through our network.

MACDONALD: And now, we got indications that China made in behind that massive Marriott hack affecting half a billion people potentially. Wow.

MOTTL: It's pervasive. It is pervasive and everything that they do they just simply play by a different set of rules, so they can tell us one thing but we know they are going to do something else. We can't trust them.

So, I'm pleased to see President Trump, you know, holding firm. I trust his judgment here and I hope that Congress is going to come along and finally join the wise party because they are really missing the boat by not protecting America and our information.

MACDONALD: Well, you know what, you know, if Congress doesn't it, the voter could and probably will. Zach Mottl of Atlas Tool Works, thanks for coming in. We'd like you to come on again soon, sir.

MOTTL: We'll see you soon, Elizabeth. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Good to see you. Let's get Ned Ryun's reaction. Ned Ryun is one of the top analysts out there, he's been watching D.C. Ned, I want your reaction to the conversation we just had.

NED RYUN, FOUNDER & CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: Well, I got to tell you, I mean, initially, when you have a clip of Senator Warren saying -- Warner saying about the fifth-generation 5G networks and Huawei, I mean, that's one of things.

I wrote about this for Fox News during the week of Thanksgiving, Liz, in which I said we have to be very careful because there is a proxy battle being fought right now between United States and China between QUALCOMM and Huawei over who's going to control that 5G network, and you are right.

The implications for the internet of things, right now there is about eight billion internet of things devices. That number is probably going to triple in the next three years. And who's going to control the networks and the data is going to be massive as we move forward into the future.

And on the other front, you're right. I mean, they have been robbing us blind. We have helped build the largest authoritarian police state in China with really bad trade deals, and now we have looked the other way as they literally over the last probably 10 years, Liz, I've seen estimates about three trillion are in technology theft and between theft and force technology transfers that we basically incentivize and given them the means to compete with us on the technology front, but also on the economic front and they're not shy about it.

They are gunning for us. They want to replace us as the center of the economic world. And right now, for in the past, we've been lightening them get away with it.

MACDONALD: You know what, there's that and there's also this other geopolitical risk that the White House is trying to address as well, Ned. Look at this. New satellite images reveal activity and an unidentified North Korean missile base.

So that's also a neck of the woods. What's you take on that?

RYUN: Well, my take on this, is again, this has been the failure of the three previous administrations kicking the can down the road of refusing to actually deal with the North Korean threat. And now Trump has been confronted with it. He realizes we cannot have this existential threat with North Korea having nuclear armaments and being able to literally at some point in the not-too-distant future have the ability to drop warheads on American cities.

The key to this, though, Liz, and it's all, again, like you said, it's all interconnected. We actually need China to play ball with us on North Korea to deal with this threat. And so, this whole trade dispute taking place with China, all of this stuff is interconnected. We have to figure out how to see China accommodate our interest in real life. They've got to prioritize our interest.

And so, this whole trade deal is not only tied to bad trade deals and intellectual theft. It's also tied to how we deal with North Korea as well.

MACDONALD: Yes. And to your point, China's military has been boosting the number of warplane intrusions into South Korea airspace, nearly doubling the number of times in recent years. Your take on that.

RYUN: Well, I mean, China, the amazing part to me is how brash China is and we're acting, we are letting them get away with this. They have been waging this economic war. They've been threatening us. They've been doing building these islands in the South China Seas and we've just been sitting there as though, we, you know, we don't know what they're up to. We know exactly what they are up to. And I think it's time.

Obviously, if we can really deal this economic trade and put them on notice I think we can start to deal with some of these military threats as well.

Trump is right to do this and I know that some people are worried about this tariff fight. I will say this, Liz. If we do not confront China now in the next few years, I'm convinced we will regret it for the next hundred years. Because China does not want trade partners. China wants tributary nations. And if we are not careful, if we deal with this trade threat and these bad trade deals and this theft of our intellectual property we're not going to like where we're at in 10 or 15 years.

MACDONALD: You know, you make a great point there. Let's move over to what's going on in Russia, Ned. I'd like your reaction to Russia doing some saber rattling, showing off new laser weapons after the U.S. is threatening to pull out of missile, that missile treaty dating back to the 80s because of Russia cheating. What's your take on that?

RYUN: I go back to, you know, despite all the left screaming buddy murderer about Trump being too cozy with Putin, he is actually been pretty aggressive with him, especially on the energy front. Over 50 percent of Russia's, the Russian governments income comes from oil and gas exports. And Trump knows what he's doing on this front.

Obviously, he confronted Merkel on Nord Stream II and Russia importing even more natural gas to Germany, and Trump said you can't do that. He's also gone in and address a lot of the middle and eastern and European countries and the three C's initiative in which he is trying to get them off of Russian energy.

Because he realizes, Trump realizes if you can cut off Russian exports in these energy areas of gas and oil, he's going to undermine all this other stuff that's taking place. So, he's focused on the right things. He has to cut off the Europeans from getting or being wholly dependent or significantly dependent on Russian energy. And if he can do that, I think he's going to really be able to put Putin in his place.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Ned Ryun. Great to see you. Come back soon.

RYUN: Thanks, Liz. We'll do.

MACDONALD: Next case, this morning 1000 friends and family attended the funeral service at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston to say a final farewell to President George H.W. Bush.

In attendance, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Chuck Norris, baseball legends Nolan Ryan, and Tommy Lasorda. And also, country singers Crystal Gayle and Larry Gatlin. The funeral train carry the casket of our 41st president a short time ago to the presidential library at Texas A&M University.
