Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WMY-CG41-JBHT-D3KW-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England Raids2018-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Deal and Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou Arrest; President George H.W. Bush Has Now Finally Laid To Rest; G.M. CEO Mary Barra Met With Lawmakers On The Hill Today; Search And Rescue Efforts Are Still Underway After Two U.S. Military Planes Collided Off The Coast Of Japan; Tris Pharma Now Recalling Some Of Its Children's Ibuprofen; Congress Passes Temporary Spending Bill; CDC: American Life Expectancy Down From Higher Overdose Deaths And Suicide; Comey To Testify Tomorrow; Transcript Will Be Made Public Within 24 Hours Of That Session; ICE Arrests More Than 50 Illegal Immigrants In New England RaidsLanhamFULL TEXT

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FBN: Well, Wall Street retracing losses big time. It was down nearly 800 points, and then down about 80 points, doing a major rethink after the initial freak out, panicked attack over the arrest that U.S. request in Canada of the CFO of Huawei, that's China's top tech giant.

That CFO, the daughter of Huawei's founder, a former Chinese military officer. She's arrested on charges that Huawei broke U.S. sanctions by selling U.S. technology to Iran. We've got details on that.

But Wall Streeters now applauding President Trump's tough line in trade talks with China because China is stealing to make China great again. We've got fresh new details on that. And it has to stop.

What's going on we've got an insider who has a front row seat on how China has hollowed out entire U.S. industries and taken U.S. jobs. And why Trump is right to fix the problem that elected officials for years have done nothing about.

The Dow down 8 percent since its October high. But take a breath for some perspective. Historically it is normal to have these kinds of downturns. We bring you what you need to know.

Plus, tech execs at the White House today on how to beat China and more. But the real firework is a fight in D.C. over G.M. getting not just loathes of federal bailout help but state bailout help and tax breaks too, where it hardly pays any taxes as its closing U.S. factories and laying off thousands of people before Christmastime, sending those factory jobs to Mexico. We've got the back story to FBN's exclusive with CEO Mary Barra.

Also, Democrat in-fighting over border wall funding. Nancy Pelosi now saying she will not even accept a decent DACA deal in exchange for border wall funding. People sick and tired of D.C. politics.

This as we bring you two big border scandals now hurting Americans.

Well, thank you for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics. We got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

OK. Let's get to the China outrage over the arrest of Huawei's CFO. They are now demanding her release accusing the U.S. and Canada of quote, "wrongdoing." This is over violating Iran sanctions. But Wall Street analysts point out other countries are saying Huawei is pretty bad.

Australia, New Zealand, Britain's telecom B.T. all kicked out Huawei over fears that Huawei is stealing and spying giving its ties to China's military. And they say President Trump is right. China for years has been hollowing out U.S. jobs and entire U.S. industries, not funding its own R&D, but instead, stealing our research to make China great again.

Our companies pay for that research. China then sells cheaper copycats, undercutting us. We're talking nuclear power generators, solar cells, computer hardware, software, and more.

Let's get to Edward Lawrence in D.C. with more on that Huawei arrest. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Liz. And don't forget, circuit boards. That was a huge thing that Chinese put out. And right now, the arrest of chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou threatens to destabilize the fragile trade negotiations that have been going on between the U.S. and China.

China calling for Canada to release the Huawei CFO. A spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry says, "The detention of a person without giving a clear reason is of course a violation of the human rights to the person, or of the person."

Now China claims they don't know the reason that she was detained. She is being investigated by the U.S. for possible violations for breaking the sanctions related to Iran. Now, the timing of arrest is interesting. She was being detained in Canada the same day President Donald Trump worked out a path forward on trade talks with China.

The national security advisor John Bolton told NPR that he was made aware of the arrest and that it would happen. The White House, though, telling us that the president did not know about it before he met with President Xi. Regardless, some senators applauding the U.S. for sticking to its morals.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MARK WARNER, (D) VIRGINIA: My fear is when the Trump administration is going to crumble on Huawei the same way they crumbled on ZTE. And as we think about particularly we move to the next generation of wireless 5G and that transformation is as big as anything that we've seen in the wireless industry. And my fear is that China could be successful at setting the standards and dominating that market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And national security advisor John Bolton also told NPR that this is a Justice Department matter and they don't always tell the president what they are doing. Liz?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Edward. Thank you so much.

Joining me now is Zach Mottl, he is a top executive at Atlas Tool Works. This is a company that has had a front row seat for years watching China's high-tech theft. We welcome you to the show, sir. Thank you so much.

ZACH MOTTL, CHIEF ALIGNMENT OFFICER, ATLAS TOOL WORKS: Great to be here, Elizabeth.

MACDONALD: OK. Your company makes precision parts for the internet, radar systems, medical devices. What do you guys seeing, is President Trump right about China stealing to make China great again.

MOTTL: He's absolutely right. You know, Huawei has built a $90 billion global enterprise based on commercial espionage, theft of western technology. You know, my customers are offered -- my business has been around for 100 years, and for 90 out of the 100 years we were a vendor in the telecom industry. That was a really important sector for myself and many other manufacturers like me.

And we watched as Chinese manufacturers Huawei ZTE came online, and in 20 years they wiped out every single western competitor. Lucent Technologies, Tellabs, Nortel Networks in Canada. Every one of these companies could not compete against commercial espionage and state subsidized technology.

MACDONALD: Because they're undercutting us taking our jobs, our R&D that we pay for and then making cheaper copycats. Sir, isn't this a big wake-up call to Congress to say, you know a what, knock it off about the media grandstanding before, you know, the D.C. cameras and get on the stick. Because China has a built-in road project that made in China 2025 project.

I mean, Obama, President Obama did try to stop China, but it's really up to Congress to get our trade laws updated to knock it, to get it to knock it off, right?

MOTTL: That's right. This telecom industry was the crown jewel of America and it portray laws and lack of oversight by Congress has allow the Chinese to steal this. Let's not lose one more high-tech industry. And quite frankly, let's bring the telephone manufacturing industry back here.

We're about to have 5G, and you know, we can worry about the security or we can simply make it here and know that it's good. Because what we've learned with this Huawei case and so many other cases, is that we just can't trust the Chinese. They say one thing, but they do something completely different. So, I'm hoping Congress will step up to the plate here.

MACDONALD: We hope so too, because this is got to stop, sir. I mean, this should be hair on fire and break the glass time right now in D.C.

MOTTL: That's right.

MACDONALD: Because to your point, we just cited these other countries worried about Huawei. Also, you mentioned 5G. China is embedding itself and the fears it's going to go into that new 5G rollout worldwide. That's the internet of things. That's wearable fitness trackers. It's robots, taxis and the like.

I mean, if China gets to jump on that and starts embedding itself in 5G, wow, game over.

MOTTL: That's right. And they're counting on, you know, they're taking advantage of the free market. They are going to undercut price and they are going to subsidize it to try to buy the market. We cannot let that happen. We need to put laws in place and we need our other country partners to work with us to shut them out of the market. Because again, we just cannot trust them. And when they say they are not spying I certainly think they are.

MACDONALD: All this breathtakingly tedious grandstanding in D.C. over it, and they are setting aside what really matters and that's what you're talking about. Because, sir, look what happened to U.S. Steel. U.S. Steel spent tons of money to pioneer a new lighter, higher grade steel product for cars and planes, but then China hacked it and hacked its computers, stole the blueprints and started selling copycats steel at way cheaper prices, right?

MOTTL: When profit doesn't matter to these companies and they have a government behind them helping them cheat and steal, how can we compete? We need to do it smarter. And what it comes down to is jobs. It's not just about high-tech and innovation. It's about jobs. It's about national security.

And the employees like mine, you know, when I lost my telecom customers in the early 2000, we have to lay people off. We reinvented ourselves, but a lot of other companies couldn't. Telecom and so many other sectors are really important. We're talking about good jobs for Americans versus growth and good jobs for people in China. I want to see it made here and I want to see it secure and safe so we can trust what's going through our network.

MACDONALD: And now, we got indications that China made in behind that massive Marriott hack affecting half a billion people potentially. Wow.

MOTTL: It's pervasive. It is pervasive and everything that they do they just simply play by a different set of rules, so they can tell us one thing but we know they are going to do something else. We can't trust them.

So, I'm pleased to see President Trump, you know, holding firm. I trust his judgment here and I hope that Congress is going to come along and finally join the wise party because they are really missing the boat by not protecting America and our information.

MACDONALD: Well, you know what, you know, if Congress doesn't it, the voter could and probably will. Zach Mottl of Atlas Tool Works, thanks for coming in. We'd like you to come on again soon, sir.

MOTTL: We'll see you soon, Elizabeth. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Good to see you. Let's get Ned Ryun's reaction. Ned Ryun is one of the top analysts out there, he's been watching D.C. Ned, I want your reaction to the conversation we just had.

NED RYUN, FOUNDER & CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: Well, I got to tell you, I mean, initially, when you have a clip of Senator Warren saying -- Warner saying about the fifth-generation 5G networks and Huawei, I mean, that's one of things.

I wrote about this for Fox News during the week of Thanksgiving, Liz, in which I said we have to be very careful because there is a proxy battle being fought right now between United States and China between QUALCOMM and Huawei over who's going to control that 5G network, and you are right.

The implications for the internet of things, right now there is about eight billion internet of things devices. That number is probably going to triple in the next three years. And who's going to control the networks and the data is going to be massive as we move forward into the future.

And on the other front, you're right. I mean, they have been robbing us blind. We have helped build the largest authoritarian police state in China with really bad trade deals, and now we have looked the other way as they literally over the last probably 10 years, Liz, I've seen estimates about three trillion are in technology theft and between theft and force technology transfers that we basically incentivize and given them the means to compete with us on the technology front, but also on the economic front and they're not shy about it.

They are gunning for us. They want to replace us as the center of the economic world. And right now, for in the past, we've been lightening them get away with it.

MACDONALD: You know what, there's that and there's also this other geopolitical risk that the White House is trying to address as well, Ned. Look at this. New satellite images reveal activity and an unidentified North Korean missile base.

So that's also a neck of the woods. What's you take on that?

RYUN: Well, my take on this, is again, this has been the failure of the three previous administrations kicking the can down the road of refusing to actually deal with the North Korean threat. And now Trump has been confronted with it. He realizes we cannot have this existential threat with North Korea having nuclear armaments and being able to literally at some point in the not-too-distant future have the ability to drop warheads on American cities.

The key to this, though, Liz, and it's all, again, like you said, it's all interconnected. We actually need China to play ball with us on North Korea to deal with this threat. And so, this whole trade dispute taking place with China, all of this stuff is interconnected. We have to figure out how to see China accommodate our interest in real life. They've got to prioritize our interest.

And so, this whole trade deal is not only tied to bad trade deals and intellectual theft. It's also tied to how we deal with North Korea as well.

MACDONALD: Yes. And to your point, China's military has been boosting the number of warplane intrusions into South Korea airspace, nearly doubling the number of times in recent years. Your take on that.

RYUN: Well, I mean, China, the amazing part to me is how brash China is and we're acting, we are letting them get away with this. They have been waging this economic war. They've been threatening us. They've been doing building these islands in the South China Seas and we've just been sitting there as though, we, you know, we don't know what they're up to. We know exactly what they are up to. And I think it's time.

Obviously, if we can really deal this economic trade and put them on notice I think we can start to deal with some of these military threats as well.

Trump is right to do this and I know that some people are worried about this tariff fight. I will say this, Liz. If we do not confront China now in the next few years, I'm convinced we will regret it for the next hundred years. Because China does not want trade partners. China wants tributary nations. And if we are not careful, if we deal with this trade threat and these bad trade deals and this theft of our intellectual property we're not going to like where we're at in 10 or 15 years.

MACDONALD: You know, you make a great point there. Let's move over to what's going on in Russia, Ned. I'd like your reaction to Russia doing some saber rattling, showing off new laser weapons after the U.S. is threatening to pull out of missile, that missile treaty dating back to the 80s because of Russia cheating. What's your take on that?

RYUN: I go back to, you know, despite all the left screaming buddy murderer about Trump being too cozy with Putin, he is actually been pretty aggressive with him, especially on the energy front. Over 50 percent of Russia's, the Russian governments income comes from oil and gas exports. And Trump knows what he's doing on this front.

Obviously, he confronted Merkel on Nord Stream II and Russia importing even more natural gas to Germany, and Trump said you can't do that. He's also gone in and address a lot of the middle and eastern and European countries and the three C's initiative in which he is trying to get them off of Russian energy.

Because he realizes, Trump realizes if you can cut off Russian exports in these energy areas of gas and oil, he's going to undermine all this other stuff that's taking place. So, he's focused on the right things. He has to cut off the Europeans from getting or being wholly dependent or significantly dependent on Russian energy. And if he can do that, I think he's going to really be able to put Putin in his place.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Ned Ryun. Great to see you. Come back soon.

RYUN: Thanks, Liz. We'll do.

MACDONALD: Next case, this morning 1000 friends and family attended the funeral service at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston to say a final farewell to President George H.W. Bush.

In attendance, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Chuck Norris, baseball legends Nolan Ryan, and Tommy Lasorda. And also, country singers Crystal Gayle and Larry Gatlin. The funeral train carry the casket of our 41st president a short time ago to the presidential library at Texas A&M University.

The president was laid to rest alongside his wife Barbara.

We're going to be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. tech execs from Google, Microsoft, and Oracle met today at the White House with Ivanka Trump, Jared Kushner, Larry Kudlow and others to talk about securing U.S. manufacturing dominance, and artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and more. Facebook executives not attending.

But to the real fireworks. The fight in D.C. with G.M. G.M. CEO Mary Barra met again today with lawmakers. They are pretty upset over G.M.'s big tax breaks in the face of G.M. plants -- plans to shut factories and lay off 14,000 workers.

Look at this. FiatChrysler, though, plans to open a new factory in Detroit.

Let's bring in Republican Ohio Congressman Warren Davidson. Good to see you, sir.

REP. WARREN DAVIDSON, (R) OHIO: Good to talk with you, Liz.

MACDONALD: You know, people are upset that G.M. keeps coming all the time with tin cap in hand getting a lot of federal bailout help, and wait for it, a lot of state tax breaks and bailout help too. And you know, Ohio gave G.M. a ton of tax breaks, but now that factories are closing. What's your take on this?

DAVIDSON: You know, it's truly disappointing. And I've been in Congress now for about two and half years, but prior to that, for the previous 15 years I was in manufacturing. So, when you talk the intersection of big tech and automotive, they're really more interconnected than you would imagine.

So, when Mary Barra came and talked with the Ohio delegation, she really led with the transformation that the auto industry is confronting. And you know, one of the points that I wanted to make is, you know, the good news is, is unlike in '08, '09 when this was happening, Ohio strong and growing. G.M. is anomaly our states hiring.

I offered to drive our economic development folks up to do a job fair at the plant. So, G.M. is offering those folks jobs I'm sure the eighth district would be happy to have them.

MACDONALD: OK. But here's the thing. We've been watching and I've been watching G.M. for years. I've been doing business journalism for three decades. I was at the Wall Street Journal. I was an editor at Forbes. I've been writing about G.M. for a long time, sir.

Here's the problem. Here's one of the issues. Ohio in 2008 gave state income tax breaks to G.M., saying you don't have to pay 75 percent of your income taxes to the state of Ohio over the next 15 years.

So, here's the thing. Should elected officials say once and for all, OK, we'll give you, Mr. car company or Mr. G.M., a tax break, with the caveat that you have to show us how you will build factories that you can retool to make -- to make either smaller or bigger vehicles when gas prices go up or down. Other car companies do that, why can't G.M.?

DAVIDSON: Well, the good news is Honda's been doing that. They reinvested, the Honda Accord wasn't selling as well as they thought. The CRV is selling way better, I think two-thirds of the cars on the road that are in demand right now our crossovers, SUVs or trucks. And Honda who is a huge anchor for Ohio has been very adaptive.

G.M. not quite as flexible. There's a lot of history behind that. And you know, frankly, some of the things were the government has been involved that shows frankly, the government should be not try to run these companies. We don't need more central planning.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Got that. Check that. Understood. I hear totally what you're saying. I don't mean to interrupt. But that is agreed upon. We don't want that. We don't want the government in there. But G.M. does really rapidly come with a tin cap getting our tax help.

I mean, it's striking, sir, that we're -- that, you know, that FiatChrysler is now opening a factory in Detroit.

DAVIDSON: Yes. I mean, that's great. And you know, we'll see where that goes for G.M. You know, I think they've been outperformed by a number of companies that's why they have to come hot in hand and begging for help.

MACDONALD: Well, that's been going on for decades.

DAVIDSON: Yes.

MACDONALD: I'm telling you that's been going on for decades.

DAVIDSON: Absolutely. Not to mention the subsidies that are going on to try to steer consumers to buy this car or that car.

MACDONALD: Right.

DAVIDSON: And the areas (Ph) of government shouldn't be trying to steer that. And the good news for G.M. is maybe they finally got the message as, you are not going to get any more bailouts. The American people don't want to bail you out nor anyone else, and so you are going to have to take care of your balance sheet and do the right things.

So, I was impressed that Mary Barra came and was proactively speaking to us on the hill. But yes, very sad news about the investment in Lordstown, Ohio, in particular.

MACDONALD: But you know what, but what about putting the feet to the fire. I understand. I watch Mary Barra. We have a lot of respect for her. She is a great CEO. But listen closely to what she says, OK. A lot of that is a lot of P.R. talk.

DAVIDSON: Yes.

MACDONALD: You got to get to the nuts and bolts. Is she going to move jobs to other factories in the U.S.? And you know, is she going to stop outsourcing to Mexico? We understand the economics of it, but we also understand the economics of giving out tax breaks when you're not, you know, building factories that are flexible, right? Final word.

DAVIDSON: Absolutely. And when you look at where the intellectual property and the tech is, the good news is a lot of that happened in the U.S. and when you tie that to what you're talking about earlier is the tech folks coming to the White House.

The Foreign Investment Risk Reduction Modernization Act, that was one of the biggest piece of registration that the House financial services committee move this past year. It was an honor to work on it. Really our country is going to be more secure, our country is going to be stronger.

And frankly, if we can complement that with a good reform to privacy so that we can make sure that whether it's on the internet or in your car or in app that you download on the phone it's always your data as a consumer. And I was impressed that was one of the questions I put to Mary is that it is an opt in practice for G.M. in the car.

MACDONALD: OK.

DAVIDSON: And so, I hope we can do that more and I hope that they'll see that the competitive advantage in the United States means they should continue to invest including in Ohio. We have a tremendous supply chain and folks are happy to supply them.

MACDONALD: There's great people in Ohio. Great people in Michigan, great people in the heartland. Congressman Warren Davidson, thank you so much. We really appreciate it.

DAVIDSON: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Let's get to other headline news. Search and rescue efforts still underway after two U.S. military planes collided in midair and crash off the coast of Japan overnight. It happened during a refueling exercise. One marine killed, another in fair condition.

However, five marines still missing. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families there.

A Southwest Airlines flight get it off the runway upon landing in heavy rain at Burbank Airport in California. There were no reported injuries. Among the 117 passengers, they were evacuated using emergency slides. That's pretty scary stuff.

And drug company, it's called Tris Pharma, now recalling some of its children's Ibuprofen after it was notified about overly high concentrations of that drug that can affect a child's kidneys. This brand was sold under private label brands at CVS, Wal-Mart and Family Dollar. Check those labels there.

Now to the border wall. Brand new analysis on how it saves thousands of lives. We've got one of the best columnists and thinkers out there. Tammy Bruce is coming up.

We have this moment in time after the George H.W. Bush funeral, that there seems to be some kind of unity. Get it done.

BRUCE: This is at the border. Eighty percent of the fentanyl in this country comes in through the southern border, and also China is involved in that facilitation as well.

MACDONALD: It's just two milligrams. We just show that stat, 78 million. That's based on the amount of fentanyl seized at the border last year and the first quarter of this year. Life expectancy has been dragged down by what is going on.

BRUCE: That is correct, because you got middle aged individuals, right? You got -- those are the individuals who are dying too early because of the drug addiction and because of suicide. We've dealt with now -- thank goodness in the economic recovery, but the last 10 years, people losing their homes, losing their savings, losing their jobs. That combined with drug addiction. So it is -- that in it of itself, because of the core of the people affected is dragging down the U.S. life expectancy.

MACDONALD: Astonishing, that finding. You know, President Trump is saying China will try to stop the importation of fentanyl into our country. That's part of the trade deal. BRUCE: Yeah. You know, he is -- what they have done is, because of the caravan, we've obviously boosted up the numbers, and the cartels which have relied on kind of a lax framework are furious because it is affecting their ability to move the drugs in.

This is why when we talk about the wall, it is not just about we need an orderly framework that happens at the border, but we must take seriously what's going on and how these drugs are moving into the country, when 80 percent of fentanyl is coming in through the southern border.

And by the way, the majority of heroin as well is not coming from Afghanistan, it's grown in Mexico. It's cultivated there and moved in through Mexico. So the wall is something that not only are we dealing with keeping bad guys out and killers and all of that and human trafficking, but to stop this.

When you got three wars of the deaths combined including Vietnam in one year, how is this not a war? All the American people deserve to be taken seriously and to have --

MACDONALD: Is it Trump's White House capitalizing on this, what you're talking about?

BRUCE: Look, they have got to talk more about the other issues that are involving the wall and why this matters. People know the opioid crisis and the prescription drugs, right, OxyContin. When you think of heroin, when you think of a poppy fields in Afghanistan --

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BRUCE: They got to talk more about this. This transcends political parties, economic status, all of those things. And I wish the president would speak more about it.

MACDONALD: Tammy Bruce, you're going to be with us later in the show. Great information there. Wow! We had a jam-packed hour. Coming up, a major arrest of illegals in Massachusetts. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XHD-WRW1-JB20-G0YK-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Optimism; Warren's War on Billionaires; Google under Pressure; China Trade Tensions; American Prosperity; Setting New Records; Impeachment Inquiry; New Technology at the Border2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTVeronica Dagher, Kevin Kelly, Danielle Hughes, Jonathan D.T. Ward, Jack McIntyre, Kevin GramerNEWSFinancial111501cb.231U.S.-China Trade Optimism; Warren's War on Billionaires; Google under Pressure; China Trade Tensions; American Prosperity; Setting New Records; Impeachment Inquiry; New Technology at the BorderMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Griff Jenkins

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: The council director Larry Kudlow said is on the brink of completion, but President Trump is not ready to sign off on it yet. We will tell you why.

Stocks climbing on the news this morning. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 56 points. As you can see, a quarter of a percent higher. The S&P is up six and the Nasdaq higher by 24. It comes after the S&P closed at another record high yesterday.

Retail rebound. Walmart's strong earnings report, a positive sign ahead of the holiday shopping season. Today we get another check on the state of the consumer when we get October retail sales out. It is out in about two and a half hours, 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We'll have the number and the analysis as soon as that number hits the tape.

Senator Elizabeth Warren capitalizing on her fight with billionaires. The 2020 hopeful now selling "Billionaire Tears" mugs on her campaign website. It is her latest strike in her war on wealth.

And a bench-clearing brawl. One player from the Cleveland Browns ripping off his opponent's helmet, using it to smack him in the head. It all went down with just eight seconds left in last night's game. How the NFL is responding this morning.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

All right, we've got a big show this morning on this Friday morning. Joining the conversation, Divine Asset Management CEO and founder Danielle Hughes is here. Benchmark managing partner Kevin Kelly is here. And "The Wall Street Journal's" wealth management reporter, the host of the "Secret of Wealthy Women" podcast, Veronica Dagher.

Great to see everybody this morning.

VERONICA DAGHER, WEALTH MANAGEMENT REPORTER, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Great to be here.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Great to be here.

I've got -- we've got the update too. Mark Cuban's, you know, Mavericks lost to the Knicks last night. So --

BARTIROMO: I know that. I know that.

KELLY: I was laughing and he's like, I'm coming back. We're getting the revenge game.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: And, yes, he didn't do it. So.

BARTIROMO: It was close, though.

KELLY: It was at half.

BARTIROMO: I looked at the score in the middle of the night just to check it, and it was like just a point between them and then it went.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The Knicks won. Mavericks down. So I'm sure Mark Cuban has a lot to say about it this morning.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, that was tough.

BARTIROMO: We've got a lot to talk about this morning.

Our top story this morning is the China trade story. Optimism this morning driving markets this morning. Take a look. S&P and the Dow Industrials up on this news that perhaps a deal is, in fact, close. A phase one deal. But there's a lot of debate about that, I just want to say, because, you know, the Chinese yesterday were baulking at buying agriculture and, of course, the U.S. side does not want to take away any tariff increases that are planned in December. Having said that, Larry Kudlow said that they are close. The president is looking at it.

The S&P, yesterday, hit record territory. White House Economic Adviser Larry Kudlow says the phase one trade talks are in the final stages, but that President Trump is not quite ready to sign it yet.

One reason is because the Chinese do not want to agree to a mechanism that actually has consequences if they steel intellectual property.

Markets are awaiting key economic data this morning. We've got October retail sales coming out in about two and a half hours.

Danielle, you think we will see a China deal getting done?

DANIELLE HUGHES, CEO, DIVINE ASSET MANAGEMENT: I think that the market loves being on the edge of its seat about the China deal every single day. I do think that we should get phase one done. I don't know when that's going to happen . I think that, you know, there is a chance that the market sells off on that news. Almost like the rumor -- you know, buy the rumor, sell the news. But I do think that it would be good specifically the manufacturing segment of America, which has really been hurt by the tariffs.

BARTIROMO: You know, the Chinese are not making this easy, Kevin. I mean yesterday I was talking to somebody who knows about this deal and he was saying to me that, look, they keep pushing back on so much. They don't want to have a mechanism that is an enforcement mechanism should they steel intellectual property. They're balling an the forced transfer of technology.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, they don't want any tariffs in place, and the president is not going to do that. The president has these tariffs in place. He's expecting to raise tariffs on December 15th. And yet maybe we are close, as Larry Kudlow says, but they have to agree to the things that are important to the U.S. side.

KELLY: You know what's frustrating is that this is the same exact script.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

KELLY: Last December Larry Kudlow specifically said, hey, we're going to get a trade deal done. We're 95 percent of the way there.

BARTIROMO: And Mnuchin said that as well.

KELLY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: Last December. It is the same exact script. The market goes up and then nothing comes away. And I think the most telling points is that the Chinese actually did not buy the soybeans they said they were going to buy.

BARTIROMO: I agree.

KELLY: Why? Because they want to hit the president hard in the states that he needs to win for the election. The Chinese aren't going to get a deal done, especially when you talk about the enforcement, because they'll sign any deal, but as long as they -- as we can't enforce it, you know, that they -- they won't care. But the problem is, is that they're not going to give up their 2025 plan, their 2035 plan, their 2049 plan and the 2049 plan is we're -- they're the number one military in the world and they can win. So, you know what, for them, they're just trying to wait out this president.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you, I don't disagree with a lot of what you just said because it just feels like, if they wanted to do a deal, they would have made -- they would have agreed to all of these things. And it does not feel like they want to agree to these things. And now they're baulking about the amount of agriculture they buy? I don't know.

DAGHER: Right, they won't put a number in writing. So, like, we're going to buy more agriculture, but when you actually put it in a deal, no, we don't want to commit to a specific dollar amount because we want to have flexibility later. Well, that doesn't help our farmers.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DAGHER: We need an idea of what's in store.

BARTIROMO: Or the whole strategy here is to baulk now and not do it now and then later say, oh, OK, we'll do it, and then come across as if we just got something. Meanwhile, it's the same deal that we've been talking about buying agriculture.

KELLY: And this goes back -- and this goes back to Iran too because, think about it, they can agree to terms and then complexly enrich as much uranium as they want, right? So the whole idea here is that, you know, we need to enforcement mechanism, and that's the most important part, and they're never going to concede to it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see. We'll see about that.

I want to talk about capitalism versus socialism with you guys.

2020 newcomer Deval Patrick already having an answer -- to an questions about his time at private equity firm Bain Capital. The company coming under fire, you might remember, in the 2012 election because then Republican candidate Mitt Romney founded Bain Capital.

Here's what Patrick said when he was asked about the state of the Democratic Party. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEVAL PATRICK (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I love that the party has moved to the left. I love that we are the party of the woke. I believe that we also have to be the party of the still waking.

There is a place for private equity in the private economy. There's a place for business in our lives. But there is -- it is also true that capitalism generally has a lot to answer for. That is so (ph). And we need to be able to confront that. And that's exactly the work I've been doing at Bain Capital. But I've done that same work in other business settings before.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Capitalism has a lot to answer to.

On this program yesterday, I spoke with Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban about the debate capitalism versus socialism. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK CUBAN, OWNER, DALLAS MAVERICKS: Capitalism's going to win. There's no question about that.

But, look, I'm never against open discourse. That's what makes this country great, you know, people being able to convey their opinions. Now, I'm not going to agree with all of them. Socialism just doesn't work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And then there's this. Elizabeth Warren, 2020 candidate Senator Elizabeth Warren's capitalizing on her stance against wealth with a new coffee mug and it has a slogan on it, "Billionaire Tears."

Kevin, this is just rich. She's against capitalism.

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: She says, so, OK, I am a capitalist, but she -- she knocks it down at every turn. And then she capitalizes on it.

KELLY: Yes, exactly. It's the definition of what a cleptocrat (ph) does and that's what she's trying to become. And if we look at the biggest issue that's facing this country is its crony capitalism and it's the government that enables that because they are -- they impose regulations. They also impose taxes. They keep people out of the free market. And that's exactly the problem that we have right now is that the tax code is complex and convoluted and it prohibits businesses from actually operating in the free market.

So the problem isn't capitalism, it's crony capitalism and it's big government Democrats that want to impose that. And so that's why people are actually talking about socialism today.

HUGHES: Demonizing billionaires goes exactly against everything that this country, I think, has to offer. It's the American dream. It's the thing that people really want to achieve. And I -- I think that it sells eyeballs though. Everybody wants to look at what you're saying and be all, you know, shocked and afraid and get that mug. But she is absolutely taking advantage of the opportunity that she has.

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes.

DAGHER: I hope the money is going to charity. I wonder if it is, right?

BARTIROMO: Well, no, it's going to her campaign.

DAGHER: It's going to her campaign. Of course it is, yes, for sure.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Right. Yes.

DAGHER: Right, that's why it's so funny. Yes, you know, since when did wealth become a bad word? That's the point. You know, so many people, they may knock it, but, secretly, they want to --

KELLY: Well, here's the problem we have. We have a society where it's victimhood. Everyone's a victim. The billionaires didn't earn that. You know, they're -- they're -- that quote/unquote say they're woke.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: But the problem is, is that they're the party of NB (ph). If you risked and took chances, you deserve the rewarded and it's not up to the government to determine how much reward you get if you took that risk.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly.

KELLY: And that's the problem we have.

BARTIROMO: I want to ask you about the anti-trust investigations into big tech this morning. The Google probe reportedly expanding to include the company's search and android business.

Veronica, this company is in the crosshairs of the government for a number of reasons, not to mention anti-trust, 90 percent market share, also the censoring of conservative conversation.

Your reaction?

DAGHER: Not going away any time soon. This company and -- and big tech in general is really a target right now. And I think that's going to stay that way until well into 2020. I think consumers want to see some reform. I'm not sure what kind of regulation they will get. But I think investors are expecting more regulations on these companies because of some of these issues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think you're right.

All right, a quick break. We are just getting started this morning.

Also on deck this morning, we've got the Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross here on the U.S.-China trade deal. We will find out exactly where we are.

The chief security officer of Huawei is here, Andy Purdy, on Huawei's FCC national security vote.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Jay Clayton is here on the state of the IPO market and why so many fewer companies are public today than just five or 10 years ago.

And the president of the Dallas Federal Reserve, Robert Kaplan, on the Fed's outlook on manufacturing and the state of the economic today. Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big three hours coming up.

We'll slip in a break and then we're looking at the big tech battle. Amazon ready to fight back after the Pentagon awards a huge cloud contract to Microsoft. Details after this.

And then the fight on the field. Three players ejected after a brutal brawl at last night's Steelers-Browns games. More on the video when we come back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

A devastated community gathers for a vigil hours after a deadly high school shooting.

Cheryl Casone with headlines this morning.

Chery.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: A frightening day yesterday, Maria. A teenager is accused of killing two people and injuring three more on his birth. The shooting took place at Saugus High School in Santa Clarita, California. The 16-year-old suspect shot himself in the head. He is now hospitalized, in critical condition. So far there is no known motive to this shooting in California.

All right, let's switch gear and talks a little Amazon. They've announced that they're going to challenge a $10 billion Pentagon contract awarded to Microsoft. Amazon Web Services has issued this statement. Numerous aspects of the JEDI evaluation process contained clear deficiencies, errors, and unmistakable bias, and it's important that these matters be examined and rectified.

Well, President Trump, a vocal critic of Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos, has publicly criticized Amazon's fit for the government's business. He actually asked for an investigation of it back in July of this year.

Well, if you missed it, let's watch it all again, an explosive end to Thursday night football. The Browns-Steelers game erupted into a sidelines clearing brawl.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Beyond words, Joe (ph).

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, gosh, that's one of the worst things I've ever seen on a professional sports field.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Unbelievable. Browns defensive lineman Miles Garrett ripped off the helmet of Steelers quarterback, Mason Rudolph, hitting him on the head with it, as you just saw. Garrett almost certainly is facing suspension, along with Pittsburgh center Mike Pouncy, who retaliated, kicking Garrett in the head. The Browns, I'm not even sure it matters, won the game 21-7, Maria.

I have not seen something this brutal on the football field -- I'm not even sure ever. This was unbelievable last night.

BARTIROMO: Terrible.

CASONE: Yes, it really is. And, yes, suspensions are coming. I can tell you that right now.

KELLY: Yes, but thank goodness he actually didn't hit him with the crown of the helmet.

CASONE: Right.

KELLY: And the way that -- the part -- portion of the helmet he hit him, otherwise, I mean, it could have been unbelievably damaging to him.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Definitely.

DAGHER: Terrible. Nasty.

KELLY: I mean he should be suspended for the rest of this season irregardless (ph). That's just --

DAGHER: Yes, that was --

BARTIROMO: So unprofessional.

DAGHER: Completely.

BARTIROMO: And just terrible.

DAGHER: Really.

BARTIROMO: He could have really -- seriously hurt him.

How is he, by the way, do we know?

CASONE: Yes. So -- looks OK.

BARTIROMO: Is he seriously hurt?

CASONE: Looks OK. But just, you know, unreal. This is why people get mad at the NFL for things like this.

BARTIROMO: It's true.

DAGHER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It is.

Thanks, Cheryl.

A quick break, and then, closer to a deal. The U.S. and China made considerable progress apparently on inking a trade agreement. Why the president is not ready to sign off on it yet.

Then, day two of the impeachment hearings this morning. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is now accusing the president of bribery.

Stay with us. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

U.S.-China trade optimism this morning moving markets. National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow saying last night that President Trump, quote, likes what he sees but is not ready to sign off on a deal just yet. This after reports that proceedings had hit a snag over farm purchases, that the Chinese were pushing back, they did not want to buy all the agricultural products that the president has said the Chinese would buy.

Joining us right now is the founder of the Atlas Organization and he is author of the new book "China's Vision of Victory," Jonathan Ward.

And, Jonathan, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining me.

JONATHAN D.T. WARD, FOUNDER, ATLAS ORGANIZATION: Good morning, Maria. It's good to be here.

BARTIROMO: So first let's talk about a U.S. and China potential partnership. You've written a lot about China. Do you think the U.S. and China will be able to have a partnership together which is equal?

WARD: No, I think -- I think -- I think that's not going to happen. I mean this is a country the communist party, this regime seeks to replace us as the dominate super power in the world. They've been absolutely clear about that in all kinds of strategic documents. They see themselves as essentially dominating the 21st century. Engagement with the United States for them is a way to get there. I mean taking our technology, having access essentially to the markets of, you know, the whole world that the United States built after the Cold War, they seek to essentially take that over and run it, ultimately.

BARTIROMO: So you -- you wrote this op-ed about this on foxbusiness.com about how America can stay on top amid the trade impasse. You write this, quote, U.S.-China competition is likely to be the highest geopolitical contest in generations. But it is a contest that the United States can win if we focus on the right objectives.

Tell us more about that, Jonathan.

WARD: Absolutely. I mean what we need to do is get through the next decade, the 2020s, working on our own productivity, investing in the United States, investing in the industries of the future, in additive manufacturing, in robotics, in all the key technology that are going to come out and make sure that we're building this at home. I mean we can stay ahead of China if we just get our productivity increases to about 2.5 percent per year each year. We can build the next 10 trillion in U.S. GDP, in annual GDP. That's what we should be focused on. And the more that we're distracted by the China market and the sort of integration with China, the less that we're doing at home and also with our allies. I mean the U.S. sort of allied world and democratic world is two-thirds of the global economy. That's where we should be building and investing, not in an adversary that seeks to replace us.

BARTIROMO: So when you hear Larry Kudlow and Steven Mnuchin say, oh we're close and this is really great that the Chinese are going to open up its market so that financial services companies can get a bigger footprint in China so that they can sell to 1.4 billion people, what do you think is -- this is all about? Because I think for far too long CEOs were more interested in getting their products in front of 1.5 billion people than actually protecting their products. You know, a lot of these people who were working on this deal, they want U.S. companies to have the access to sell to the Chinese people. They're not thinking at other things like national security the way you are.

WARD: Well, they're not thinking long term either. I mean the whole cost of going into the China market is that you're going to lose essentially intellectual property. I mean this is also a country that's actively cyber hacking and, you know, into every American company. We just saw this in the National Association of Manufacturers. You know, they're going into trade industries and into anything they can to get any kind of advantage, whether that's industrial or informational. So going over there, I mean if CEO's are thinking too short term, I mean they really need to be looking out about a decade and asking where their company is going to be, because you're also -- I mean the communist party is producing what they call national champions to essentially go out around the world with stolen American and multinational intellectual property.

A great example is Micron and (INAUDIBLE). I mean there's, you know, just massive theft of deep R&D and such. So, you know, there are many examples of this. And that's what the China market really is, you're over there, they're taking from you and they're sending it back into global markets, becoming your competitors with the backing of the Chinese state, fulfilling this broader communist party grand strategy of replacing the United States. And it's very dangerous for U.S. companies.

KELLY: Yes, and, Jonathan, I think you're hitting a very good point here and how are we going to address the state-owned enterprises that are actually even going out and dumping into those other markets.

I'll give you a great example. We're going to have Andy Purdy on here later in the show from Huawei. And what does Huawei do, they undercut their rivals by 60 percent. And then the Chinese state-owned banks actually give low financing and cheap financing, where carriers can't resist buying their equipment and then also competitors can't compete.

WARD: Right. And Huawei is a perfect example of China's sort of national security play. I mean their attempt to sort of dominate undersea cables, 5G, next generation infrastructure, it's going around to geographical areas where the communist party sees its sort of global strategy being built in, you know, the belt and road, the entire sort of Eurasian super continent. They'd like to get Huawei into as much of Europe as possible, if they can't get it to the United States. And, ultimately, they'll have access to everybody's networks. I mean every single --

KELLY: And how do we prevent that? How do we stop that?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly.

KELLY: That's the question. It's like how do American companies compete? How do western democracies compete against that? What -- how do we prevent that?

WARD: Yes, you're going to need free world 5G. I mean we should -- if you can't fund our own, then deal with Nokia and Erickson. I mean we've got to have democratic alternatives. I mean you really need to get the United States, Europe and Japan together thinking about essentially these are the OECD (ph) nations.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WARD: Add India to that. India just walked out of a China-led trade deal for the region, ACEP (ph). India is sitting there right now wanting a trade deal with somebody. I mean that's a big one that we should be working with.

Do bilaterals if you can't do multilaterals for now. I mean India, Japan, get into, you know, Brexit, as that's happening. I mean give something to the British and start rebuilding the actual free and democratic world that we led China into thinking that China was going to become a responsible stakeholder. That is panned out as completely false. It's never going to happen. So we're going to have to build --

BARTIROMO: Yes, you have to export --

WARD: Yes, you want a foundation now. So whatever's going on in the negotiations, I mean it may make sense to have this partial or sort of intermediary truce type thing.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WARD: I mean the fact that the Chinese want the tariffs off as some kind of precondition, I mean this is a country -- I mean they're going to lie, they're going to cheat, they're going to steal. I mean they've broken every international agreement they've ever signed up to. That's what Hong Kong's all about. They've broken that.

BARTIROMO: And -- and -- and what do you think about -- what do you think about what's going on? This is -- this is six months now in Hong Kong and now Hong Kong officially falling into recession for the first time in a decade.

WARD: Right.

BARTIROMO: And the economy shrank by 3.2 percent last quarter, Jonathan. Violent anti-government protests and the U.S.-China trade path (ph) certainly has to have some pressure here on the Chinese, but they're still unwilling to keep the promises that they made in that initial trade deal back in May, which included, you know, having it against the law to steal intellectual property, and -- and -- and other things like forced transfer of technology. They -- I mean, I don't know if they're going to renege on this, but there are -- there are no indications that they're agreeing to -- to any, you know, mechanism to keep them at the table in terms of an enforcement.

WARD: Yes, they're not going to do that. That's their model. Their model is to steal from us. So that's what you're dealing with and it's why you need leverage. I mean the tariffs are essentially the leverage now. You can get more leverage, I think, by putting in other trading agreements with other partners and start building on towards the future with less dependency on China, but we have to get past this ugly dependency on a communist, you know, totalitarian dictatorship that's committing -- committing, you know, human rights atrocities and Shinjang (ph), you know, challenging the U.S. and all their allies. I mean they're building up a military that's designed to -- to -- for conflict with us. You have to build a foundation now that's about staying ahead of them and making sure they never catch up, because if they do catch up, economically or technologically, all of the big non- negotiable problems in U.S.-China relations only get worse.

You know, they talk about this now, Maria. It's something called the community of common destiny for mankind.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WARD: They're basically putting out this idea of what world order looks like with China at the center. I mean if China regains, as they see it, this sort of central position in the world that, you know, they're not putting the concepts together for what the 21st century looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WARD: Which is why they're not negotiating the way we'd like them to.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you --

WARD: They're very confident that this picture belongs to them.

BARTIROMO: You have to ask yourself -- and the Europeans, you know, they should be asking themselves as well as they hold on to their Huawei equipment, who do we want running the world? Do we the -- do we want a free democracy as the largest super power in the world or do we want communists as the largest super power in the world?

WARD: Right.

BARTIROMO: It's an important question and we should be -- because that is where they're going.

Jonathan, it's good to have you this morning.

And we will check out your op-ed on foxbusiness.com.

Great to see you this morning, Jonathan.

WARD: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan Ward joining us, Atlas Organization.

Stay with us, I'll be speaking with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross about all of this and the chief security officer of Huawei Technologies, Andy Purdy is here in the 7:00 a.m. hour. We will talk more about this.

First, though, day two of the public impeachment hearings. The ex- ambassador to Ukraine facing a grilling later this morning. What you need to know coming up.

And then security at the border. We'll introduce you to one company using thermal technology for screenings. Wait till you see this.

Back in a minute.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. TGIF. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, November 15th. Your top stories right now at 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

The final stages of phase one, National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow says the agreement with China is on the brink of completion, but President Trump is not ready to ink the deal just yet. We are taking a look at exactly where we are here.

Stocks are climbing on the news. Take a look. Dow futures are up 60 points right now. S&P futures up six and the Nasdaq up 23.

Yesterday we had another record high for the S&P 500. Take a look. The S&P announced (ph) an all-time high of 3,096, with a gain of just two points. The other major indices were flat. The Dow and the Nasdaq down fractionally.

European indices this morning are mixed. Take a look. The FT 100 down 43, but the CAC quarante in Paris is up eight and the DAX index in Germany is lower by about a point.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly higher. As you'll see here, the best performer was Korea. The Kospi index up better than 1 percent.

Cracking down on immigration. The Homeland Security Department deploying new body heat technology to stop trespassers at the southern border. We've got the cameras right here on set. Wait till you see this.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning, but, first, our top story this half an hour.

China trade optimism pushing markets higher this morning. As you can see, the Dow Industrials are up 64 points, the S&P 500 adding on to another record high close yesterday. The Dow and the Nasdaq were down fractionally. But as you can see, we've got some -- a firmer tone this morning.

White House Economic Adviser Larry Kudlow signaled progress on phase one of the China trade deal, saying that it is in the final stages, but President Trump is not ready to sign off on it.

Joining us right now is Brandywine Global fixed income portfolio manager Jack McIntyre.

And, Jack, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks for being here.

JACK MCINTYRE, FIXED INCOME PORTFOLIO MANAGER, BRANDYWINE GLOBAL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: How important is a China deal from your standpoint?

MCINTYRE: So it's important. It's probably more important from a marketing sentiment standpoint. I'm not in the camp that, hey, we get a deal and all of a sudden there's going to be a flood of CapEx, I mean because this -- phase one is the low-hanging fruit. And if we're struggling to get phase one, what does that mean for phase two and phase three. So I really worry about euphoria going into phase one and then reality kind of kicks in.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Yes, I think one of the biggest things that's impacting the market right now is what's happening in yields. We saw the market sell off all the defensive named, the bond proxies, right? We even had, you know, the fixed income ETF sold off 10 percent. We saw utilities were down 5 percent. Real estate was down 5 percent.

Where do you think yields are going to go here and are we going to still see this volatility in the rates market because it's happening really episodically?

MCINTYRE: So, yes, I actually agree, I think we probably will get a little bit more volatility in the context of a range. So I don't see inflation really moving higher. I'm on the same camp with Powell. I think, you know, low inflation means we're going to get a sustainable recovery or expansion. And without inflation, inflation expectations aren't going to be high, so I don't think yields have to be (INAUDIBLE) higher.

KELLY: Which we saw core inflation yesterday, it came under expectations.

MCINTYRE: Right. Having said that, though, I don't think it -- I don't think yields are going to go significantly lower without seeing deterioration in the U.S. labor market. So I -- the mindset I have is, you're probably going to earn your coupon from a fixed income standpoint.

DANIELLE HUGHES, CEO, DIVINE ASSET MANAGEMENT: One of the things that Powell said, Jack, in his comments this week is the debt in the U.S. is growing faster than nominal GDP and ultimately, in the long run, it's not sustainable and our grandkids are going to have to use their tax dollars sustaining the debt.

What do you think about that?

MCINTYRE: Yes, I agree, but that's been the story for decades, you know, we've been growing these massive, this debt, running these huge budget deficits. At some point the market are going to send a message, the bond vigilantes are going to say, hey, you guys need to get your act in order. We're not there yet. And I'm not sure what it's going to take. You have to differentiate, you know, where's the debt coming from. It's not in the household sector. So governments, corporations are having a huge amount of debt right now.

HUGHES: The yield frenzy that's really kind of percolating right now.

MCINTYRE: And my take is when we have this much debt, it ultimately deflationary. It means that yields can't go significantly higher --

HUGHES: Right.

MCINTYRE: Because the cost of servicing that debt gets out of control and then we head into a recession.

VERONICA DAGHER, WEALTH MANAGEMENT REPORTER, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Some wealthy investors are expecting a big pullback in 2020. I'm wondering what you think of that. As a result, many of those investors are holding a lot more cash.

So a pullback in sort of risk asset?

DAGHER: In that market. Yes.

MCINTYRE: I'm not there yet because I don't -- I just -- I think we're going to have sort of this OK economic backdrop. And I think it's sort of a goldilocks. We're going to get some growth. It's not going to be real strong growth. I think there's probably going to be better growth away from the U.S. and this is where we're kind of contrarian, but I don't think -- I don't see the need for the U.S. equity markets to go under a significant selloff right now.

DAGHER: Not holding more cash as a result?

MCINTYRE: No, I think, you know, cash -- cash did well last year. That was the best-performing asset. I don't think that's going to be the case -- it wasn't the case this year and it's not going to be the case next year.

BARTIROMO: And the chairman yesterday, Fed Chief Jay Powell, was optimistic during day two of his testimony on Capitol Hill. He said rate cuts this year would help offset lingering headwinds, like trade uncertainty. What do you think about that, the trade uncertainty, the CapEx situation where managers started to sit on cash because they're uncertain about what's happening in trade?

MCINTYRE: Right. So I get my -- a sense that Powell kind of did a little bit of a victory lap. And deservedly so because, hey, the Fed reacted quickly enough, they cut cuts, they -- they're expanding the balance sheet now.

Again, I don't think, even with the U.S.-China trade deal, that this is going to ignite a wave of CapEx spending because there's still a huge amount of uncertainty. I'm in the camp, this is an economic cold war. Hey, we can move the ball forward, but it's the other issues, phase two and three, the national security issue, the U.S. kind of imposing on China sovereignty issues.

KELLY: Well, so was -- is it one of the biggest overhangs for American companies is that the strength of the dollar has actually precluded them from competing in the -- on the global scale because it's so expensive that it, you know, we're losing in emerging markets.

MCINTYRE: So -- and that's a great point and I would advise Powell, yes, things look good, but keep an eye on the dollar because the dollar is the mechanism that lines weak global growth to strong U.S. growth. And if that continues, the dollar is going to appreciate.

KELLY: Yes.

MCINTYRE: And that's a tightening of financial conditions. I don't think that's the case. I don't actually expect the U.S. dollar to weaken as that growth sort of in -- outside the U.S. does better than the U.S.

HUGHES: Right, because the emerging markets have actually -- those central banks have remained and continue to be accommodative. Do you see that -- those markets actually win? They've had a terrible couple of years.

MCINTYRE: And I -- you're absolutely right, and I actually think that is probably one of the key things to focus on is that globally inflation is low, so that means that it allows central banks and EM to cut rates. The Fed having cut rates opened the door. I think we're at sort of 50 plus central banks cutting rates. So I think that actually is going to help growth. There's a lag effect with that, but that should set a better backdrop for growth in 2020 globally.

DAGHER: Looking around the world, where do you see more opportunity for investors right now?

MCINTYRE: So we are skewed more towards the emerging markets. So, from a bond standpoint, those yields are still attractive. Those currencies are very undervalued.

One of the things that we're watching about -- watching very closely is these -- the protests. We've got to -- because that -- that brings sort of risk into idiosyncratic countries specific as opposed to just sort of U.S.- China trade and the Fed. But, despite that, I still think there's good opportunities in the emerging markets.

BARTIROMO: Which ones?

MCINTYRE: So we are still in Mexico, Malaysia. So Latam (ph) has gotten beaten up. I mean you look at Chile, the protests, I think there are opportunities presenting themselves there. We've got to see some type of resolutions on the -- on these protests. But commodity prices have been weak. I expect them to be stable. And I think the commodity producers, which have gotten beaten up significantly, should -- should do OK.

BARTIROMO: Jack, it's great to have you. Thanks so much.

MCINTYRE: It's always my pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Jack McIntyre joining us.

Stay with us, I'll be speaking with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan about the economy in the 8:00 a.m. hour. Don't miss that. He will join us live coming up.

But, first, tech on the southern border. One company using thermal technology for screenings. More on the ground breaking change coming up.

Then, 15 minutes of fame over. All three "Jeopardy" contestants stumped by this answer. Who they missed coming up.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The impeachment inquiry hearings entering their second day. today, in a few hours from right now, former Ukrainian Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch will appear on Capitol Hill.

Fox's Griff Jenkins is live on Capitol Hill this morning with more.

Griff, good morning to you.

GRIFF JENKINS, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria.

Day two. History in the making. Only one witness, Yovanovich. And we expect her to talk about what she said in her closed door hearings, that she felt, quote, threatened by President Trump and that she believes that the president's personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, was waging a smear campaign against her. We find out that she cried. She was very emotional during that closed-door deposition and so perhaps Democrats hope she will be emotional as well today while the whole country is watching. We believe that Republicans are interested in really asking about the timeline because Yovanovitch was recalled in May and yet, of course, we know that famous call between President Trump and President Zelensky wasn't until July 25th.

If you look at sort of how this is going to unfold at 9:00 a.m., they'll gavel in. There will be opening statements swearing in. And then, like we saw on Wednesday, the majority gets 45 minutes of questions, minority gets 45 minutes of questions, and then there's a five-minute round for each member. There's 13 Democrats, 9 Republicans on the committee.

Meanwhile, Speaker Pelosi changing her language towards what she believes President Trump has done, calling it bribery and even comparing it to Watergate.

Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA): To bribe is to grant or withhold military assistance in return for a public statement of a -- of a fake investigation into the elections.

The cover-up makes what Nixon did look almost small.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: And, Maria, there's also one other thing happening here, another closed-door depositions, this of David Holmes, who is a staffer, an aid to Ambassador Bill Taylor, who we learned on Wednesday apparently Holmes overheard the president speaking with Ambassador Sondland and believes that that was a conversation about the president's interest in investigations into Biden. Perhaps we'll find out more.

But we're not done today, Maria. We have eight -- eight more witnesses that will go before the opening hearings next week on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow, what a two weeks, Griff. We will check back. Thanks so much.

Griff Jenkins on Capitol Hill.

Coming up, tech and the border. We've got new, ground breaking technology here on set to show you. It uses thermal vision for security screenings. You don't want to miss it. Wait till we show you what they can find out about you.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New technology transforming border security Thruvision uses body heat cameras to detect concealed items. The technology being deployed all over the world, including at the U.S. southern border.

Joining us right now is Thruvision U.S. operations head, Kevin Gramer.

Kevin, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

KEVIN GRAMER, U.S. OPERATIONS HEAD, THRUVISION: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So we have this technology here on set. First, tell us about the technology and how it works.

GRAMER: Right. Through Vision technology is a passive technology, meaning it does not emit any radiation. And we use thermal contrast recognition, which essentially we're measuring the body heat coming from your body and identifying the items that are blocking that energy.

BARTIROMO: So we're going to look at it right now because we've got the technology on set. And what are we seeing right now? We're seeing items in his pocket.

GRAMER: Yes, you can see Patrick here has some items on him. You see the black areas are the items that are blocking that energy coming from the body. So, Patrick, can you show us say what you have in your midsection there? We have -- the way -- the way the technology works --

BARTIROMO: Ah-hah.

GRAMER: All right, so this is a money belt. We can see powders, plastics, liquids, gels. You know, a metal detector detects metal. We can detect all other items in -- that a metal detector cannot detect.

BARTIROMO: So how does this compare to other screening methods that we all know as we go through the airport, for example?

GRAMER: Yes, good point. Detection at range is new category for security technologies. So we're -- we're screening people from a distance. So usually when you go to the airport or you go through -- you go through a metal detector, you stand in a system and you put your hands up over your head, our system does this from a distance and we do it in a -- basically in a passive way so there's no radiation coming at you. We can see items on the body that are blocking that energy coming from your body. And the officers can make a determination on what to do next.

KELLY: I think one of the best parts is, we now know fanny packs aren't out of style, but I think the good news is, is that this is currently being deployed actually in London right now, right, to -- as a use case to see one of the biggest problems they have, and that's knife attacks.

GRAMER: Yes, we did some knife crime trails with the U.K. government in different locations there and it was a very effective use of our technology.

DAGHER: How far away can you spot something?

GRAMER: So up to -- it depends on the size of the object, but about 10 meters is kind of a sweet spot for us, so a little bit less if you're looking for smaller items, a little bit further away if you're looking at bigger items. Suicide vests are something that we can detect very well from a much further distance, but we can see down to even much smaller items for, say, airport security.

HUGHES: So you can see jewelry, you can see anything that's really foreign that's not emitting some kind of heat. So what's to prevent suicide bomber to, you know, put some kind of heat admitting technology around their bomb?

GRAMER: Yes. Because of the sensitivity of our system and the way it measures that energy coming from there, it would be almost impossible to thermalize something exactly to body temperature.

BARTIROMO: Can this be deployed anywhere, whereas, you know, people could actually be screened and they don't even know it or, I mean, I know your customers are largely governments, right?

GRAMER: Right. It can be screened -- you can deploy it in multiple ways. It's a mall enough item to where you can deploy it, like we have it back here where we just literally set it on top of a box. We have systems where you can actually move it around and do a mobile deployment so you can kind of do random and unpredictable screening. We can hang it from the ceiling. I could be --

BARTIROMO: So people could be screened and they don't even know it at their -- at their own will. I mean --

GRAMER: Yes, that's completely up to the -- whoever's deploying the technology on that, but, yes, it can -- you can do it overtly or covertly.

BARTIROMO: Where is this technology now? How wide scale is it?

GRAMER: So recently we announced a win that we have with the U.S. Customs and Border Protection to deploy on the border. Currently, as you probably know, or may not know, that people crossing the border are not -- there's no technology screening them. So the officers rely on the K9 and their training on there -- we provide them a tool to actually look at the people that are coming across the border. We can --

KELLY: And it -- when people are moving in motion too, right? So they don't have to be standing there and they can actually deploy it on a -- on a wide-scale --

GRAMER: Absolutely.

KELLY: OK.

GRAMER: Yes, if you think of it as a camera, and what we can just see in a different part of the spectrum and the frequency that we see, essentially clothes disappear, but we do not see any anatomical detail on that.

KELLY: Right.

GRAMER: So if somebody's carrying drugs or like say fentanyl or opioids on their body and they're coming across the border, we'll be able to see those.

HUGHES: There was a big trend with 3D guns, ceramic knives, things like that. Is the technology like this, could that pick that up?

GRAMER: Absolutely. Good question. The technology, again, looks for the things that are blocking that energy coming from the body. So a 3D printed gun will likely make it right through a metal detector. Anything that's not metal will make it through a metal detector. We see all of those items because they're blocking that. So 3D guns, 3D printed guns, the ceramic knives, carbon fiber, other -- other items as well, and all non-metallics.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And this is at the southern border already?

GRAMER: We're working with CBP to deploy at the -- at the southern border now. We're also working with TSA and their innovation task force to look at new, faster ways to get people through airports -- the security. So we have airport --

DAGHER: Thank you for that.

GRAMER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUGHES: Yes.

GRAMER: Airport -- air travel is actually increasing at 5 to 8 percent a year. The TSA administrator has said that they're not going to people their way out of the problem, so they have to deploy technology to do that. We're in consideration to do that.

BARTIROMO: We're looking at pictures right now when I took the show to the -- to the El Paso border. And I couldn't believe how easy it was to get from Juarez, Mexico, right across -- it was supposed to be a river but there was no water -- right across right into Mexico -- I'm sorry, from Mexico right into the United States, into El Paso, Texas. It was -- there was -- there was nothing.

GRAMER: Yes. Yes. So we are -- we're deployed at the border. So we used it at the port of entry where people are coming through on there, so the CBP is looking at deploying in a variety of environments.

BARTIROMO: Kevin, it's great to have you. Thanks so much.

GRAMER: Great. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will be following your -- your technology for sure.

Kevin Gramer joining us there.

Still ahead, I'll be speaking with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross next talking phase one of a U.S.-China trade deal.

Plus, 15 minutes of fame over. All three "Jeopardy" contestants stumped by this answer. What they didn't know next hour right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

And it is Friday, November 15th. Your top stories right now just before 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The final stages of phase one. National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow says the agreement with China is on the brink of completion, but President Trump is not ready to ink the deal just yet.

A breakthrough in USMCA apparently. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi signaling progress in talks with the Trump administration. She says she wants it passed by the end of this year. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross will weigh in coming up live, exclusive, straight ahead.

Futures this morning are higher.
