urn:contentItem:5SGG-YNH1-JB20-G4MC-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax Debate2018-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Kevin Kelly, Ermanno Santilli, Bre Payton, Jack McIntyreNEWSFinancial060403cb.231U.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax DebateDagen McDowell, Kat Timpf, Blake Burman, Cheryl Casone, Nicole Petallides, Hillary Vaughn, Stuart Varney, Dani Klupenger, Connell McShane

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 4th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Markets extending gains from Friday a 128-point gain on the Dow futures. Trade worries? Not showing up in the market. Stocks rally on Friday following that much better than expected jobs' report. The unemployment rate falling again at an 18-year low. We have 219-point gain on the blue chips and that green is now showing up in Europe. We have gains across the board to report to start this week in Europe. Same story in Asia overnight, all four major markets there gaining this Monday. Facebook under fire, a new report from The New York Times says the social media giant gave users data to device makers including Apple and Samsung. This raising new privacy concerns surrounding the company and it's weighing on the stock down nearly 1 1/2 percent in premarket trading. This comes as the tech industry is facing scrutiny over censorship not just Facebook, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes had a warning for big tech on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES WITH MARIA" yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIR, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I would hope that they, you know, just don't get involved in politics and don't sensor conservatives and Republicans, but if they continue to do it then we have to move obviously to hearings on this issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We take a closer look straight ahead. MCINTYRE: Right. So, I don't think expansion have to die of old age. And the one characteristic of this expansion, as you pointed out, it's been long. But it's been a pretty slow expansion. So, it's not strong but it is long. But you're right, there's risk from on the trade standpoint. Clearly, if this escalates into a trade war, that's going to bring forward the next recession. But if I'm right about CAPEX, kind of coming to the forefront -- and inflation not getting out of hand, because you know the fed obviously ends up ending a lot of these expansions and if inflation remains tame the fed won't do it this time around. So, it is a possibility. It's you know, 18 months away, but I don't think it has to happen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Jack. Good to see you, Jack McIntyre. The president continues to tweet this morning, writing this: "As has been stated by numerous legal scholars, I have the absolutely right to pardon myself. But why would I do that when I have done nothing wrong? In the meantime, the never-ending witch hunt led by 13 very angry and conflicted Democrats and others, continues into mid-terms." And he tweeted this again. Mr. President, are you watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA? "China already charges a tax of 16 percent on soybeans; Canada has all sorts of trade barriers on our agricultural products. Not acceptable." Because that's exactly what Connell McShane was just talking about with that soybean farmer. So, it could go to 25 percent, at least that's the U.S. threat, but could it go lower than 16 percent? We'll be right back.

DANI KLUPENGER, TENNIS CHANNEL REPORTER: Welcome back to Tennis Channel Court Report a special presentation for Fox Business. I'm Dani Klupenger. It was a great day for the red, white, and blue at Ronald-Garros with two American women reaching the quarter finals for the first time in their careers.

Sloane Stephens' blasted in that (INAUDIBLE) off the court to punch her ticket into the elite eight. The U.S Open champion took the last 11 games of the match to wrap up the impressive win in under an hour.

Earlier, Madison Keys comfortably took care of business against Romania's Mihaela Buzarnescu to set up a quarterfinal meeting with Yulia Putintseva Kuznetsova. Four aces and 17 winners for last year's finals at flushing meadows.

Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova renewed their rivalry, Monday, in Harrisburg Place in the quarter, and you can watch it live on Tennis Channel. Our coverage from Ronald-Garros ticks the air at 5:00 a.m. Eastern. I'm Dani Klupenger.

MCDOWELL: The President still tweeting this morning, "The U.S. has made such bad trade deals over so many years that we can only win!"

Shares of Dell, meantime, up two percent this morning, after beating first- quarter revenue expectations. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with much more. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Monday morning, Dagen. That's right, so we're watching Delta this morning -- Dell to the upside this morning after the revenue really wowed Wall Street. The stock is up about two percent, so they saw the pc shipments on the rise. In fact, products overall, saw an increase of 22 percent. And that's the -- that is the motherload of what they do for revenue, about 78 percent of the revenue comes from products. So, that's where they saw the increase of 22 percent. Service revenue also gained and so with that, you see, it was a winning quarter. The stock over 52 weeks is up about 24 percent.

And then Amazon. When we're watching Amazon, we had some positive comments from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. The analyst there puts a $2000 price target. This is the fourth time this year that he's uped his price target. He actually is liking private label for the company. That would include Amazon's Echo essentials apparel, Elements nutritional supplements, but when will it get to that trillion-dollar market cap. Will it beat out Apple to do so? Well, in fact, if you want to see Amazon in the trillion- dollar market cap, it would have to trade at 2060.89, so not quite here but -- yet, but it's had five record closes in a row, looking at a sixth this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange.

Google in hot water, and now some are calling for a probe of the tech company in the wake of Google listing Nazism as an ideology of the California Republican Part. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Pretty strong stuff I'd say. When you're bandying about labels like Nazis and a South Carolina State Senator -- or North Carolina State Senator was called a bigot. That was stamped across her picture. This is all part of the Google picture at the moment, and I think is one of the reasons, why Google is underperforming the other tech stocks. You may notice, Dagen, that recently, Microsoft passed Google in terms of overall market value. That was a surprise. And there's other things going on as well. I remember the "60 Minutes'" piece one week ago, where -- well, it emerged that Google is watching you, knows everything about you, but who is watching Google?

Well, now, Representative Devin Nunes says, look, you're operating like a monopoly. Keep going like this and we're going to have hearings into you. Well, that's interesting because that's a real threat to Alphabet's business, Google's business going forward. It's profitability going forward, I think they're pressing for the breakup of the company. This is something to watch, because big tech is so powerful, they're just asking the politicians to rein them in.

MCDOWELL: And they've gotten away with a lot in recent years, and we just sat back and did nothing.

VARNEY: That's true.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: You, too.

MCDOWELL: Always, my dear Sir, 9:00 a.m. to noon, Monday through Friday, Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." You can't miss a minute.

Coming up, a fight over California's $0.12 gas tax intensifies. We head live to Orange County, California where a midterm battle to repeal the state's gas tax is brewing.

MCDOWELL: A midterm battle over California's $0.12 gas tax is brewing. Hillary Vaughn is live in Orange County, California with the very latest. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen. Well, National Democrats tell me their pathway to the majority in November runs right here through California. They are targeting 10 seats in the state, four right here in Orange County, but National Republicans says this, $0.12 tax -- gas tax increase at the pumps that state Democrats pushed through is actually going to pump the brakes on their road to victory in November because Republicans say it's energizing their base.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MATT GORMAN, COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, RNC: There's a lot of energy on the Republican side. People want to talk about how Democrats are enthused. Well, I don't see Democrats marching in the streets overpaying upwards of $5.00 a gallon for gasoline. And I think this is going to resonate with voters not just now but as well in the fall.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Voters are so fired up over this gas tax issue that one state senator is facing a recall vote tomorrow to kick him out of office for voting for the tax. But the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is convinced voters aren't going to be worried about rising transportation costs when weighing who to support for Congress and instead are focused on what's happening in D.C.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW GODINICH, SPOKESMAN, DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSIONAL CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE: I think that when voters are going to the polls this week, the issues that they are thinking about when they're voting for Congress are the issues that they're seeing coming out of Washington.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: There is one tax Democrat say voters are worried about the GOP tax plan that they say has hit voters in California the hardest. The California Republican leadership says Democrats in the state are to blame for the high taxes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM BRULTE, CHAIRMAN, CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN PARTY: I think there's a collective Democrat strategy to blame Washington, D.C., and Donald Trump for all of the ills in California. The fact of the matter is the Democrats own California, they've had total control of it for over seven years, and they don't want to take credit for their record here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Dagen, this $52-billion tax plan is meant to push cars off the road, but the GOP hopes it will push Democrats off the ballot in November. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Hillary. Hillary Vaughn for us in Orange County, California. Coming up, final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: A giant fake hug to Kevin Kelly and Lee Carter for being with me this morning. So much to talk about trade, but these markets are loving what's coming out of Washington, at least so far. That does it for MORNINGS WITH MARIA. "VARNEY & COMPANY" is up right now. Stuart, it is all yours, Sir.

VARNEY: All right. We're off and we are running this Monday morning. Looks like kind of a follow on from last week. Good morning, everyone. Our allies are united on this, they don't like the tariffs we're imposing on them.

Kat -- that's Kat Timpf (INAUDIBLE) he lists what he accomplished, massive tax and regulation cuts, military and vet, lower crime, and illegal immigration, stronger boarders, judgeships, best economy and jobs ever, and much more. We had repeal and replace done and the ...

urn:contentItem:5SGW-FG31-JBHT-D54C-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax Debate2018-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax DebateLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 4th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Markets extending gains from Friday a 128-point gain on the Dow futures. Trade worries? Not showing up in the market. Stocks rally on Friday following that much better than expected jobs' report. The unemployment rate falling again at an 18-year low. We have 219-point gain on the blue chips and that green is now showing up in Europe. We have gains across the board to report to start this week in Europe. Same story in Asia overnight, all four major markets there gaining this Monday. Facebook under fire, a new report from The New York Times says the social media giant gave users data to device makers including Apple and Samsung. This raising new privacy concerns surrounding the company and it's weighing on the stock down nearly 1 1/2 percent in premarket trading. This comes as the tech industry is facing scrutiny over censorship not just Facebook, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes had a warning for big tech on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES WITH MARIA" yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIR, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I would hope that they, you know, just don't get involved in politics and don't sensor conservatives and Republicans, but if they continue to do it then we have to move obviously to hearings on this issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We take a closer look straight ahead. Trade turmoil, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross returns from China with no deal, when it comes as our allies ramp up their threats of retaliation over our steel and aluminum tariffs. And breaking news overnight, a shooting on a football field, five people shot including a pregnant woman who had to have an emergency C- section, we have latest from Texas. Plus, scare in the sky, a flight forced to make an emergency landing after the plane's windshield cracked. And a warning from American Airlines, ticket prices could go higher as that airline faces higher fuel costs. And former President Bill Clinton offering his take on the impeachment debate. He says proceedings would be in full swing for impeachment if a Democrat was in office. All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Fox News Contributor, Kat Timpf is here, Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly, and Maslansky + Partners President Lee Carter. Good morning. We got one hour left. I can't wait to get to all of that. President Clinton not helping the Democrats.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: No.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: No.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Of course. Can I just say something about the markets? One of the reasons why we're seeing strong market action this morning and we saw it actually strengthen in Friday session is because the manufacturing numbers exceeded expectations. I mean we're well into expansion numbers. I mean we were supposed to get 57-print on the PMI numbers of manufacturing. We got a 58 number.

MCDOWELL: But except, if you look at the front page of the Journal this morning that global economic growth that the optimism is diming that you have global manufacturing at a nine-month and the Baltic Dry Index that shipping measure peaked last month, copper prices are falling, so there -- there's warning flares --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Yes. There's -- there are some warning flares on the global side especially because that's emanating out of Europe, and so Europe is really weighing down the global economy, and so their strike with political discourse. But the problem that you're having is not here in the U.S. We're 25 percent of the world's GDP. We're still strengthening and so I think that's a good thing.

MCDOWELL: And let's move onto that Facebook privacy story. It's privacy policy is under scrutiny again amid a new report. This is from The New York Times that Facebook gave phone makers, device makers like Apple and Samsung vast access to user data. Blake Burman is on this story in Washington, D.C. with more. Good morning, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hello, Dagen. Good morning to you as well. Yes, we're talking about the biggest names here Apple, Blackberry, Samsung, Microsoft, Amazon, just a handful of the roughly 60 device makers that Facebook shared data with according to a brand-new report our this morning from The New York Times. The partnerships according to the report allowed for the use of like buttons and address books and allowed for Facebook to access the data of users' friends without their explicit consent. In a posting in response to the Times article, Facebook defending itself by saying, "These partners signed agreements that prevented peoples Facebook information for being used for any other purpose than to recreate Facebook like experiences, partners could not integrate the user's Facebook features without their devices or with their devices rather without the user's permission." Now, over the weekend, Congressman Devin Nunes was warning tech companies both of reaching into the political arena and whether or not companies need to be regulated.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: That brings in a whole another set of circumstances. Are these companies Facebook, Twitter, Google, Apple, etcetera, are they monopolies and should they be reined in? I would hope we don't have to go there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now, that opens the door to even more questions about Facebook, Dagen, and user privacy when Mark Zuckerberg was testifying on Capitol Hill just a few weeks ago. This issue was not publicly known then, so it was not raised either, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Blake, thank you for that. Blake Burman in Washington for us. Turning to trade tensions, the Trump administration showing no signs of backing down after imposing sweeping tariffs on aluminum and steel imports from Canada, Mexico, and the European Union late last week despite swift pushback from America's allies.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: The national security issue is not about Canada, or China, or Turkey, or any other country that sends us aluminum or steel. National security issue is a flood of imports from 20 countries that are putting our aluminum and steel businesses out of business. And so the national security issue is basically us looking outward defending ourselves against that flood of imports so that these industries can thrive.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now as President and CEO of MagneGas which is focused on the $5 billion metal cutting market, Ermanno Santilli. Ermanno, some of America's closest allies are calling these tariffs insulting, unacceptable even illegal. They're threatening retaliation lining up tariffs on goods that we export to nations like Canada, Mexico, and Europe, how are these tariffs going to impact your business?

ERMANNO SANTILLI, PRESIDENT AND CEO, MAGNEGAS CORPORATION: Well, MagneGas Corporation is profiling companies that will definitely benefit from these tariffs. (INAUDIBLE) MNGA, we're a small to medium-sized company. We're in the industrial gas sector and we have created industrial gas that is unique, developed here in the United States. It replaces the (INAUDIBLE) and that's used to cut and form metal. So clearly, if this economy in respect to the metal and aluminum starts taking off even more so than it already has I think MagneGas will definitely benefit and we're not alone.

KELLY: Ermanno or Ermanno, I apologized. How do you face shareholders and talk about the growth going forward and the volatility around the sanctions and your cash flows and managing really shareholder expectations because this may be a temporal situation that only happens for a few quarters?

SANTILLI: Well, that's a good question. And at the end of the day, our customers of our product are not going to stop welding. They're not going to stop building. They're not going to stop producing automobiles just because the cost of welding where it goes up by 10 percent. I think it's something that and if you look at the industry as a whole, I mean in -- unemployment is down 18-year low, back orders that are 14-year high, industry really isn't that afraid about these tariffs on the whole in my opinion.

CARTER: Industry is not necessarily concerned but a lot of the individuals out there are because we just heard, and Dagen -- and when Dagen's last interview said there is going to be short-term pain for consumers. So while it might have an impact on jobs, do you think it's going to have an impact on individuals?

SANTILLI: I think it's high -- if you look at a six pack is going to go up by a few pennies and automobile will go up by -- the price will go up by $40. I honestly don't think it's going to have a huge impact on other consumers. Frankly, I think it's all hype.

MCDOWELL: But it's not just -- it's not just a six pack of beer and it's an automobile, Ermanno, it's everything that follows. It's also the retaliatory tariffs from all these other nations. The administration is looking at automobile tariffs, so if you want to buy a Kia, that Kia might go up by several thousand dollars in cost, so when -- the sum total and it's not just -- again, so you're admitting that consumer prices are going to go up. I mean Peter Navarro was on this show when these tariff were first announced before they were ever implemented saying don't you worry your head. The six pack of beer is not going up that much. But again, it affects the entire supplier chain as well and some manufacturers are left wondering how they're going to source their materials.

SANTILLI: Yes. I think that's true. I think that there is a risk for some retaliatory tariffs, but tariff mechanisms are used every day by every country in the world, 50 percent of products imported in the United States are subject to some sort of a tariff. Now, it's not 25 percent. It's usually much lower. I think the average is about 2-1/2 percent. Retaliatory tariffs are a concern but hopefully Trump will be using this as sort of a negotiations tool to avoid that.

MCDOWELL: Do you have any sense? Have you talked to anybody in the administration at all? Do you have a sense of when we might have more certainty on that?

SANTILLI: No, I have not. I know that my customers and our suppliers, they're just kind of rolling with it. Prices are going up for aluminum and steel. But again, in our sector, we're not going to stop building just because something goes up by a few pennies.

MCDOWELL: Ermanno, thank you for being here. Ermanno Santilli, take care.

SANTILLI: My pleasure.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, President Bill Clinton ramping up his rhetoric. The former President arguing that impeachment hearings would have already started if a Democrat was the commander-in-chief. That's ahead. Plus, a crude awaken, American Airlines warning customers might face higher ticket prices if oil prices stay high. We break down the details, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: At least five people including a pregnant woman shot at a football game in Texas last night. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Well, the pregnant woman was shot in the chest and underwent an emergency C-section. The baby reportedly is OK, but the woman herself is in critical condition this morning. Now, this happened after two people opened fire at a football game. It happened in South Dallas. There's injured at least three women and two men. The motive for the shooting still unclear at this point, police are searching for the suspects in this. Well, (INAUDIBLE) this morning, Jordan's Prime Minister Hani Al-Mulki has resigned after several days of protests in that country. "AL JAZEERA" is reporting that Jordan's King Abdullah asked the prime minister to step down. These recent demonstrations over tax increases are the biggest in years in that country and a lot of police fired, and tear gas, and blocked roads is now the result of these protests as it really erupted in Jordan as you can see on your screen.

Well, an American Airlines flight was forced to make an emergency landing after its windshield was shattered by a powerful hailstorm. One passenger able to get this picture shows. You can see here the excessive damage to the nose of the plane. Luckily, the flight was able to lane safely. No injuries were reported. But meanwhile, American Airlines has warning now that a continued rise in oil prices could result in higher ticket prices for the passengers this summer. The spike in prices also resulting in a somber forecast for global airline profits in general. According to the International Air Transport Association, the industry is expected to post a $33.8 billion profit this year, but that's down $0.12 from the previous forecast. This of course due largely to rising fuel costs for the airline, and may oil reached 730 bucks per barrel for the first time in four years. Now, we're at 65.52. But again, these higher prices if they continue to the summer in particular airlines can only hedge so much, Dagen, you know they can maybe hedge 60 percent, 70 percent, but not whole enchilada, so your ticket may get a little pricier this summer.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: Now, all the good news for you this morning.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl Casone. urn:contentItem:5SGW-FG31-JBHT-D551-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax Debate2018-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Talks End in an Impasse; Trudeau Calls Trump's Tariffs 'Insulting' To Long-standing U.S.-Canada Alliance; Impact Of Tariffs On American Farmers; Global Growth Concern; CA Gas Tax DebateLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 4th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Markets extending gains from Friday a 128-point gain on the Dow futures. Trade worries? Not showing up in the market. Stocks rally on Friday following that much better than expected jobs' report. The unemployment rate falling again at an 18-year low. We have 219-point gain on the blue chips and that green is now showing up in Europe. We have gains across the board to report to start this week in Europe. Same story in Asia overnight, all four major markets there gaining this Monday. Facebook under fire, a new report from The New York Times says the social media giant gave users data to device makers including Apple and Samsung. This raising new privacy concerns surrounding the company and it's weighing on the stock down nearly 1 1/2 percent in premarket trading. This comes as the tech industry is facing scrutiny over censorship not just Facebook, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes had a warning for big tech on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES WITH MARIA" yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIR, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I would hope that they, you know, just don't get involved in politics and don't sensor conservatives and Republicans, but if they continue to do it then we have to move obviously to hearings on this issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We take a closer look straight ahead. Trade turmoil, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross returns from China with no deal, when it comes as our allies ramp up their threats of retaliation over our steel and aluminum tariffs. And breaking news overnight, a shooting on a football field, five people shot including a pregnant woman who had to have an emergency C- section, we have latest from Texas. Plus, scare in the sky, a flight forced to make an emergency landing after the plane's windshield cracked. And a warning from American Airlines, ticket prices could go higher as that airline faces higher fuel costs. And former President Bill Clinton offering his take on the impeachment debate. He says proceedings would be in full swing for impeachment if a Democrat was in office. All of that and so much more coming up this morning. Fox News Contributor, Kat Timpf is here, Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly, and Maslansky + Partners President Lee Carter. Good morning. We got one hour left. I can't wait to get to all of that. President Clinton not helping the Democrats.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: No.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: No.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Of course. Can I just say something about the markets? One of the reasons why we're seeing strong market action this morning and we saw it actually strengthen in Friday session is because the manufacturing numbers exceeded expectations. I mean we're well into expansion numbers. I mean we were supposed to get 57-print on the PMI numbers of manufacturing. We got a 58 number.

MCDOWELL: But except, if you look at the front page of the Journal this morning that global economic growth that the optimism is diming that you have global manufacturing at a nine-month and the Baltic Dry Index that shipping measure peaked last month, copper prices are falling, so there -- there's warning flares --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Yes. There's -- there are some warning flares on the global side especially because that's emanating out of Europe, and so Europe is really weighing down the global economy, and so their strike with political discourse. But the problem that you're having is not here in the U.S. We're 25 percent of the world's GDP. We're still strengthening and so I think that's a good thing.

MCDOWELL: And let's move onto that Facebook privacy story. It's privacy policy is under scrutiny again amid a new report. This is from The New York Times that Facebook gave phone makers, device makers like Apple and Samsung vast access to user data. Blake Burman is on this story in Washington, D.C. with more. Good morning, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hello, Dagen. Good morning to you as well. Yes, we're talking about the biggest names here Apple, Blackberry, Samsung, Microsoft, Amazon, just a handful of the roughly 60 device makers that Facebook shared data with according to a brand-new report our this morning from The New York Times. The partnerships according to the report allowed for the use of like buttons and address books and allowed for Facebook to access the data of users' friends without their explicit consent. In a posting in response to the Times article, Facebook defending itself by saying, "These partners signed agreements that prevented peoples Facebook information for being used for any other purpose than to recreate Facebook like experiences, partners could not integrate the user's Facebook features without their devices or with their devices rather without the user's permission." Now, over the weekend, Congressman Devin Nunes was warning tech companies both of reaching into the political arena and whether or not companies need to be regulated.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: That brings in a whole another set of circumstances. Are these companies Facebook, Twitter, Google, Apple, etcetera, are they monopolies and should they be reined in? I would hope we don't have to go there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now, that opens the door to even more questions about Facebook, Dagen, and user privacy when Mark Zuckerberg was testifying on Capitol Hill just a few weeks ago. This issue was not publicly known then, so it was not raised either, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Blake, thank you for that. Blake Burman in Washington for us. Turning to trade tensions, the Trump administration showing no signs of backing down after imposing sweeping tariffs on aluminum and steel imports from Canada, Mexico, and the European Union late last week despite swift pushback from America's allies.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: The national security issue is not about Canada, or China, or Turkey, or any other country that sends us aluminum or steel. National security issue is a flood of imports from 20 countries that are putting our aluminum and steel businesses out of business. And so the national security issue is basically us looking outward defending ourselves against that flood of imports so that these industries can thrive.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now as President and CEO of MagneGas which is focused on the $5 billion metal cutting market, Ermanno Santilli. Ermanno, some of America's closest allies are calling these tariffs insulting, unacceptable even illegal. They're threatening retaliation lining up tariffs on goods that we export to nations like Canada, Mexico, and Europe, how are these tariffs going to impact your business?

ERMANNO SANTILLI, PRESIDENT AND CEO, MAGNEGAS CORPORATION: Well, MagneGas Corporation is profiling companies that will definitely benefit from these tariffs. (INAUDIBLE) MNGA, we're a small to medium-sized company. We're in the industrial gas sector and we have created industrial gas that is unique, developed here in the United States. It replaces the (INAUDIBLE) and that's used to cut and form metal. So clearly, if this economy in respect to the metal and aluminum starts taking off even more so than it already has I think MagneGas will definitely benefit and we're not alone.

KELLY: Ermanno or Ermanno, I apologized. How do you face shareholders and talk about the growth going forward and the volatility around the sanctions and your cash flows and managing really shareholder expectations because this may be a temporal situation that only happens for a few quarters?

SANTILLI: Well, that's a good question. And at the end of the day, our customers of our product are not going to stop welding. They're not going to stop building. They're not going to stop producing automobiles just because the cost of welding where it goes up by 10 percent. I think it's something that and if you look at the industry as a whole, I mean in -- unemployment is down 18-year low, back orders that are 14-year high, industry really isn't that afraid about these tariffs on the whole in my opinion.

CARTER: Industry is not necessarily concerned but a lot of the individuals out there are because we just heard, and Dagen -- and when Dagen's last interview said there is going to be short-term pain for consumers. So while it might have an impact on jobs, do you think it's going to have an impact on individuals?

SANTILLI: I think it's high -- if you look at a six pack is going to go up by a few pennies and automobile will go up by -- the price will go up by $40. I honestly don't think it's going to have a huge impact on other consumers. Frankly, I think it's all hype.

MCDOWELL: But it's not just -- it's not just a six pack of beer and it's an automobile, Ermanno, it's everything that follows. It's also the retaliatory tariffs from all these other nations. The administration is looking at automobile tariffs, so if you want to buy a Kia, that Kia might go up by several thousand dollars in cost, so when -- the sum total and it's not just -- again, so you're admitting that consumer prices are going to go up. I mean Peter Navarro was on this show when these tariff were first announced before they were ever implemented saying don't you worry your head. The six pack of beer is not going up that much. But again, it affects the entire supplier chain as well and some manufacturers are left wondering how they're going to source their materials.

SANTILLI: Yes. I think that's true. I think that there is a risk for some retaliatory tariffs, but tariff mechanisms are used every day by every country in the world, 50 percent of products imported in the United States are subject to some sort of a tariff. Now, it's not 25 percent. It's usually much lower. I think the average is about 2-1/2 percent. Retaliatory tariffs are a concern but hopefully Trump will be using this as sort of a negotiations tool to avoid that.

MCDOWELL: Do you have any sense? Have you talked to anybody in the administration at all? Do you have a sense of when we might have more certainty on that?

SANTILLI: No, I have not. I know that my customers and our suppliers, they're just kind of rolling with it. Prices are going up for aluminum and steel. But again, in our sector, we're not going to stop building just because something goes up by a few pennies.

MCDOWELL: Ermanno, thank you for being here. Ermanno Santilli, take care.

SANTILLI: My pleasure.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, President Bill Clinton ramping up his rhetoric. The former President arguing that impeachment hearings would have already started if a Democrat was the commander-in-chief. That's ahead. Plus, a crude awaken, American Airlines warning customers might face higher ticket prices if oil prices stay high. We break down the details, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: At least five people including a pregnant woman shot at a football game in Texas last night. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Well, the pregnant woman was shot in the chest and underwent an emergency C-section. The baby reportedly is OK, but the woman herself is in critical condition this morning. Now, this happened after two people opened fire at a football game. It happened in South Dallas. There's injured at least three women and two men. The motive for the shooting still unclear at this point, police are searching for the suspects in this. Well, (INAUDIBLE) this morning, Jordan's Prime Minister Hani Al-Mulki has resigned after several days of protests in that country. "AL JAZEERA" is reporting that Jordan's King Abdullah asked the prime minister to step down. These recent demonstrations over tax increases are the biggest in years in that country and a lot of police fired, and tear gas, and blocked roads is now the result of these protests as it really erupted in Jordan as you can see on your screen.

Well, an American Airlines flight was forced to make an emergency landing after its windshield was shattered by a powerful hailstorm. One passenger able to get this picture shows. You can see here the excessive damage to the nose of the plane. Luckily, the flight was able to lane safely. No injuries were reported. But meanwhile, American Airlines has warning now that a continued rise in oil prices could result in higher ticket prices for the passengers this summer. The spike in prices also resulting in a somber forecast for global airline profits in general. According to the International Air Transport Association, the industry is expected to post a $33.8 billion profit this year, but that's down $0.12 from the previous forecast. This of course due largely to rising fuel costs for the airline, and may oil reached 730 bucks per barrel for the first time in four years. Now, we're at 65.52. But again, these higher prices if they continue to the summer in particular airlines can only hedge so much, Dagen, you know they can maybe hedge 60 percent, 70 percent, but not whole enchilada, so your ticket may get a little pricier this summer.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: Now, all the good news for you this morning.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl Casone. Coming up, President Bill Clinton speaking out, why the former President is arguing that impeachment hearings would have already started if a Democrat was commander-in-chief? Plus, tensions bubble over trade ahead of President Trump attending the G7 meeting in Canada. We're breaking down the tariff tussle ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A different kind of double standard, former President Bill Clinton claiming if a Democrat was in office, impeachment proceedings would have already been happening.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think they have tried by and large to cover this investigation based on the facts. I think if roles were reversed now, this is me just talking but based on my experience. If there were a Democratic President in these facts for President, most people on Washington believe impeachment hearings would have begun already.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The President teaming up with author James Patterson, you saw him there for a spy thriller, a fictitious spy thriller involving the President of the United States. Joining me now is Bre Payton, a staff writer for The Federalist. Bre, what do you make of Clinton's comments?

BRE PAYTON, STAFF WRITER, THE FEDERALIST: Yes. I think he's totally wrong. I think that if the roles were reverse and if the Republican really were a Democrat, I don't even think that there would be an investigation at all to be, you know, quite frank. And, you know what, the part of his comments that bothered me the most was at the end when he said that, you know, the media has been covered this fairly and that their coverage of the Mueller -- ongoing Mueller probe has been, you know, based in fact and all of these sort of things like that. I think that that's totally off base. I think it's clear that a lot of members of the media are active participants in these ongoing investigations, you know, they're not passive recorders of history like Bill Clinton seems to think that they are.

TIMPF: Bre, hi, it's Kat. Why is Bill Clinton talking? I mean do you really think that having him out there is something that helps Democrats? Do you think that it could be actually doing some harm?

PAYTON: Yes. I think it could potentially be doing some harm, you know, in the same interview when he was asked if he has ever apologize to Monica Lewinsky, you know, throughout 20 years of having ample opportunity to do so he said that he hadn't, you know, so I think, you know, having out there rehashing a lot of these same things I think it just reminds everyone of what happened 20 years ago, and how not great things were, and have been for Democrats since then.

MCDOWELL: Well, and then you throw in Hillary Clinton who -- I, you know, who can't get away from a microphone. It's like a -- there's a magnet that what did she say in one of the recent speeches she gave in the last couple of weeks, I'm not over it.

PAYTON: No kidding.

MCDOWELL: Which it should have been the title of her book by the way, Bre.

PAYTON: Yes. I definitely agree. I think that honestly, you know, it is time to accept the lessons of 2016 on both sides of the aisle except that both parties are radically different now than they were three years ago. It's not the same political environment of America. I mean really it feels like every day we're rehashing the same thing or rehashing November 2016 all over again. I think it would be great if people would take the lessons away from that, and move along, and do what they need to do.

CARTER: You know, one of the things that I'm curious about. I mean I know that they did covered, did you apologize to Monica Lewinsky? But this President was known to be or may be if we were to look at it in the context of how would be perceived today, his behavior in the Me Too movement all of that, you know, we were talking about this earlier. It's astounding that wasn't brought up during this interview. Why do you think that was?

PAYTON: I think it wasn't brought up because I think that Bill Clinton gets a free pass along a lot of members of the media. I think you're absolutely right that it is time to revisit what happened to Monica. I mean she was patient zero in all of this, you know, in today's modern media and all these things like that. I definitely think that her story needs to be retold and revisited, and, you know, I think that the fact that they didn't ask him that and gave him a free pass on that goes to show you that the media definitely has a double standard, and that if the roles were reversed that things would not at all be the same.

MCDOWELL: And now, Bre, I point to the fact that Town & Country invited Monica Lewinsky to this event and then disinvited her once Bill Clinton agreed to show up, and then tried to like offer her up little chicklets if you will to get her to avoid talking about it and I think that just shows you why -- maybe not a whole party, but that man still gets a free pass from a lot of people.

PAYTON: Oh, yes, absolutely. I mean, you know, I guess in today's environment even after we've had the Me Too movement certain victims of sexual abuse are going to get elevated. Their stories are going to get elevated above others. It's really sad that our country is so politically divided to the point that that is a political issue as well, right? And that if you're a victim of a certain man, you're going to get marginalized and pushed to the sidelines, but if you're a victim of another man, it's going to be wall-to-wall coverage of, you know, this same thing, right? That disparity in and off itself is not fair. We shouldn't not have a double standard when it comes to women who have, you know, suffered at the hands of powerful men.

KELLY: Bre, it's Kevin Kelly here. And I think the kind of looming situation about Bill Clinton or Hillary Clinton keep going out to talk about themselves and what happened in November 2016 is overshadowing the Democrats especially going into this midterm elections, do you think would -- the Clintons are doing is counterproductive to helping the Democrats in the elections coming up?

PAYTON: Yes, absolutely. I mean I think it's very clear that the base of the Democratic Party has moved past the Clintons. So, you know, I think it would behoove the Democratic Party if they would picked up on that queue, you know, and would say, OK, it's very clear that our voters do not like these people. Let's move on and figure out what they do like who they do want to see on the ticket coming forward who they do want to see on the TV and what issues that they actually do care about. It's very clear that Democrats honestly don't care about many of the factions of the people that they try to pretend to care about or say that they care about, and I think this is just another example of that.

MCDOWELL: So this spy political thriller that President Clinton worked on with James Patterson, it involves cyber espionage and a traitor in the White House, is this a commentary on the current political environment according to Clinton and corner -- and based on what you said, Bre, about the division in this country?

PAYTON: Yes. I definitely think it could be a not so subtle, you know, swipe at what's going on, you know, I personally I'm kind of tired of fictionalized stories that are kind of rift from the headlines especially regarding this issue just because I personally feel just totally saturated, you know, with coverage of this. I don't think that, you know, the things that I enjoy for fiction and for pleasure reading need to have this as well. Personally, that's how I feel about it.

MCDOWELL: Bre, good to see you. I know that --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: The outrage machine in the last week has been and I only know how they're getting the gasoline to keep it charged up --

(CROSSTALK)

PAYTON: Their perpetual revolution marches on as always.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you, Bre. Bre Payton, as always. So President Trump tweeting this morning, this is my 500th day in office and we have accomplished a lot, many believe more than any President in the first 500 days. Kat -- that's Kat Timpf (INAUDIBLE) he lists what he accomplished, massive tax and regulation cuts, military and vet, lower crime, and illegal immigration, stronger boarders, judgeships, best economy and jobs ever, and much more. We had repeal and replace done and the savings to our country of one trillion dollars except for one person, but it is getting done anyway. Individual mandate is gone and greet less expensive plans will be announced this month, drug prices coming down and right to try.

KELLY: He didn't bring up the wall though.

TIMPF: Just the way that he tweets and the way that he speaks always makes me laugh. I don't know --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You can' help it. You can't help it --

(CROSSTALK)

TIMPF: Many people believe --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: But he left the wall out.

TIMPF: He did leave the wall out.

MCDOWELL: Well --

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: He did talk about borders.

MCDOWELL: Well, there was no wall funding and the -- for the most part there was replacement fencing funding and the omnibus spending bill, no restrictions on sanctuary cities in that -- in that spending bill. So again, but I will quote Ed Rollins he said that 20/20 bumper sticker should be promises made, promises kept. That's a lot of it whether you agree with the President or not, he has gotten a lot --

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: -- look forward on the healthcare. Don't go backwards.

MCDOWELL: But they've got to come up with a plan because --

(CROSSTALK)

CARTER: They have to come up with a plan.

MCDOWELL: Those premium increases are going to get announced in October right before people go to the polls.

CARTER: So much forward and get something done. Don't look back to what happened.

MCDOWELL: You don't want Nancy Pelosi as the Speaker of the House.

CARTER: No.

TIMPF: Certainly not.

MCDOWELL: So coming up, Dell reported quarterly earnings before the bell this morning beating revenue expectations. We'll break down those numbers ahead. Plus, high stakes in the soybean industry. We will -- you get a live look with Connell McShane on the farm. The impact of the tariff tussle between the U.S. and China on the farming communities, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 4th. Your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Markets still gaining at 139-point gain on Dow futures right now. We're looking at a nice rally to start this new week. This after stocks rallied on Friday, after that much better-than-expected jobs' report. Again, to point that out, job growth accelerated last month from where it's been on average in the last 12 months. It's an incredible in economic expansion that's been going on for more than nine years. Global markets following those gains; look at England, France, and Germany, we have gains across the board there. And in Asia overnight, it was the same story -- buying galore. All four markets, major markets in Asia, up this Monday. Nevertheless, trade turmoil. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross returns from China with no deal and it comes as our allies ramp up the threat of retaliation over steel and aluminum tariffs. The White House Trade Policy Director Peter Navarro standing firm on the need for these tariffs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NAVARRO: All the president is doing is defending this country's national security sovereignty and economic security from the flood of imports.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at the implications for business and markets straight ahead. Targeting the gas tax. A battle looming in California over a $0.12 hike. How it could impact the midterms as voters there, head to the polls tomorrow? Amazon in focus. One analyst raising its price target to $2000 a share. But where does it put the company in the race to one trillion against Apple? We will tell. Dell arising in the premarket. The company reporting better-than-expected revenue. The details, later this hour. Targeting tariffs. U.S. allies criticizing the Trump administration over its latest round of tariffs ahead of the G7 summit later this week in Quebec, Canada. Farmers are among hardest hit because of the tariffs so far. Connell McShane is in Ogden, Iowa with the very latest details. Hey, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, Dagen. Yes. You know, it's interesting, we want to try to make this story come to life as much as we can -- you talk about the trade talks over the weekend, so we come up to this soybean farm in beautiful part of Iowa. And we're just going to get down here and show you the rows of soybeans that are being grown here. And the idea when you think trade with China: look at these rows, they won't be harvest until September that's why they're so low to the ground. One out of every three rows of soybeans that we're looking at, end up going from United States, to China, eventually. The business numbers wise, works out to about $12 billion a year. So, when we talk about trade tensions in the United States, they're felt out here in Iowa. I want to introduce you to Ron Hecht, who's out here with us, a farmer, in Iowa, he's also on the president's advisory council for agriculture. Ron, thanks so much, first of all, for having you out -- having us out to your farm -- a beautiful place.

RON HECHT, IOWA FARMER: Thank you. It's a great place to be this morning.

MCSHANE: We were in Beijing there about a month ago or so. And at the time, they were telling us that some of the orders for later of the year had actually stopped -- for soybeans coming from the United States -- but how is your business been impacted by all of this trade talk, trade tensions?

HECHT: Well, actually, the price of soybeans has gone up since the talks started -- buyers around the rest of the world are stepping up and buying more soybeans than they were. So, we've -- so far, we've had a price increase.

MCSHANE: How does business work? In other words, this time of the year, they're not normally -- the Chinese buying from United States, right, comes later in the year?

HECHT: Right. China, is a seasonal buyer. They buy from the United States about six months a year, during our harvest time, and then they buy about six months a year from South America.

MCSHANE: From Brazil, and Argentina -- the final point, what's your big worry in all of this? Could they shift some that buying to the Brazilians, to the Argentinians, and how do you see the whole thing playing out?

HECHT: Absolutely. So far, so good. Everything has been fine. But if they shift their purchases during their normal purchasing time from U.S. -- which is starting in September -- that could be a problem for us, and that's when we might feel the price impact.

MCSHANE: All right. So, watch these trade talks like the rest of us. We'll be talking to Ron and some of the folks out here, Dagen, throughout the day but that's the idea -- they're watching it like all of us but watching it obviously a little bit more intently because this is their livelihood. A $12 billion a year business.

MCDOWELL: Connell, do you mind if -- I'm curious to ask Ron something can you just -- is he making any changes in the way he's managing his farm at all? Has he made any -- is he changing --

MCSHANE: Well, you know, that's --

MCDOWELL: You might already know that.

MCSHANE: It's interesting. We've talked a little bit about that off camera, but Dagen was asking you, and just a quick answer, Ron, if you're making any changes in the way you're managing your farm because of this? I know it's tough to anticipate what's next.

HECHT: No, I'm not really making any changes, but I'm being more watchful of what's going on in the marketing. But no changes are called for yet. Actually, nothing has happened, so far. And there is a chance that as a result of these negotiations, it will actually be helpful for U.S. and Chinese soybean trade. So, it's hard to know which way to jump right now.

MCSHANE: And that's kind of a final point, Dagen, is that the Chinese already charged a tax, right? There's a 16 percent tariff on soybeans coming out to United States into China now. Their threat is to make 25. But people like Ron are hoping, obviously, maybe that number at 16 goes lower. So, that's why they're so uncertain -- they may come out on top by the time this is all done. But right now, they just don't know.

MCDOWELL: I said when you were talking, you do such incredible reporting. So, I'll say that to your face, McShane. Connell McShane, in Iowa.

MCSHANE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: All right. Take care. You can catch Connell all day -- actually, for the next few days in Iowa. Rhetoric over Trump tariffs heating up over the weekend with Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau calling the president's move an insult. White House Economic Advisor, Larry Kudlow, saying: we must put America first.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, WHITE HOUSE ECONOMIC ADVISOR: Mr. Trudeau, I think he's overreacting. I don't want to get in the middle of that. As a fine friend and ally of the United States, nobody denies that. But the point is, we have to protect ourselves. We must protect ourselves.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Larry Kudlow also said this is like a family squabble, a feud. Joining me now with more about this tiff over tariffs, Brandywine Global Portfolio Manager, Jack McIntyre. Jack, to be clear, Friday, today, there is no worry showing up in the stock market here at home.

JACK MCINTYRE, GLOBAL PORTFOLIO MANAGER, BRANDYWINE: Yes, that's correct, because we know the U.S. economy is doing well. There's a strong employment report. Right. The risk obviously is from trade standpoint: is it going to escalate? I think the markets are kind of keying off Kudlow and Mnuchin versus Navarro and Lighthizer. As long as that's the case, I think the equity market will do OK.

KELLY: Jack, you know, one of the interesting things -- it's Kevin Kelly here. One of the interesting things that's been a theme this year for the markets is the rising rate environment we've seen. We've touched 3.15 on the 10-year treasury on an intraday basis. What are your worries for the fixed income markets, and are they going to be exacerbated given trade talks, given kind of what's happening right now with our ballooning deficit with -- as well as bunch of other -- structural things like are going to be happening the next decade where we have to issue tons of debt?

MCINTYRE: Yes. No, it's a great point. You know, the back end of that, about the -- budget deficit increasing trade deficit deteriorate. I mean, ultimately, that should be weaker or drive U.S. dollar lower, which to me is part of the solution that would help, maybe, alleviate some of the trade tension in there. But so, I think -- from a fixed-income investor standpoint. I don't see a lot of inflation pressures building right now. The fed is going to go slow. I think they've kind of given as the road map. So, yes, yields are going to drift higher, but not to the point where it's going to derail the U.S. economy.

MCDOWELL: Jack, there is a front-page story in the Wall Street Journal, today talking about global economic -- the growth story globally is fading. Dimming markets' optimism is the headline -- the global manufacturing, the index there, nine-month low. Baltic dry index, a measure of shipping costs, down 22 percent since peak last month. Copper prices, also down. Can the U.S. keep growing at a clip that the Atlanta fed thinks this quarter is going to be 4.8 percent growth which is extraordinary? Can we keep growing at that kind of pace if the rest of the world is slowing?

MCINTYRE: So, yes, I'm not sure we're going to actually print four percent in the U.S. But, so I think -- if you look at China, and the U.S. and combine those, those are two big, obviously, economies where data is still coming in better than expected. That's why I take the other side of that article because I think global economy still on solid footing yet Q1 was sort of a little bit slower. I suspect we'll see a little uptick in growth. I don't see global inventory overhang. The key is, the corporate sector CAPEX. I suspect, we'll see CAPEX cycle tying in trade sensations, though, that creates uncertainty in a business community, and if it accelerates then corporate might not build up CAPEX quite to the degree that they would absent those trade sensations. But bottom line, I think the global economy is still on very solid footing.

MCDOWELL: Well, on that note, there's a survey from the National Association of Business Economics shows many are worried about a recession, by 2020. Your take on that report? Because again, a -- we're more than nine years into this expansion. That would be -- that would be -- a recession by 2020 would be an expansion of 12 years. But what's your take? Because again, to introduce the worry of tariffs and what that will do to business that you know, prices and business activity here in the U.S.

MCINTYRE: Right. So, I don't think expansion have to die of old age. And the one characteristic of this expansion, as you pointed out, it's been long. But it's been a pretty slow expansion. So, it's not strong but it is long. But you're right, there's risk from on the trade standpoint. Clearly, if this escalates into a trade war, that's going to bring forward the next recession. But if I'm right about CAPEX, kind of coming to the forefront -- and inflation not getting out of hand, because you know the fed obviously ends up ending a lot of these expansions and if inflation remains tame the fed won't do it this time around. So, it is a possibility. It's you know, 18 months away, but I don't think it has to happen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Jack. Good to see you, Jack McIntyre. The president continues to tweet this morning, writing this: "As has been stated by numerous legal scholars, I have the absolutely right to pardon myself. But why would I do that when I have done nothing wrong? In the meantime, the never-ending witch hunt led by 13 very angry and conflicted Democrats and others, continues into mid-terms." And he tweeted this again. Mr. President, are you watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA? "China already charges a tax of 16 percent on soybeans; Canada has all sorts of trade barriers on our agricultural products. Not acceptable." Because that's exactly what Connell McShane was just talking about with that soybean farmer. So, it could go to 25 percent, at least that's the U.S. threat, but could it go lower than 16 percent? We'll be right back.

DANI KLUPENGER, TENNIS CHANNEL REPORTER: Welcome back to Tennis Channel Court Report a special presentation for Fox Business. I'm Dani Klupenger. It was a great day for the red, white, and blue at Ronald-Garros with two American women reaching the quarter finals for the first time in their careers.

Sloane Stephens' blasted in that (INAUDIBLE) off the court to punch her ticket into the elite eight. The U.S Open champion took the last 11 games of the match to wrap up the impressive win in under an hour.

Earlier, Madison Keys comfortably took care of business against Romania's Mihaela Buzarnescu to set up a quarterfinal meeting with Yulia Putintseva Kuznetsova. Four aces and 17 winners for last year's finals at flushing meadows.

Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova renewed their rivalry, Monday, in Harrisburg Place in the quarter, and you can watch it live on Tennis Channel. Our coverage from Ronald-Garros ticks the air at 5:00 a.m. Eastern. I'm Dani Klupenger.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The President still tweeting this morning, "The U.S. has made such bad trade deals over so many years that we can only win!"

Shares of Dell, meantime, up two percent this morning, after beating first- quarter revenue expectations. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with much more. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Monday morning, Dagen. That's right, so we're watching Delta this morning -- Dell to the upside this morning after the revenue really wowed Wall Street. The stock is up about two percent, so they saw the pc shipments on the rise. In fact, products overall, saw an increase of 22 percent. And that's the -- that is the motherload of what they do for revenue, about 78 percent of the revenue comes from products. So, that's where they saw the increase of 22 percent. Service revenue also gained and so with that, you see, it was a winning quarter. The stock over 52 weeks is up about 24 percent.

And then Amazon. When we're watching Amazon, we had some positive comments from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. The analyst there puts a $2000 price target. This is the fourth time this year that he's uped his price target. He actually is liking private label for the company. That would include Amazon's Echo essentials apparel, Elements nutritional supplements, but when will it get to that trillion-dollar market cap. Will it beat out Apple to do so? Well, in fact, if you want to see Amazon in the trillion- dollar market cap, it would have to trade at 2060.89, so not quite here but -- yet, but it's had five record closes in a row, looking at a sixth this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange.

Google in hot water, and now some are calling for a probe of the tech company in the wake of Google listing Nazism as an ideology of the California Republican Part. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Pretty strong stuff I'd say. When you're bandying about labels like Nazis and a South Carolina State Senator -- or North Carolina State Senator was called a bigot. That was stamped across her picture. This is all part of the Google picture at the moment, and I think is one of the reasons, why Google is underperforming the other tech stocks. You may notice, Dagen, that recently, Microsoft passed Google in terms of overall market value. That was a surprise. And there's other things going on as well. I remember the "60 Minutes'" piece one week ago, where -- well, it emerged that Google is watching you, knows everything about you, but who is watching Google?

Well, now, Representative Devin Nunes says, look, you're operating like a monopoly. Keep going like this and we're going to have hearings into you. Well, that's interesting because that's a real threat to Alphabet's business, Google's business going forward. It's profitability going forward, I think they're pressing for the breakup of the company. This is something to watch, because big tech is so powerful, they're just asking the politicians to rein them in.

MCDOWELL: And they've gotten away with a lot in recent years, and we just sat back and did nothing.

VARNEY: That's true.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: You, too.

MCDOWELL: Always, my dear Sir, 9:00 a.m. to noon, Monday through Friday, Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." You can't miss a minute.

Coming up, a fight over California's $0.12 gas tax intensifies. We head live to Orange County, California where a midterm battle to repeal the state's gas tax is brewing.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A midterm battle over California's $0.12 gas tax is brewing. Hillary Vaughn is live in Orange County, California with the very latest. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen. Well, National Democrats tell me their pathway to the majority in November runs right here through California. They are targeting 10 seats in the state, four right here in Orange County, but National Republicans says this, $0.12 tax -- gas tax increase at the pumps that state Democrats pushed through is actually going to pump the brakes on their road to victory in November because Republicans say it's energizing their base.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MATT GORMAN, COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, RNC: There's a lot of energy on the Republican side. People want to talk about how Democrats are enthused. Well, I don't see Democrats marching in the streets overpaying upwards of $5.00 a gallon for gasoline. And I think this is going to resonate with voters not just now but as well in the fall.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Voters are so fired up over this gas tax issue that one state senator is facing a recall vote tomorrow to kick him out of office for voting for the tax. But the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is convinced voters aren't going to be worried about rising transportation costs when weighing who to support for Congress and instead are focused on what's happening in D.C.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW GODINICH, SPOKESMAN, DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSIONAL CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE: I think that when voters are going to the polls this week, the issues that they are thinking about when they're voting for Congress are the issues that they're seeing coming out of Washington.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: There is one tax Democrat say voters are worried about the GOP tax plan that they say has hit voters in California the hardest. The California Republican leadership says Democrats in the state are to blame for the high taxes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM BRULTE, CHAIRMAN, CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN PARTY: I think there's a collective Democrat strategy to blame Washington, D.C., and Donald Trump for all of the ills in California. The fact of the matter is the Democrats own California, they've had total control of it for over seven years, and they don't want to take credit for their record here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Dagen, this $52-billion tax plan is meant to push cars off the road, but the GOP hopes it will push Democrats off the ballot in November. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Hillary. Hillary Vaughn for us in Orange County, California. Coming up, final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A giant fake hug to Kevin Kelly and Lee Carter for being with me this morning. So much to talk about trade, but these markets are loving what's coming out of Washington, at least so far. That does it for MORNINGS WITH MARIA. "VARNEY & COMPANY" is up right now. Stuart, it is all yours, Sir.

VARNEY: All right. We're off and we are running this Monday morning. Looks like kind of a follow on from last week. Good morning, everyone. Our allies are united on this, they don't like the tariffs we're imposing on them.

END

END

urn:contentItem:5V9X-3JM1-DXH2-6008-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Talks; Infant Ibuprofen Recall; New York Post: Chinese Billionaire Zhang Chin in Talks to Buy $60 Million New York City Apartment; The Next Phase of Poptivism2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMike Huckabee, David Barnett, Tasha Keeney, Matthew KingNEWSDomestic013102cb.231U.S.-China Trade Talks; Infant Ibuprofen Recall; New York Post: Chinese Billionaire Zhang Chin in Talks to Buy $60 Million New York City Apartment; The Next Phase of PoptivismMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, James Freeman

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It is the busiest day for earnings. Check out General Electric. The company reported earnings in the last hour. They were better than expected on revenue. The stock has been rising ever since the report's out. It is now up 4.5 percent. That is going to certainly impact markets this morning. GE up 4.5 percent on the heels of revenue coming in better than expected for the fourth quarter.

We're watching big tech today. Facebook soaring on a record profit last night even in the face of the privacy scandal. As you see, Facebook shares are up almost 12 percent right now.

The one to watch this afternoon is Amazon. It's reporting after the close tonight.

As you can see, Tesla down almost 5 percent, CFO stepping down, weaker than expected results there.

Microsoft down 2 percent this morning, also on earnings.

Raytheon missing estimates this morning at $2.93 a share versus an estimate of $2.89 a share on earnings.

We will keep following all the numbers that are hitting the tape as we speak.

Futures pointing to a mixed open this morning. Dow Industrials are down 7 points. The S&P 500 up 3. And the Nasdaq right now up 32 as you can see there.

After a sharp rally on Wall Street yesterday on the heels of the Federal Reserve basically saying it's on hold dependent on data for interest rate hikes. Dow Industrials shot up 500 points midday, up 434 points at the close, 1.75 percent. The S&P was up 41. And the Nasdaq up 155 points, 2.25 percent higher at the close yesterday.

Boeing and Apple really set the tone early in the session yesterday and even the Fed fueling even more gains late in the day. The central bank saying that it is done raising interest rates for now which is something Bridgewater's Ray Dalio told me just last week in Davos.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RAY DALIO, BRIDGEWATER: I think you will see a slowing that is more than they would expect and I think it will be a global he slowing because we have to look at ourselves within the context of Europe, it's slowing; China, it's slowing.

And when those things happen and connected, I think that it's -- they won't raise rates.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: In fact, he said that as early as November that he was expecting the Federal Reserve to change its stance.

European markets this morning are higher across the board. FT 100 up 43 points, two-thirds of 1 percent. CAC 40 in Paris is up 11 points, that's quarter of a percent. And the DAX index up 11 points as well, fractional gain in Germany this morning.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, take a look. best performer was Hong Kong and Japan, each up better than 1 percent.

And then back in the U.S. there's this. The arctic blast has turned deadly. Temperatures across the Midwest falling to the lowest levels in decades. We're going to take you there. It is really an incredible story this morning on weather.

Countdown to the Super Bowl meanwhile just three days away. We're taking a look at the big business of gambling and how it's changing the sports world.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down. Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and former Arkansas governor, Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee.
