BARTIROMO: No, it's not going to satisfy. The -- what I know is that China wants to open its markets. It's willing to open its markets in financial services. Already UBS has gotten the go-ahead. They own 51 percent of a bank in China. They're going to be able to own 100 percent of that company within three years.

Number one, Steven Mnuchin said to me yesterday or two days ago when I was in D.C., well, why are we waiting three years for 100 percent? They want it sooner, not in three years and financial services doesn't really address President Trump's base, the manufacturing base.

So, I think China -- we'll see. I mean, if it's a shell and it's nothing in between, but definitely I think China is willing to do financial services 100 percent.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, Foxconn backed off its plans to add manufacturing jobs in Wisconsin. That they're going to focus on research, development and design jobs but they said to make these liquid crystal displays in Wisconsin, that it's too expensive. So, I don't know how that plays with trade negotiations.

HUCKABEE: And never forget one important thing, people also want to live in the United States more than they want to live in China for the freedom, for the opportunities. The most important thing that we in this country that we export to the world --

MCDOWELL: But will we accept those immigrants?

FREEMAN: Yes, that's right.

HUCKABEE: -- is liberty, never forget that.

MCDOWELL: Will we accept those immigrants? That is the core of what is going on in Washington right now. Do we have open arms and will we raise the number of people we allow to immigrate to this country legally every year?

FREEMAN: Yes, that's a --

MCDOWELL: As we crackdown on illegal immigrants.

FREEMAN: If China won't embrace the entrepreneurial economy, let's recruit their talent. And this White House policy, what he's doing is he's reshuffling the existing slots. What the president ought to say in the State of the Union is we're going to increase the number of PhD engineers that we bring in from China, India and elsewhere.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right, we'll take a short break. When we come back, parents beware, big story here, infant ibuprofen recalled over potential dangers. We've got the story and the details next.

And then a major real estate play, Chinese billionaire Zhang Xin who I spoke with in Davos last week building her portfolio in the United States, she continues to expand, details on the price tag, next up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A nationwide infant ibuprofen recall has been expanded. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Parents listen up, Tris Pharma is expanding avoluntary recall of its infant ibuprofen because the product might contain a higher concentration of ibuprofen than labeled. The company has added three more lots to the recall list, they were manufactured for CVS and Walmart. Tris Pharma says there have been no reports of any illness.

A Chinese billionaire in talks to buy a $60 million apartment in New York City. The New York post says Zhang Xin is close to acquiring a full floor unit at 432 Park Ave. the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere. Zhang is the co-founder and CEO of China's largest property developer SOHO China. And Maria, you talked with Zhang about real estate at the World Economic Forum.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ZHANG XIN, CO-FOUNDER AND CEO, SOHO CHINA: Chinese have such a habit of putting money into real estate, buying real estate, and so -- and but now they're worrying on the other side, you know, the economy slowing down. So then, what does the government do and you know, to ease the credit, let the real estate continue and then people will with the credit put money into real estate, buying real estate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: The New York Posts says two other units at 432 Park Avenue on the market for $40 million are currently under contract.

And this, researchers at MIT are showing off their new robot that taught itself to play Jenga. Using a camera for ayes and two small prongs for fingers. It can gently remove the pieces. The robot determines which move is the best one to make by touching the pieces first, testing them out.

And speaking of Jenga, Louis Vuitton is releasing a $2,400 luxury Jenga set, the 54 L.V. monogrammed pieces are made from plexiglass, not wood. So, if you ever need an expensive gift, there you go.

BARTIROMO: Cool. Thank you, Lauren. Coming up, making the world better through business, the story of pop sockets and how it's using sales to help charities around the world. Good story next, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Pop sockets are taking over cell phones. They stick to your device to help you get a better grip and make it easier to watch videos. Today the company is launching the next phase of Poptivism, which it says is aimed at making the world better.

Here now in an exclusive interview is the CEO and founder of PopSockets, David Barnett. David, great to see you.

DAVID BARNETT, CEO AND FOUNDER, POPSOCKETS: Thanks very much for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. And PopSockets, what a great idea. How did you come up with this idea?

BARNETT: Well, back in 2010, I was tired of my headset tangling in my pocket. Each time I took it out, it was tangled. So, I went down to the nearest fabric store and glued a couple of huge clothing buttons to the backside of my iPhone 3 and wrapped my head set around them, it looked ridiculous. I got made fun of. And so, I started tinkering with mechanisms to get the button to expand and collapse, so that it would look a little more respectable and have more functionality, act as a stand, and act as a grip for the phone. Eventually --

BARTIROMO: So, you started off thinking you could just put your headphones around it, but then you realized there were so many other ideas.

BARNETT: That was the initial problem which is a lesson for me, that the problem that motivates you start tinkering is not always the problem you end up solving. So, the current product does solve for that problem. But that's not what most people use it for. So, I ended up settling on this accordion mechanism. And we just finished our fifth year of business. So, I started out of my garage, in Boulder, Colorado. And we've sold about a hundred million of these so far.

BARTIROMO: A hundred million pop sockets, wow.

FREEMAN: You were a philosophy professor.

BARNETT: That is correct. I'm ready for questions.

FREEMAN: When was the moment where you decided iPhone accessories were a better line of work?

BARNETT: Yes, all it was -- I would say some -- half of the philosophy professors watching this are laughing at me. And the other half are probably pretty jealous.

So, it is -- it can be a lot more fun than being a philosophy professor and sometimes, the problems we're dealing with are a little bit easier, usually.

HUCKABEE: Yes, but an assassin is the mother of invention and you invent something out of necessity. And I just love entrepreneurial ideas that come from necessity. You created something. I'm absolutely in awe of people who do something so simple and when I see it, I say why didn't I think of that?

MCDOWELL: But how are you giving back?

BARNETT: Thank you.

(CROSSTALK)

BARNETT: Sure, today, I'd love to share with you. Today we launched our Poptivism program to the public. And it encourages anybody sitting here to go to our website, you create your own grip. So, you upload your own art work, hopefully it work with an artist, unless you're a natural artist. So, you upload some beautiful graphic and then you can tag any charity you want. So, any five O's, 503 --

FREEMAN: 501(c)(3)

BARNETT: 501(c)(3), thank you, that you would like. So we have a bunch already lined up for you. And 50 percent of every sale of that product will go to that charity. So we have --

MCDOWELL: 50 percent of the sale, not the --

BARNETT: Not the profit.

MCDOWELL: -- income, not the profit, which is a huge amount of money.

BARNETT: Yes. I don't know any other -- any other brand giving this much away and allowing you to design the product. So it's customized impact. We have a bunch of different categories of charities including some charities around veteran services, so the Wounded Warrior, Bob Woodruff Foundation, The Mission Continues. Anyway, long list.

BARTIROMO: How great. And what are this retail for pop grips?

BARNETT: They start at $10.00 for the graphics and they go up to -- there's Swarovski for $50.00. I have a marble on my -- a genuine marble on my phone today. And it's -- I believe it's $30.00 for the marble.

MCDOWELL: Do you give these to influencers so they use them? Because I see them all over like reality television.

BARNETT: So, the virality of this is partly explained by the fact that celebrities got a hold of them organically. We don't -- we don't seed the influencers. We've made some -- we've had some partnerships with influencers but originally this blew up around Los Angeles because celebrities we saw Gigi Hadid and Ryan Seacrest. And it's just a long list of celebrities using them and that really led to their -- to their growth, quickly.

FREEMAN: And that's because it's a great handle for a selfie?

BARNETT: Sorry, I should explain it, yes.

FREEMAN: Or was it mainly a fashion?

BARTIROMO: let me see the (INAUDIBLE)

BARNETT: I haven't yet even explained it, you're right. It collapses and expands and it allows you to move your hand away from the backside of your phone. I have one of our wallets underneath it. It allows you to move your hand away. Once you do that, you can access your whole screen with your thumb.

BARTIROMO: Very cool.

BARNETT: Without having to drop your phone. You can take selfies, photographs much more easily.

BARTIROMO: We're going to be doing that.

I don't know. I know the victory in the Senate side is going to be a big win for this president but certainly the House could do investigation after investigation ...

urn:contentItem:5TM1-35S1-JBHT-D2NR-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Deadly Synagogue Shooting; Hillary's 2020 Vision; Brazil Elects Bolsonaro; Red Sox Win World Series; Best October Box Office Ever; Caravan Moves Closer To U.S.2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Tensions; Deadly Synagogue Shooting; Hillary's 2020 Vision; Brazil Elects Bolsonaro; Red Sox Win World Series; Best October Box Office Ever; Caravan Moves Closer To U.S.LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: A lot going on. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much and good morning, everyone. Happy Monday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us. And it is Monday, October 29th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. one the East Coast. Investors looking to start the week on a strong note. Take a look at where we stand with futures.

As you just heard, Dow Industrials set to open up about 50 points this morning, that's a quarter of a percent higher.

The S&P 500 is up 11, almost one-half of percent.

And the NASDAQ, up 62 points right now, that is up almost one percent.

This after major the indices capped off a volatile week last week with sharp declines. When all was said and done, the Dow and the S&P 500 down, better than one percent on Friday alone.

Meanwhile, the NASDAQ sliding another two percent on Friday. On the heels of disappointing results from Amazon and Alphabet, NASDAQ officially in correction territory now, that's down 10 percent from highs.

Global markets this morning, a firmer tone there as well. The FT-100's up 1-1/4 percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up a quarter of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany right now up now 1-1/2 percent, 160 points higher in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower at the close, with the exception of Hong Kong. As you can see there, the worst performer was China. Then another two percent overnight on the Shanghai Composite.

Earnings, of course, setting the tone on Wall Street this morning. Several Dow Components, including Apple, set to report this upcoming week. Investors are watching General Electric as well.

The Wall Street Journal reporting another dividend cut may be on the way for GE. That will not be good news for the stock. We will watch that this morning.

A little bit of a merger Monday on Wall Street this morning. IBM is acquiring Red Hat for roughly $33 billion. That is IBM's largest acquisition ever. How the deal will drive growth of the struggling technology giant, of course, it's all about the cloud which we heard a lot from, well, Larry Ellison, last week on the cloud computing business.

Breaking news overnight, a plane crashes shortly after takeoff in Indonesia. Nearly 200 people were onboard. We have the very latest on the search efforts going on this morning. Stay with us on that.

Plus, honoring the victims of the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting. Thousands filling the streets last night after President Trump condemned the attack on Saturday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This evil, Anti-Semitic attack is an assault on all of us, it's an assault on humanity. It will require all of us working together to extract the hateful poison of Anti- Semitism from our world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest as the alleged shooter is set to appear in court today. We will bring you that coming up.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle, and the President of maslansky + partners, Lee Carter, is here. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Happy Monday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Good morning. Happy Monday. Sad weekend, though.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Very sad.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So tragic.

ROSCHELLE: For sure.

BARTIROMO: Tough week, actually.

ROSCHELLE: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: Yes, what to make of it all, because, again, it doesn't seem like the political rhetoric from any -- either side is really being muted whatsoever.

And that, if anything, this violence has amplified it somewhat, and I don't know. I'm curious.

I mean there's much to be said about that, and the fallout for the country, and quite frankly, the world at large.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Uh-hmm.

CARTER: You know, it's a really sad time for our country. And when we have these kinds of attacks happening, I mean these are terrorist attacks and historically, we've come together at times of tragedy, in times of crisis and we can rise above the partisanship and that doesn't seem to be happening now.

And I don't think what it's going to take for our nation to heal. We've been through such terrible times and these terrorists need to be stopped and we need to come together to find a way to make sure that this never happens again.

BARTIROMO: And more evidence that there's a mental problem in the United States. And that also needs to be addressed.

By the way, different story, a victory in Brazil for the far-right candidate. Interesting to see what's taking place in other places away from America in terms of the people voting for more conservative leadership.

MCDOWELL: What they don't want to wind up being Venezuela quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Correct.

MCDOWELL: And they see how devastating socialism can be to a country and to everybody that it doesn't lift all votes and I think that that's part of what's at play here.

BARTIROMO: And Mr. Bolsonaro is being compared to Donald Trump in Brazil so we'll --

ROSCHELLE: Well, more populism and more nationalism themes in a lot of these elections around the world, too.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So it seems like it's certainly a trend right now.

BARTIROMO: Italy as well, another one. We will take a look at all of this coming up and we have a lot coming up in the next three hours.

Our top story right now is about earnings. The earnings keep on coming, Apple, Starbucks, General Electric, Facebook, ExxonMobil, all reporting their third quarter earnings this week. This is going to be another busy woke.

The October jobs report is also coming out this week on Friday. Expectations, 190,000 jobs to have been added to the economy last month with the unemployment remaining unchanged, 3.7 percent. That is the expectation.

Of course, we are beginning the month of November this week, so Friday, we'll get those jobs numbers first Friday of every month.

Here now, the National Investment Consultant at U.S. Bank Wealth Management, Dan Heckman joining us. Dan, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

DAN HECKMAN, NATIONAL INVESTMENT CONSULTANT, U.S. BANK WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So let's talk about the backdrop for investing today and that would be earnings in the economic story.

Your expectations for earnings, how would you assess things so far and the upcoming jobs report?

HECKMAN: Well, earnings have been actually pretty good, Maria. The top line's growing on average about eight percent, 50 percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported so far.

And, again, eight percent on the top line on the average. And on the bottom line, it's been up over 20 percent.

So earnings have not been, you know, all of that bad. I just think there's been a lot of high expectations going into this quarter. And any kind of disappointment, whatsoever, is being very much punished.

The market's gone through a very we'll say severe correction. S&P 500 is down about 9 percent, the Nasdaq almost 11 percent.

Out of the last 25 trading days, we've been down 20 days of those 25. And so, you know, our works is just that we're probably pretty much through the majority of this correction. We may have some continued volatility, but there's been some great opportunities created in this decline in the markets.

BARTIROMO: And you would expect we'll start to get clarity after the midterm elections in terms of the President's agent and whether it gets executed.

Part of that is tax cuts coming, the upcoming midterms after the midterms.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, told me yesterday on Sunday morning futures that they are, in fact, working on a second tax cut plan, not only extending the individual cuts, but also lowering taxes for the middle class and additional 10 percent.

Here's Kevin Brady yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN BRADY (R-TX), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE: The economy is booming. We're on track for the first total year over year plus three percent economic growth in more than a decade.

We're seeing jobs coming back, paychecks going up. Main Street is hiring again. So the President's really about -- focused on more of that economic growth.

I think permanence really depends on this election, if Republicans and -- are -- retain control of the house, and the senate, next year we will do reconciliation and make these tax cuts permanent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So Mitch, he did say that it's a separate thing, the 10 percent cut, additional cut in taxes, separate from the -- making the individual cuts permanent, so it is a second tax cut plan that they're working on.

ROSCHELLE: Right. The thing that we haven't heard a lot about is how this is getting paid for.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROSCHELLE: The President talked about doing it from a budgetary perspective with cutting all of the departmental budgets by 5 percent, but from a tax policy perspective, I don't know if they're going to have to unwind something from the previous plan in order to pay for this.

MCDOWELL: Well, half of Americans already paid no net federal income tax, number one, and I think a lot of people are all for making the individual tax cuts permanent, which could have been done potentially if Democrats got on board --

CARTER: They'd --

ROSCHELLE: Right, right.

MCDOWELL: -- with the tax reforms in the first place. But I think you have to be -- if you're in Washington, be very careful about anything at this point that drives up a deficit and the debt even more.

Because what kicked off this recent -- this bout of volatility and the down -- the downward move in the market earlier in October, it was worries about higher interest rates.

So if you do anything in Washington in terms of spending and not paying for it and that five percent cut to all these departments is less than one percent --

ROSCHELLE: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- because discretionary spending makes up what -- discretionary spending acts defense --

There's an actual break period in between innings, and we'll have people bet substantial sums of moment just on the next inning. You're taking a three-hour game, you're chopping it down to a 20-minute game. Tennis, same sort of thing, people will bet set by set or game by game, and you're taking a longer event and chopping it down into a much shorter event so people can make their bet, know whether they won or loss in a short period of time.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Joe, great to have you, thanks so much. We'll be watching.

ASHER: All right. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Joe Asher, joining us there. Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. Back in moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lee Carter.

CARTER: I am looking forward to seeing how this week plays out in polling coming out to the midterms. I think that this week could surprise us all, and I think it's going to be a week that's going to lean Republican.

BARTIROMO: Really? All right.

CARTER: They do.

BARTIROMO: Eight days away from the Midterms. Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: The Fed's preferred inflation measure, PCE, just came out, it's still flat at two percent which is the Fed's target. So, let's see if the Fed holds off and doesn't continue to raise rates.

BARTIROMO: Why do we need a rate hike in December, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath has co-wrote an article in the Wall Street Journal that starts at "What If That Was as Good as It Gets In Terms of the Economy?" Well, we're looking at 3.1 percent wage growth coming up this Friday for last month, that would be the best in 9-1/2 years.

BARTIROMO: Which is good stuff.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: All right. Have a great day, everybody. Go seize the day! Dagen McDowell, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, great to see you. Let's get right to Stuart. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VW0-HXD1-JBHT-D4W3-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Deadly Synagogue Shooting; Hillary's 2020 Vision; Brazil Elects Bolsonaro; Red Sox Win World Series; Best October Box Office Ever; Caravan Moves Closer To U.S.2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisU.S.-China Trade Tensions; Deadly Synagogue Shooting; Hillary's 2020 Vision; Brazil Elects Bolsonaro; Red Sox Win World Series; Best October Box Office Ever; Caravan Moves Closer To U.S.LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: A lot going on. Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much and good morning, everyone. Happy Monday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us. And it is Monday, October 29th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. one the East Coast. Investors looking to start the week on a strong note. Take a look at where we stand with futures.

As you just heard, Dow Industrials set to open up about 50 points this morning, that's a quarter of a percent higher.

The S&P 500 is up 11, almost one-half of percent.

And the NASDAQ, up 62 points right now, that is up almost one percent.

This after major the indices capped off a volatile week last week with sharp declines. When all was said and done, the Dow and the S&P 500 down, better than one percent on Friday alone.

Meanwhile, the NASDAQ sliding another two percent on Friday. On the heels of disappointing results from Amazon and Alphabet, NASDAQ officially in correction territory now, that's down 10 percent from highs.

Global markets this morning, a firmer tone there as well. The FT-100's up 1-1/4 percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up a quarter of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany right now up now 1-1/2 percent, 160 points higher in Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower at the close, with the exception of Hong Kong. As you can see there, the worst performer was China. Then another two percent overnight on the Shanghai Composite.

Earnings, of course, setting the tone on Wall Street this morning. Several Dow Components, including Apple, set to report this upcoming week. Investors are watching General Electric as well.

The Wall Street Journal reporting another dividend cut may be on the way for GE. That will not be good news for the stock. We will watch that this morning.

A little bit of a merger Monday on Wall Street this morning. IBM is acquiring Red Hat for roughly $33 billion. That is IBM's largest acquisition ever. How the deal will drive growth of the struggling technology giant, of course, it's all about the cloud which we heard a lot from, well, Larry Ellison, last week on the cloud computing business.

Breaking news overnight, a plane crashes shortly after takeoff in Indonesia. Nearly 200 people were onboard. We have the very latest on the search efforts going on this morning. Stay with us on that.

Plus, honoring the victims of the Tree of Life Synagogue shooting. Thousands filling the streets last night after President Trump condemned the attack on Saturday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This evil, Anti-Semitic attack is an assault on all of us, it's an assault on humanity. It will require all of us working together to extract the hateful poison of Anti- Semitism from our world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest as the alleged shooter is set to appear in court today. We will bring you that coming up.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle, and the President of maslansky + partners, Lee Carter, is here. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, everybody. Happy Monday.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Good morning. Happy Monday. Sad weekend, though.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Very sad.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So tragic.

ROSCHELLE: For sure.

BARTIROMO: Tough week, actually.

ROSCHELLE: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: Yes, what to make of it all, because, again, it doesn't seem like the political rhetoric from any -- either side is really being muted whatsoever.

And that, if anything, this violence has amplified it somewhat, and I don't know. I'm curious.

I mean there's much to be said about that, and the fallout for the country, and quite frankly, the world at large.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Uh-hmm.

CARTER: You know, it's a really sad time for our country. And when we have these kinds of attacks happening, I mean these are terrorist attacks and historically, we've come together at times of tragedy, in times of crisis and we can rise above the partisanship and that doesn't seem to be happening now.

And I don't think what it's going to take for our nation to heal. We've been through such terrible times and these terrorists need to be stopped and we need to come together to find a way to make sure that this never happens again.

BARTIROMO: And more evidence that there's a mental problem in the United States. And that also needs to be addressed.

By the way, different story, a victory in Brazil for the far-right candidate. Interesting to see what's taking place in other places away from America in terms of the people voting for more conservative leadership.

MCDOWELL: What they don't want to wind up being Venezuela quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Correct.

MCDOWELL: And they see how devastating socialism can be to a country and to everybody that it doesn't lift all votes and I think that that's part of what's at play here.

BARTIROMO: And Mr. Bolsonaro is being compared to Donald Trump in Brazil so we'll --

ROSCHELLE: Well, more populism and more nationalism themes in a lot of these elections around the world, too.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So it seems like it's certainly a trend right now.

BARTIROMO: Italy as well, another one. We will take a look at all of this coming up and we have a lot coming up in the next three hours.

Our top story right now is about earnings. The earnings keep on coming, Apple, Starbucks, General Electric, Facebook, ExxonMobil, all reporting their third quarter earnings this week. This is going to be another busy woke.

The October jobs report is also coming out this week on Friday. Expectations, 190,000 jobs to have been added to the economy last month with the unemployment remaining unchanged, 3.7 percent. That is the expectation.

Of course, we are beginning the month of November this week, so Friday, we'll get those jobs numbers first Friday of every month.

Here now, the National Investment Consultant at U.S. Bank Wealth Management, Dan Heckman joining us. Dan, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

DAN HECKMAN, NATIONAL INVESTMENT CONSULTANT, U.S. BANK WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So let's talk about the backdrop for investing today and that would be earnings in the economic story.

Your expectations for earnings, how would you assess things so far and the upcoming jobs report?

HECKMAN: Well, earnings have been actually pretty good, Maria. The top line's growing on average about eight percent, 50 percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported so far.

And, again, eight percent on the top line on the average. And on the bottom line, it's been up over 20 percent.

So earnings have not been, you know, all of that bad. I just think there's been a lot of high expectations going into this quarter. And any kind of disappointment, whatsoever, is being very much punished.

The market's gone through a very we'll say severe correction. S&P 500 is down about 9 percent, the Nasdaq almost 11 percent.

Out of the last 25 trading days, we've been down 20 days of those 25. And so, you know, our works is just that we're probably pretty much through the majority of this correction. We may have some continued volatility, but there's been some great opportunities created in this decline in the markets.

BARTIROMO: And you would expect we'll start to get clarity after the midterm elections in terms of the President's agent and whether it gets executed.

Part of that is tax cuts coming, the upcoming midterms after the midterms.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, told me yesterday on Sunday morning futures that they are, in fact, working on a second tax cut plan, not only extending the individual cuts, but also lowering taxes for the middle class and additional 10 percent.

Here's Kevin Brady yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN BRADY (R-TX), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE: The economy is booming. We're on track for the first total year over year plus three percent economic growth in more than a decade.

We're seeing jobs coming back, paychecks going up. Main Street is hiring again. So the President's really about -- focused on more of that economic growth.

I think permanence really depends on this election, if Republicans and -- are -- retain control of the house, and the senate, next year we will do reconciliation and make these tax cuts permanent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So Mitch, he did say that it's a separate thing, the 10 percent cut, additional cut in taxes, separate from the -- making the individual cuts permanent, so it is a second tax cut plan that they're working on.

ROSCHELLE: Right. The thing that we haven't heard a lot about is how this is getting paid for.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROSCHELLE: The President talked about doing it from a budgetary perspective with cutting all of the departmental budgets by 5 percent, but from a tax policy perspective, I don't know if they're going to have to unwind something from the previous plan in order to pay for this.

MCDOWELL: Well, half of Americans already paid no net federal income tax, number one, and I think a lot of people are all for making the individual tax cuts permanent, which could have been done potentially if Democrats got on board --

CARTER: They'd --

ROSCHELLE: Right, right.

MCDOWELL: -- with the tax reforms in the first place. But I think you have to be -- if you're in Washington, be very careful about anything at this point that drives up a deficit and the debt even more.

Because what kicked off this recent -- this bout of volatility and the down -- the downward move in the market earlier in October, it was worries about higher interest rates.

So if you do anything in Washington in terms of spending and not paying for it and that five percent cut to all these departments is less than one percent --

ROSCHELLE: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- because discretionary spending makes up what -- discretionary spending acts defense --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- is a very small part of our annual spending, so I'd be very - - they need to tread very, very cautiously in in D.C.

BARTIROMO: To the point.

CARTER: I also think that it's a -- it's a very -- it's a fine line that they're walking right now between tax cuts and the deficit because so many traditional conservatives want to see us get spending under control.

And so if they don't have a plan that address both sides of it, I think that you're going to lose a lot of traditional conservatives' enthusiasm especially going into the midterms.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. Now, this trillion dollar budget deficit is not a good thing for this country, period.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And something has to get done to fix that.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about that, Dan?

HECKMAN: Well, we are very concerned about the projection of the deficit going out forward and we think the additional supply, which has been a 63 percent increase in the second half of treasury securities' year over year has certainly weighed on the bond market and one factor, in our opinion, of why rates have risen so much here in the second half.

So we are certainly concerned about the budget deficit. I think we share - - your other guests' earlier comments about, how are you going to pay for it?

BARTIROMO: Right.

HECKMAN: So rising deficits are going to be an issue that the market is going to be focused on and I think they have already talked about it.

BARTIROMO: So there's -- so there's debt and deficits, and then there's the China story and the tariffs. I spoke with Senate Homeland Security Chairman Ron Johnson yesterday.

He said, very bluntly, there is a real threat from China. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. RON JOHNSON (R-WI), CHAIRMAN, SENATE HOMELAND SECURITY: Let's face it, China has been stealing hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of our industrial secrets, as well as our military secrets. And that is really, I think, one -- the biggest threat that we face in terms of our relationship with China.

If we have a unified rest of the world when it comes to trade in our dealings with China --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JOHNSON: -- we'll discipline them to begin, you know, really adhering to the norms of the rest of the world trading system.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: So a moment ago, Dan, you seem believe that this market was sort of stabilizing at this point and you suggested you would be putting new money to work in stocks, is that right, or do you worry about debt and the China story as cutting into that?

HECKMAN: Well, we really think there are some great opportunities in the market right now. The P/E average right now on stocks is about 17 times, that's near the historical 25-year average.

So, you know, many of these stock have just been hammered to the point where they look like pretty attractive values and we are pleased to see the bond market kind of calm down here, so to speak.

The 10-year yield has come back down, but regarding China, it's been, I think, no big secret that they have been diminished in their activities in the -- our treasury auctions.

Last week, we had very weak bid to cover ratios, so it needs to be monitored here, there's no question about that, Maria.

MCDOWELL: One thing that I'll add and to tie the earning season into what's been going on, so Apple is -- many people are looking at Apple hoping that Apple can somehow rescue this overall market.

You saw how Alphabet and Amazon got hammered up after they reported just slower sales growth or tepid sales growth however you want to characterize it. Apple -- listen for Apple on Thursday when they report to talk about china because they are chained to China in terms of a manufacturing hub.

They can't really extricate themselves from that, that's what -- one that people are going to be listening for from Tim Cook and others on the call.

BARTIROMO: And specifically inventories. Remember Dan Niles joined us last week and he said that inventories at Apple are up 89 percent.

And, you know, when you have that kind of a product inventory, you're really --- you're really reliant on selling those phones, and are you going to be able to sell a thousand dollar XPhone into China where the economy is slowing down to get those inventories cleaned up.

ROSCHELLE: And --

BARTIROMO: So that's going to be something I want to watch as well on --

ROSCHELLE: Let's not lose sight of the fact that the dollar's song and the one is weal, so you're also selling those in a -- in a period of time where they're sort of more expensive as well. So, that's another thing to consider.

BARTIROMO: I'm surprised we haven't heard more about currency from quarterly earnings.

ROSCHELLE: I think it's --I think it's a big issue across the board.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And I think you should hear more of it in guidance, they're talking more about tariffs because they're politicizing a little bit, but currency's a big issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: Uh-hmm.

ROSCHELLE: And maybe the two are interrelated to some degree, but currency's a major issue for corporate earnings.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm sure you're right. Dan, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

HECKMAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Dan Heckman joining us. And be sure to join us for full election coverage next week. We are -- we are now eight days away. MORNINGS WITH MARIA will start an hour earlier at 5:00 a.m. Eastern on November 7th, the day after the big midterm elections on Tuesday night, the 6th.

I'm going to get your reaction to what you're seeing, Lee Carter, this morning. I want to get your sense of where we are eight days from the midterm elections, so we'll get into that this morning. Stay with us on that.

But first, a nation is mourning this morning. The victims of the Pittsburgh Synagogue attack are remembered. The alleged shooter will appear in court today. We will have the very latest there after this break.

And then a multibillion dollar deal to tell you about, IBM and Red Hat team up to become the world's number one cloud provider, that's next. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Tragedy at the Tree of Life Synagogue, thousands of people attending a vigil honoring the victims of this massacre where 11 people were killed, six others injured, and the alleged killer set to appear to court today.

Fox News' David Miller -- David Lee Miller is live in Pittsburgh this morning. David, good morning to you.

DAVID LEE MILLER, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. We are in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood. Behind me, over my shoulder, the Tree of Life Synagogue.

At this hour, it is still a crime scene. This despite the fact the shooting took place almost 48 hours ago. You can see the yellow police tape around the perimeter of the building.

It was early Saturday morning that 46-year-old Robert Bowers, authorities say, entered that building and killed 11 people. He entered with three handguns and an AR-15 style semi-automatic rifle. They say he used all four weapons in his rampage.

An FBI affidavit quotes Bowers during his gunfight with police saying, "They are committing genocide to my people. I just want to kill Jews."

The U.S. Attorney has now stated that the process is in place to seek the death penalty.

Meanwhile now, for the first time, survivors are speaking out. Barry Werber was only feet away from the gunman inside this synagogue Saturday morning when he went unnoticed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARRY WERBER, SHOOTING WITNESS: He didn't see us. Thank God. The only thing I had in my hand was a cell phone and it's a dumb phone so it doesn't light up when I'm talking on it.

I could see that he looked around only because there was a shaft of light as he opened the door. He stepped over Mel's body, didn't pay any attention, stepped back and walked out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MILLER: At last word we were told that Bowers was in fair condition being treated for gunshots at a local hospital. Later today, he will be in court. Maria.

BARTIROMO: I will be watching that, David. Thanks very much, David Lee Miller this morning in Pittsburgh.

Quick break and then air disaster, a massive recovery operation underway this morning after a jet crashes into the sea in Indonesia, details coming up.

And then third time's a charm, I guess. Hillary Clinton hints at another run for president. What she said, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A massive recovery mission underway this morning after a passenger jet crashed in Indonesia. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. The Lion Air Boeing 737 with 189 passengers and crew onboard went down into the waters off the coast of Indonesia.

Indonesian officials now say they do not expect to find new survivors. The plane went missing just 13 minutes after it left for an island off of Sumatra. All that rescue crews have found so far are ID cards, some personal belongings, and aircraft debris.

We're going to continue to follow up this developing story as they are looking into cause of that crash.

Well, the Florida man accused of sending at least 14 pipe bombs to prominent Democrats is set to make his first court appearance in Miami today.

56-year-old Cesar Sayoc faces five federal charges up to 48 years in prison.

He was arrested on Friday, four days after the first package was found in New York. A single fingerprint led the FBI to his arrest.

U.S. Marshals are also expected to transfer Sayoc to New York City where the Justice Department wants to try him in the U.S. Attorney's Southern District.

Well, IBM making its biggest acquisition ever. The company buying software and services company, Red Hat, for 33 billion.

IBM attempted to become the world's largest hybrid cloud provider. A hybrid cloud is when a company keeps some of its data in a public cloud service and some of its data on servers on its own premises.

IBM CEO, Ginni Rometty, calls this acquisition a "game changer". She believes this is the next chapter of the cloud.

Taking a look at shares of IBM, they are lower in the premarket, down more than five percent, but take a look at Red Hat, the stock is soaring in the premarket, 50 percent in change, Maria. There you go. Big news in the tech world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it sure is. And, of course, we've heard all about the cloud and the potential for big growth numbers from the cloud from Oracle Cofounder, Larry Ellison, last week --

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- when he sat down with me for an exclusive interview. We discussed cloud opportunities. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

South Korea, India and, at least, seven other Asia-Pacific countries are exploring these new taxes as our Mexico, Chile, and other Latin American countries. Take a look at shares of Facebook and Google, they're higher in the pre-market, Maria.

But you know, the IMF warned about the economies of emerging markets having problems. I guess this is their fix. Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right. Now, go where the money is, right. Cheryl, thank you. Coming up, countdown to the midterm elections. We break down how the economy may impact decisions for voters, coming up.

And then, an incredible win for the Boston Red Sox yesterday, the highlights from the World Series all here, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, October 29th, your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Personal income and spending reports just hitting the tape. Personal income, coming out now, not a major market reaction but we are just getting the numbers right here, and we are awaiting these numbers. It has not typically been a market mover. Markets are up 151 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as you can see. Personal income up was two-tenths of a percent versus an estimate of up three-tenths of a percent.

Meanwhile, personal spending, is up four-tenths of a percent versus an expected increase of four-tenths, so it is right in line with the estimates. Futures, as you can see, trading higher this morning. Dow Industrials up 164 points, that's two-thirds of one percent. S&P500 is up better than one percent, and the NASDAQ up 1-1/4 percent on the morning this morning. Futures indicating a pretty good opening for the Broader Averages after a tough week last week.

European indices also higher this morning. Take a look at European indices with the FTSE100 higher by 141 points, that's better than two percent -- this is the high of the morning right here. Things have been improving all morning. CAC Quarante in Paris is up 1-1/4 percent and the Dax, in Germany, up better than two percent right now. As we said, personal income up two-tenths of a percent versus three-tenths of a percent; and personal spending right in line with the estimates, up four-tenths of one percent. Asian markets overnight -- and futures, as you can see, are higher. Asian markets overnight, were mostly lower. As you can see, with the exception of Hong Kong up a fraction; Shanghai Composite down better than two percent overnight.

Voting to the right. Brazil electing a conservative candidate, who some have compared to President Trump. Of course, the alternative was the socialist candidate. We're breaking it all down for you this morning.

The $20 million tweet. Why Tesla CEO Elon Musk says the tweet that cost him all that money was actually worth it.

Plus, Boston's big win. The Red Sox beating the L.A. Dodgers to the take the World Series yesterday. We have all the highlights in sports.

And then, place your bets. Details on the latest sports team to strike a sport gambling deal, coming up this morning as well.

All those stories coming up this morning, as we continue. President Trump just tweeting on Brazil's election, meanwhile, here is what he said, the president: "Had a very good conversation with newly elected president of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, who won his race by a substantial margin. We agreed Brazil and the United States will work closely together on trade, military, and everything else. Excellent call. Wished him congratulations," says the president. All that coming up, on Brazil.

But first, our top story this half an hour: 8 days to go until the midterm elections. President Trump, has been hitting the campaign trail every day to rally before the midterms. The recent economic swings put at forefront for voters. Joining us now, is Douglas Holtz-Eaken, he is former CBO Director from a McCain Economic Advisory and American Action Forum President. Douglas, good to see you. Thanks for joining us this morning.

DOUGLAS HOLTZ-EAKEN, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN ACTION FORUM: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: What's your outlook for the midterms, Doug?

EAKEN: Well, I think I don't know much more than the experts. And they suggest that the Republicans are going to lose control of the House, the Democrats will control the House. Republicans could pick up a seat in the Senate and that will leave us with a Congress that probably won't have the ability to get a whole lot of legislation done over the next few years.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean if you were to see, the Democrats take the House which is largely expected, does the agenda that the president has been putting out, come to a halt?

EAKEN: It looks that way to me. It's very unlikely that they're going to pass anything to make the tax cuts permanent for example, which is going to be a very good idea. I don't see any real hope for further legislation other than, you know, getting the spending bills done, and that's keeping the government running, and that could run into something difficult.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I want to talk about this spending and these tax cuts because I know that you've been a deficit hawk and we want to talk about where we are in terms the debt and deficits, but we are looking at a potential tax break for middle class which is in the works. Pennsylvania Congressman Scott Perry joined us earlier, he said he's in favor of more tax cuts, congress needs to focus on less spending first, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SCOTT PERRY (R), PENNSYLVANIA: You don't fix your overspending problem by taxing people more, you fix that by spending less, and so that's what we really need to focus on. The president, offered a budget that spent less and we didn't take much or any of it up being. As a matter of fact, the tax proposal that House sent, the Senate, I think, saved $400 billion, but yet the Senate sent it back with a trillion dollars additional spending. And unfortunately, to get something that allows the people to keep more what they earned has to make it through Senate as so long as that's full of liberal folks that don't want to cut spending, we're going to have this problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What about that, Doug, can they stop spending? Or cut down on spending?

EAKEN: There's no evidence to that so far. No evidence so far. I mean, you and I had this conversation before. They're concentrating on the annual spending which is a third of the budget. No one is even talking about the two-thirds of the budget that's growing at -- you know, growth rates for the next 10 years of six percent for Social Security, 5.8 for Medicare, 5.2 for Medicaid.

Those are enormous growth rates, they have to come down, that's where the money is and there's no conversation about that. So, I'm sympathetic to the idea that we need a tax code that's permanent, this idea with of temporary tax cuts from the middle class makes no sense. They could do some things that are built on the success last December, but they really do have to get serious on the spending side, and they haven't.

BARTIROMO: Yes, so, where are the opportunities to spend less? Let's talk about that, because you know, Maya MacGuineas form the Committee for Responsible Budget is saying that the budget is in an unsustainable long- term trajectory. She writes, the federal debt already high and rising. The country's fiscal outlook in medium and long terms are both extremely troubling. And they're looking at long term outlook, where is the opportunity to cut spending, Doug?

EAKEN: Well, for the record, Maya is a crazy optimist -- it's a little worse than that, in my view. So, look, it's not complicated. The Social Security program, for example, is promising to cut benefits across the board by 25 percent, for people in retirement, in 12 years when it runs out of money. That's a terrible way to run a pension program. So, we should fix Social Security, we should fix Social Security right now.

There have been six or seven bipartisan commissions that put together proposals to get that done. That should be the number one objection for anybody. Why would we want to have something that retirees can't count on? Then you move over to the next big ones: Medicare and Medicaid. Those are programs that don't serve the beneficiaries very well at all. I mean, we know that our seniors don't get the health outcomes that other country seniors do, yet we spend so much money, indeed it has an unrestricted draw in the U.S. Treasury.

So, the first thing to do is put those programs on budget, make them live within a finite amount of money and serve the beneficiaries. And then, we can just move across the board, go to the farm programs, go to annual spending. There's lots of waste in there. And really, get serious about running these programs effectively.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you need courage to be able to come out during an election year, and say, we're cutting back on your Social Security checks and your pension. But, clearly, you've got to go where money is. And then, there is this global market worrying over trade and tariffs, Senator Ron Johnson told me on Sunday that the president should keep the pressure on China since they pose more than just an economic threat, but is tariffs the answer? Here's what he said, Doug, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. RON JOHNSON (R), WISCONSIN: Let's face it, China has been stealing hundreds of billions of dollars-worth of our industrial secrets, as well as our military secrets, and that is really, I think, the biggest threat that we face in terms of our relationship with China.

I think the good news is because of public awareness, the gap between those on offense and those of us on defense, is quite honestly narrowing. And hopefully, if we have a unified rest of the world when it comes to trade and our dealings with China, we'll discipline them to begin -- you know, really, adhering to norms of the rest of the world trading system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Your take, Doug, is China going to adhere to the norms -- the rules of the world on the global basis or not?

EAKEN: Not without a lot of pressure. I think China really does not understand how far it is out of line with acceptable behavior.

BARTIROMO: You're right.

EAKEN: I think the important phrase there with Senator Johnson was a "unified world," I don't think we have that. The administration has correctly identified China as problem, has been very aggressive in a bilateral fashion and trying to get China to change this behavior, that's been utterly unsuccessful. I think it will be unsuccessful but acting alone. The key is to get a multilateral approach where all of our key allies in Europe, and in Japan, and in other parts of the world agree to enforce better discipline on China. That's not happening right now, that's the missing piece in this strategy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I wonder if as he continues to do trade deals and confirms these deals with others, like a deal with E.U., you know, like when the new president in Mexico gets into place where you as actually see the commerce back-and-forth from the new USMCA deal, will that bring these countries together in a unified front against China?

EAKEN: It may, but it's a big if. They are the -- negotiated USMCA has a provision that says: "Anyone who signs this cannot negotiate a free trade agreement with nonmarket economy," aimed directly at China. So, that makes sense. If you can get to those deals in place, and I'll point out, Canada and Mexico haven't signed that deal yet, there's been a lot of talk about it, but there's no signature, and it still -- we have to go through Congress as well.

BARTIROMO: Right.

EAKEN: Going -- getting a deal with Europe takes time. So, all of these things are very time-consuming, and quite frankly, China has a much greater capacity, just wait us out. President Xi is a president for life, their capacity to directly intervene in the economy is enormous.

BARTIROMO: Right.

EAKEN: And so, I worry about the time tables here, and I worry about whether there's enough pressure from enough countries to get things moving quickly.

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll be watching that. Doug, it's always a pleasure to see you, thanks so much.

EAKEN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Douglas Holtz-Eaken joining us there. Stay with Fox Business for a special midterm election coverage, it begins on November 6, at 7:00 p.m. Eastern, we are all hands-on deck. And then the next morning, MORNINGS WITH MARIA will start an hour early at 5:00 a.m. Eastern, that's on November 7th. So, join us, as we bring you all the results from midterms.

First, though, Elon Musk is firing back. Why the Tesla CEO says 20- million-dollar fine against this his company was, well, it was worth, straight ahead. Then Brazil's next president; Stuart Varney weighs in on the country's elections back in a moment right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Check out Tesla shares up this morning as CEO Elon Musk brushes off worries about an investigation into the infamous funding secure tweet. Susan Li is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with details there. Good morning, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. That is right, the Tesla's CEO, well, still CEO, Elon Musk, says it was worth it, the $20 million in fines that he had to pay and Tesla had to pay for those tweets back in August, when he said funding was secured, he was taking the company private and that was at $420.

Well, don't forget, the SEC, of course, a part of that settlement says that Elon Musk, if he's going to tweet about Tesla, he has to go through the company's communications channels, so not sure if he's adhering to those procedures but he did say late on Friday after that tweet, less than an hour later, he says he's going to take a few days off the Twittersphere.

OK. Let's also talk about Wal-Mart. And I guess in this case, what Amazon can do, Wal-Mart will try to do better if they can, so they are launching their own cashier-less stores. They're testing something called Sam's Club Now, that will open in Dallas next week. They told us about this back in June, and it's pretty much similar to what Amazon Go is doing. So, they're employing mobile checkout, camera-like systems for inventory management, and I guess, they're still playing catchup to Amazon at this point. Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Susan, thank you. We are watching markets today. We'll be watching you with a big rally expected at the opening of trading. Meanwhile, Brazil's next president, big story, conservative candidate Jair Bolsonaro is claiming victory this morning in his country's election. Joining us now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Good morning to you, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Look, I don't think that the election of Jair Bolsonaro is going to have that much effect on our daily lives in America or our economy or our market, but it really is another marker on an extraordinarily populist trend. I think it started with Brexit, it continued with the election of Donald Trump in November 2016, then it's the five-star movement in Italy, a populist movement, which runs Italy, and which may well break up the European Union. And now, Brazil, it's the largest country in Latin America, 210 million Brazilians, the largest economy in Latin America, and it's going to be run by a conservative. This is quite something. So, it's in with the new, which seems to be populism, and out with the old. I'm sure you've reported it, Maria, but Angela Merkel, she's stepping down as the leader of her party, and will try to finish out her term as Chancellor of Germany. But whether she makes that or not is another story.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: She is out, and the populists in Brazil, Italy, America, elsewhere are in. What a trend.

BARTIROMO: I think -- I think it's also important to note that look what the alternative was, Stu, if you didn't vote in Brazil for Bolsonaro, you were voting for a socialist. So, once again, socialism was tested here.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We're looking at socialism sort of testing the waters across the world. People are not having it.

VARNEY: I wonder if it has an implication for our elections in eight days here. After all, the Democrats could be characterized as moving rapidly towards socialism, and President Trump, you could characterize him as a populist, if you like. That's the contest that we face in eight days' time. I just wonder if these worldwide trends will play out here, all over again.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It really seems like it is taking a hold across the world. In people -- in places you didn't expect like Italy, as you mentioned.

VARNEY: Oh, yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Stu, I know you're going to have a lot more in 10 minutes. We will see you then.

VARNEY: Yes, you will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Do not miss Stuart after MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

But first, there's this, hockey's new bet, details on the partnership between the New Jersey Devils and sports book operator William Hill. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. So, the New Jersey Devils getting into the legal gambling business. The NHL team making a multi-year deal with William Hill, to provide legalized gambling inside the Prudential Center, where they play. Joining us now is the CEO of William Hill U.S., Joe Asher. Joe, great to see you this morning, thanks so much for being here.

JOE ASHER, CEO, WILLIAM HILL U.S.: Hey, good morning. Nice to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, congratulations.! This has been a long-term investment for William Hill, right?

ASHER: Well, it is. You know, we've been working towards the day when sports betting would become legal outside Nevada, and of course, that day came about five months ago when the Supreme Court overturned the federal law that had prevented that. And we are going to New Jersey pretty shortly thereafter, and recently announced the deal with the Devils and we're excited about it.

BARTIROMO: How much -- what kind of revenue are you talking about? What are you expecting in terms of the revenue that this will bring in?

ASHER: Well, across the country, I mean, you're looking at a market that the estimates are somewhere between 150 to $400 billion in the amount waged; figured about five or six percent that comes into revenue. So, it's a substantial market across the country, but of course, that's going to develop over a period of years, as states begin to legalize sports betting at the state level. You know, the Supreme Court basically turned the issue back to the states. States like Delaware, NEW Jersey, Mississippi, West Virginia got going quickly, and others are in the process, and it will develop over the next few years.

ROSCHELLE: Joe, Mitch Roschelle, good morning. Is the plan to expand across multiple states or is the plan in New Jersey to expand in the State of New Jersey?

ASHER: Well, our plan, of course, is to do both, Mitch. We've opened already at about a dozen locations in Mississippi, one in West Virginia. We're gearing up to get going in the not too distant future in Pennsylvania and in Rhode Island. And in New Jersey, we've just opened up our third retail location, but also in New Jersey, you can bet online by just downloading the app in the App Store, and you can bet from anywhere within the state, but you do have to be present within the State of New Jersey in that case to place your bets. You know, out here in Nevada, you've been able to bet on sports for decades, and you go into a casino, you sign up for your mobile account here in the State of Nevada and then you can bet anywhere within the state. Right now, we do about two-thirds of our business on mobile.

CARTER: So, you're just betting on the -- you know, you're at -- you're at a Devils game, you're just betting on that game or can you bet on all sports? Can you tell me a little bit about what it's like for them?

ASHER: Sure, you can bet -- you can bet on all sports within the -- within the State of New Jersey. Just like, you know, like I was at the Golden Knights game here in Las Vegas last night, really, really exciting game and they do a great job there, but not only were people betting on the Golden Knights game, they're betting on other hockey games that are going on. And now, of course, this is a busy time in the sporting calendar, last night, you had the last game of the World Series, basketball is getting going, we're in the middle of football season. So, there's a lot of -- there's a lot going on in the sporting calendar, which makes it a busy time of the year for us.

MCDOWELL: Joe, it's Dagen McDowell, name a sport that people might be surprised that people bet on so much. Like -- go ahead.

ASHER: No, I was going to say one of -- one of the big -- so, right now, we do about -- here in Nevada, we do about 37 percent of our business on what we call "in-play sports," or betting after the game has started. The number one sport for in-play by far is Major League Baseball, because the pace of the game is so conducive to it. But also, tennis is a -- is a big game that -- or a big sport for in-play wagering.

LEE: I would not expect tennis.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But people -- but again, it's -- because it's only two players, and/or in singles as two players, you can see if somebody looks fatigued.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Has gotten inside of their own head. And so, that's when you place in in-play bet maybe.

ASHER: Oh, you know, it's got --

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE) from experience.

ASHER: Yes, you know, look, it allows you to take a bigger game then chop it down into a much shorter interval. So, for instance, in baseball, people like to bet will there be run scored in the next inning, yes or no. There's an actual break period in between innings, and we'll have people bet substantial sums of moment just on the next inning. You're taking a three-hour game, you're chopping it down to a 20-minute game. Tennis, same sort of thing, people will bet set by set or game by game, and you're taking a longer event and chopping it down into a much shorter event so people can make their bet, know whether they won or loss in a short period of time.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Joe, great to have you, thanks so much. We'll be watching.

ASHER: All right. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Joe Asher, joining us there. Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. Back in moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lee Carter.

CARTER: I am looking forward to seeing how this week plays out in polling coming out to the midterms. I think that this week could surprise us all, and I think it's going to be a week that's going to lean Republican.

BARTIROMO: Really? All right.

CARTER: They do.

BARTIROMO: Eight days away from the Midterms. Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: The Fed's preferred inflation measure, PCE, just came out, it's still flat at two percent which is the Fed's target. So, let's see if the Fed holds off and doesn't continue to raise rates.

BARTIROMO: Why do we need a rate hike in December, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath has co-wrote an article in the Wall Street Journal that starts at "What If That Was as Good as It Gets In Terms of the Economy?" Well, we're looking at 3.1 percent wage growth coming up this Friday for last month, that would be the best in 9-1/2 years.

BARTIROMO: Which is good stuff.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: All right. Have a great day, everybody. Go seize the day! Dagen McDowell, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, great to see you. Let's get right to Stuart. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria.

END
