urn:contentItem:5WT5-B0Y1-JB20-G2CM-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Turmoil; Interview with Rep. Warren Davidson (R) Ohio; Gun Regulation; Fallen Marine Identified; Blackrock Takes State at Authentic Brands; From Friend to Foe; Oil in Focus2019-08-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Rep. Warren Davidson, Tom Kloza, Ron Carson, Peter Thiel, Joe PiscopoNEWSFinancial081202cb.231U.S.-China Trade Turmoil; Interview with Rep. Warren Davidson (R) Ohio; Gun Regulation; Fallen Marine Identified; Blackrock Takes State at Authentic Brands; From Friend to Foe; Oil in FocusDagen McDowell, Richard Fowler, Cheryl Casone, Jared Max

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 12th.

To your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

U.S.-China trade turmoil, Goldman Sachs warning the risk of recession rising due to ongoing trade battle and that a deal is not expected before the 2020 election.

Futures are showing a lower open of 157 point loss on the Dow futures. this after the Dow, Nasdaq and S&P closed lower for the second week in a row. You see the losses across the board, much turmoil in the markets.

In Europe you have selling as well in England, France and Germany.

In Asia overnight, markets mixed there. In China the yuan was once again set weaker than 7 yuan per U.S. dollar for the third day in a row. The Hang Seng down as protests continue in Hong Kong. The Nikkei closed for a holiday.

From friend to foe -- major tech companies calling California home but now that very same state's lawmakers are going after these giants.

Oil in focus, Saudi-state owned oil giant reporting a decline in profits due to falling oil prices but looking to diversify as it prepares for an IPO.

Plus housing in America -- a look at the markets that are red hot. The locations might surprise you.

Here to break it all down this morning: radio, host New Leader senior fellow, Fox News contributor Richard Fowler; pollster and Maslansky & Partners president Lee Carter; and PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle.

Welcome one and all.

Mitch -- what are you watching for this week. we do have some news here in the U.S. Consumer prices, we get that I think on Tuesday; retail sales, Walmart earnings are on Thursday. Will anything change the mood in the markets which is one of grave concern I should say about the global economy?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: If those numbers come out, inflations low and retail sales are strong I think it's going to reinforce the notion that our consumer-dependent economy is still strong. However, every day that goes by where there's lack of clarity as to what is going to happen with the China deal and we continue to get bad news about other countries around the world, I think that's going to continue to put pressure on our markets.

GDP in the U.K. was negative, they came out a couple of days ago last week. So I think their markets are going to be continuing to be very defensive worrying about what's going on around the world.

MCDOWELL: And $15 trillion in government debt that has a negative yield on it.

ROSCHELLE: And there's actually -- could be as much as $5 trillion more of non-government debt that's indexed to the government debt.

MCDOWELL: All right. Banks hard hit last week and you saw the bank stocks fall and money just flood out of exchange-traded funds.

Lee, what are you watching in terms of the consumer and how people are feeling? Because you do -- you have this unusual convergence of the rhetoric from the campaign trail and from the President and then the negative news that's showing up in the markets. And I just wonder if that ultimately has an impact on sentiment.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Yes. I think that when you're looking at consumer confidence right now, it's an all-time high. When you look at the Democrat candidates and they're trying to tell the American people how bad the economy is right now. So Elizabeth Warren over the weekend was really tweeting about this kind of thing. When we have evidence right now that people can look to to support the Democrats' assertions.

So you could day is the economy as strong? Are we going into recession. Look at weakness in the markets. The Democrats are going to have some points now that they can drive home and I think it's going to resonate with voters.

so I think that it's a really dangerous place for Republicans to be in. I think they have to take it very seriously and look at how this is going to play out meantime (ph).

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think Lee is absolutely right. I think what you have to look at is the overall marketplaces. As for consumers, yes, the economy is doing well. They know it's doing well. We saw the wages uptick a little bit but the problem with that is that everything around wages, everything you your wages to pay for has gone up, whether it be housing, whether it be prescription drug costs, whether it be any early childhood education.

All these costs have gone up for working families. So when now the economy's pointing to these indicators, I think these indicators are already there, and the American worker has already experienced --

MCDOWELL: But overall inflation -- that's actually the problem, that overall inflation is rock bottom. So you, from a political perspective, pick out things that people get upset about like prescription drugs. But again, over all, consumer prices --

ROSCHELLE: But (INAUDIBLE) are down. You know the cost of the television is down.

And (INAUDIBLE) stays down gasoline --

MCDOWELL: Gas is one thing that is still very -- the gasoline price is very much in check and that's kind of one thing that is a point -- a sore spot for people when gas starts going up.

ROSCHELLE: You know, when you're talking about CPI, they often ship out food and energy. But right now food and energy are down.

MCDOWELL: Right. We will have more coming up. But right now China trade in focus. Negotiations between the world's two largest economies at a standstill as President Trump suggests the next round of talks with China maybe called off.

Goldman Sachs now worrying that the trade fight could trigger a recession and says it does not expect a deal with China before the 2020 election.

USMCA also on pause, that's the Canada-Mexico-U.S. trade deal as Democrats delay the vote.

Maria spoke exclusively with former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" asking him about the sticking points for a trade truce with China and the likelihood of adopting USMCA.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Can the President do a deal with China without the promise that these things will be reversed?

STEVE BANNON, FORMER WHITE HOUSE CHIEF STRATEGIST: They have really been taking American innovation for free for 10 or 15 years. Trump is stopping that. And that's you see the so-called elites on Wall Street in corporate America keep saying the sky is falling, the sky is falling.

I think President Trump has got them. He's got all the face cards right now. He holds all the cards. I think he's being very consistent.

Look, this is an economic war the Chinese have been at the United States. It's got a technology part. It's got a currency part. It's got a trade part.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BANNON: President Trump has done I think a very solid job.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on whether or not Nancy Pelosi brings USMCA to the floor and will the President be successful in these other trade deals with European nations?

BANNON: President Trump I think has cut good deal here. He's accommodated both of these nations particularly got this content situation in Mexico. So China can't game the system and send their products through Mexico. It's a deal that works for people, works for the farmers.

I don't know how Nancy Pelosi holds this back, anything but partisan politics.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now Ohio Congressman House Financial Services Committee, member of the Republican Study, Committee and Second Amendment Caucus Warren Davidson. Congressman -- good to see you.

What are your expectations for getting the passage of USMCA, but also this U.S.-China trade deal -- which the markets are saying you better get it done and get it done fast.

REP. WARREN DAVIDSON (R-OH): Hey -- Dagen. Thank you for the questions. Thanks for covering the issue. I mean trade is vitally important to Ohio and to the nation.

So, you know, prior to coming to Congress, I was in manufacturing 15 years on the receiving end of bad trade policy. And when President Trump talked about getting after fixing our trade agreements, enthusiasm. I mean just a tremendous amount of support from the country from this sector. And we're still expecting great things.

And with USMCA you can see we have a great agreement. We just need to get it across the finish line. I expect it'll have to be voted on in September, maybe early mid-October at the latest.

MCDOWELL: But business investment has weakened in the most recent quarter, actually turning negative. You have factory activity has slowed for several months in a row. Manufacturing was, you know, the great manufacturing renaissance last year, but that being hit by these trade negotiations. How long can the manufacturing companies and the very employees withstand these negotiations?

DAVIDSON: Well, I think with the investment -- that's the biggest reason we need some kind of certainty. So when I spoke with the President we were talking about how to move USMCA agreement across the finish line, we were talking about look at steel stocks, for example. They're more profitable than they've been but yet their share prices, the public-traded companies are down.

And that's not because of the cash flow or normal economic models. It's just people know that this could change maybe with one tweet. So we really need to get a law on the books, some kind of certainty that would say markets can know where they are heading., whether that's a 20 percent tariff, a 200 percent tariff or zero percent tariff. That certainly will help market settle.

And when I talk to the biggest companies, they say look, you know, we go into annual planning here in the fall and we all, we're looking at, you know, regulatory reform, tax reform, invest, grow, put the capital to work here in America but the uncertainty on trade is causing them to pause and say, I don't know, where do we put it to work. And so I think it's a real factor that does need addressed.

MCDOWELL: Let's turn to gun regulation in the aftermath of the shootings in El Paso, Texas and Dayton, Ohio. Former vice president and 2020 hopeful Joe Biden writing an op-ed in the "New York Times" calling for a renewal of the ban on so-called assault weapons. It's titled "Banning Assault Weapons Works".

"That's why as president I will push to ban them again." It reads in part, "I fought hard to expand the assault weapons and high capacity magazines banned in 2004. The Republicans who allowed these laws to expire asserted that they were ineffective. But almost 15 years after the bans expired with the unfortunate benefit of hindsight, we now know that they did make a difference. The 1194 assault weapons and high-capacity magazines bans worked. If I'm elected president, we're going to pass them again and this time we will make them even stronger."

Congressman -- your reaction to that, because this -- Vice President Biden is saying this, but is this really on deck something for Congress to tackle?

DAVIDSON: Well, I'm speaking to you from Dayton, Ohio, so really the whole region still reeling from the, you know, horrible events here. And really thankful for the tremendous amount of support we've received from all over the country.

And when you look at the solving problems, you want to make sure that you do cause and effect, right. So people structure these logical fallacies and say this is what caused it, that's what caused it.

Well, the shooter is what caused it, we need to focus on what is the root cause that's changing in shooters. The assault rifle ban, if you looked at murders in the U.S., the long-term mean is about 13,000. Murders are actually trending down over the long term. But mass shootings are going up.

On average it's about 300 murdered by rifles per year. So truly if you we wanted to reduce murders by firearm in a year, you would -- you would look at handguns which are about two-thirds of the problem.

So when you look at trying to solve this, you know, the data just doesn't show that this is what's the issue. But yes, people say these things have a great capacity to inflict more -- more harm, more casualties faster, but it really isn't being done.

Thankfully with all the assault rifles as they're defined all over the country, they're mostly sitting in gun safes causing no harms to anyone and then used actively by enthusiasts.

MCDOWELL: Well Congressman -- would you get behind, I will say strengthened (ph) background checks because, again, unlicensed firearm sellers say at gun shows and online there aren't backgrounds in some cases performed with those sales, would you get behind basically requiring background checks for any sale of weapon in the U.S. say for like an exchange between relatives?

DAVIDSON: I don't think -- you talk about hypotheticals, but I don't think I've seen language that I can support on that.

I mean, so one, let's be clear, background checks are already required including for online sales. So while you can buy from an online vender the firearm has to be shipped to a Federal Firearm's License holder and that FFL holder has to do a background check to transfer the firearm.

So when you look at what this would really get after would be private sales where there would be a (INAUDIBLE) to saying if you want to sell your car, well, you can't sell it, you have to go to a dealer to a dealer to sell it.

And I get there are different things, but it really is a tremendous change in the scope of the law. And most people agree that the only way to truly make that effective is to have a firearms registration protocol. Some people support that, most -- most Second Amendment supporters do not.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- good to see you. Thank you so much -- Congressman Warren Davidson. Take care.

Coming up, the world's biggest money manager Blackrock adds "Sports Illustrated" to its portfolio. Details on the multimillion dollar deal.

Plus the housing market, red hot in some parts of the U.S., the surprising places that are seeing a boom straight ahead.

MCDOWELL: A marine killed in combat in Iraq identified overnight.

Cheryl Casone has the details -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, Dagen -- gunnery Sergeant Scott Koppenhafer died from enemy fire on Saturday. He was advising Iraqi security forces there. The 35-year-old from Colorado joined the Marine Corps in 2005, earned several honors including bronze stars and the title of Marine Special Operator of the Year. Koppenhafer leaves behind a wife and two children. He's the first American service member to die in combat in Iraq so far this year.

Well, Blackrock is adding "Sports Illustrated" to its portfolio -- the world's biggest money manager taking and $875 million stake in Authentic Brands. This makes it the company's largest shareholder.

Authentic Brands, you may not know this, they own "Sports Illustrated", Nine West shoes, Aeropostale and similar brands. This values Authentic at more than $4 billion. That includes debt, we should add. There is Blackrock's year to date for you.

Finally you can never have enough news about mac and cheese. Chick-Fil-A is now serving it nationwide as of today. This is the first time the restaurants offered a new permanent side dish since 2016. Chick-Fil-A mac and cheese really nice gooey blend of cheddar, parmesan, Romano. The chain also offering its frosted caramel coffee today. That's coffee, vanilla ice cream desert with some caramel syrup in there.

I just thought I would talk about mac and cheese and a lot of sweet things at 7:18 in the morning, New York time.

MCDOWELL: You know what? Thank you -- Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: We're talking about it because again, people making disparaging remarks about Senator Cory Booker because he's a vegan, right. And so we did a little research online to find out what Senator Booker was eating at the Iowa state fair and apparently it was a fried peanut butter and jelly sandwich and some fried pickles.

CARTER: Sounds like a smart choice, right.

FOWLER: I would eat both of those things.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Who did the best job, you think at the Iowa State Fair. I know you were watching over the weekend. Do want to call out somebody in terms of really being able to connect with the people?

FOWLER: That's a good question. I mean I think the soap box thing is always if you have to do it, it's the next. And I thought Joe Biden did very well with the crowd outside the gaffe. And I also think that Senator Booker did really well as well.

MCDOWELL: What were you going to say -- Lee.

CARTER: I'm all about Andrew Yang -- because I think there's somebody who is grabbing headlines that nobody's expecting too. Everybody is looking at Biden, I don't think it changed anybody's minds. I think Andrew Yang is gaining so much.

MCDOWELL: And he got an endorsement on Twitter inadvertently from Elon Musk over the weekend.

CARTER: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So there you go. But I don't like when -- you know what? You can disagree with Senator Booker's politics and his policies. But don't shame him because he chooses not to eat animals. Again friends not food.

CARTER: But I also love that --

(CROSSTALKING)

CARTER: -- in the article that he ordered another one. He had one bite and he's like said this is good, let me order another one.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Exactly.

CARTER: Love not.

MCDOWELL: So he's not in the health camp. He's just in the I don't eat animals camp. I think Tulsi Gabbard is either a vegetarian or a vegan too. Just saying.

Coming up, oil in focus. Saudi state-owned oil giant reporting a decline in profit but is looking to diversify as it prepares to go public.

Plus big tech in focus. Lawmakers in California considering a bill that forces Google to answer some tough questions. We take a look later this hour.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back.

Oil under pressure. Down again morning below $54 a barrel. Prices moving lower in the midst of a trade dispute -- our trade dispute with China not only the U.S. but really worldwide. The International Energy Agency last week lowering its forecast for global oil demand for the third time in four months.

Joining us now, OPIS, that's the Oil Price Information Service energy analysis global head -- I got it all -- Tom Kloza. Tom -- good to see you.

TOM KLOZA, ENERGY ANALYSIS GLOBAL HEAD, OIL PRICE INFORMATION SERVICE: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: What is going on with oil right now? Demand versus supply and what about the direction of this?

KLOZA: Well, demand versus supply is a little bit of a head fake. We are definitely seeing global demand exceed global supply and will probably see that for the next few months or so. The problem is that trading community recognizes that in 2020 that gets reversed. And we have more supply than we have demand.

And you throw in the downdrafts, almost like wind sheer from trade war and so forth. And you do have these revisions in downward demand growth for mostly emerging countries. So we thought that prices were going to be close to $70 right now, we are about $12 short of that and it doesn't look as though the investment community which really accounts for most of the movement in crude oil. It does not look as though they will be seduced into buying something they think might go to $70 but then go to $60.

ROSCHELLE: Tom, what does that mean for the domestic production that we have because you say that it's stalled, is that temporary or permanent because I'm thinking about our own economy which is dependent upon those jobs that are created in domestic production?

KLOZA: I think it's temporary. We are going to see U.S. production probably surpass 13 million barrels a day next year. It was probably about 5, 5.5 back during 2011, 2012, the first day of spring.

So we can fall a little bit more and companies can make money if they don't have a lot of debt. If you're Chevron and or you're Exxon in the Permian Basin you're ok. If you're somebody that's mortgaged an awful lot to drill you're probably not ok.

So we are right there at the line where if we dip another $5 or $6 a barrel it will definitely slowdown.

FOWLEWR: What impact does this have on all of the -- I mean I know you have various pipelines that are being put online to sort of increase United States oil production with this sort of downward pressure on oil prices. What impact does it have on all those explorations?

KLOZA: Well, they are building the pipelines. And those pipelines are going to come online. They're going to come online the last hundred days of the year and they're going to bring that crude oil from New Mexico and WestTexas to Houston and to Corpus Christi for exports.

Now the problem is who is your major export customer? China -- and if China cuts a deal with Iran, you know, I don't think the United States is going to be looking to sort of intercept vessels leaving from Iran to China. So it's going to be quite an Italian (ph) offer to drive here.

I mean the President has proved that he has an itchy Twitter finger when it comes to oil and oil prices. He tweets if prices dropping lower. Doesn't appear as though he has an itchy trigger finger to really start something apocalyptic in the gulf.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of that region, Saudi Aramco is buying 20 percent stake in India Reliant Energy business, one of the company's largest overseas acquisitions ahead of planned IPO. Tom -- your take on this?

KLOZA: I think they're going to be buying a lot of assets internationally. I think they probably would have pulled the trigger on U.S. asset, a U.S. refinery if not for the MBS tragedy and all the bad publicity, bad publicity that they got for the royal family there.

MCDOWELL: For the murder of the journalist.

KLOZA: Yes. They definitely want to buy more downstream. They want to have a customer for all that crude because the Saudis have another 2 million, 3 million-barrels a day in their pocket. Stuff to think its start up in an instant beyond what they can start up if they start using some of the new technology and really pumping more oil. And if world demand were to rise.

So they want to buy more U.S. refineries, more foreign refineries, that refinery that you mentioned in (INAUDIBLE) it's like Gunggadin (ph) -- they have thousands and thousands of people working on it and it is the biggest refinery in the world.

MCDOWELL: So real quick -- gasoline prices, U.S., where do you see them in a couple of months in the summer?

KLOZA: Trending lower, I think not going much higher unless we have a hurricane, that can always screw things up but probably really low. If I were gaming sort of presidential politics for the next 18 months or so I would say the gas prices will not be an issue in the 2020 campaign. If anything it might be oil prices are a little bit too low, gas prices very, very modest. But it's probably not going to be a point of contention.

MCDOWELL: Makes it harder to sell that green new deal where they get rid of fossil fuels in a decade doesn't it now. We've cheap and plentiful fuel to drive us around this fine nation?

KLOZA: It does. But there will be a battle between the Obama era CAFE standards and what they call SAFE where you can basically drive big SUV wherever you want and not worry about it. That battle looms in September and that may set the stage for the next five or six years.

MCDOWELL: Between essentially California and the rest of the nation.

KLOZA: California, 23 states and the rest of the country where you actually do drive like in the commercial and pick up, you know, deliver a calf or in New Jersey you drive a big SUV and you pick up a pound of veal.

ROSCHELLE: Drop kids off at soccer.

KLOZA: That's it.

MCDOWELL: Go Giants.

KLOZA: Go giants. And go downhill Cowboys.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Tom Kloza -- great to see you as always, sir.

KLOZA: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: Coming up we are watching markets this morning. Futures extending their losses -- 208 point loss on the Dow futures right now. We take a closer look ahead.

Plus Peter Thiel targeting Google, why the billionaire investor thinks the FBI should take a closer look at the tech giant next.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo, it's Monday, August 12th, your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. U.S.-China trade turmoil, Goldman Sachs warning the risk of a recession is rising due to the ongoing trade battle and then a deal is not expected before the 2020 election.

Futures are pointing to a lower open on Wall Street, this following a week where the Dow, NASDAQ and S&P all finished to the downside.

Protest escalates in Hong Kong, all flights cancelled, after demonstrators staged another sit in at the airport. Questions about Google and U.S. National Security, Peter Thiel, calling for Google to be investigated by the U.S. government, the PayPal co-founder wants to know if the tech giant has been infiltrated by China. MORNINGS WITH MARIA starts right now.

We have a big show this morning, joining the conversation, New Leaders senior fellow, FOX News contributor, Richard Fowler. Good morning, Richard, so good to see you.

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Pollster and Maslansky & Partners president, Lee Carter, and PWC partner, Mitch Roschelle, I love all three of these people, individually, in different ways. Again, you all --

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: And collectively.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but you all bring, like, such intelligence and such insight and work ethic and rigorous honesty to the conversation. You can't beat that.

Also on deck this morning, tech billionaire investor, Facebook board member and PayPal co-founder, Peter Thiel, who spoke with Maria on Google investigations in the future of Artificial Intelligence, radio host A.M. 970 and Saturday Night Live alum, Joe Piscopo, on the cancelling of the movie, The Hunt, and the Opis Energy analyst global head, Tom Kloza, on oil, senior FOX News Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano and pro golfer Rory McIlroy on the big business of golf, you don't want to miss any of these guests coming up.

But right here, right now, U.S.-China trade, Goldman Sachs economists saying that fears of a U.S.-China trade war, leading to a recession are increasing, and that Goldman no longer expects a trade deal before the 2020 election.

President Trump, threatening to impose a 10 percent tariff on $300 billion of U.S. imports from China on September the 1st that would mean that every dollar of imports into this country has a tariff on it.

Meantime, protests in Hong Kong, still ongoing with over 100 flights cancelled at the airport today, amid a sit in. And if you take a look at the Futures coming off last week, this is a rough start. But Mitch, what do you make of this Goldman Sachs call?

ROSCHELLE: It's interesting. I do all of my research on the golf course on the weekends and I was talking to a bunch of traders who had an observation that China-U.S. trade war isn't impacting just our economy, but it's impacting all global economies because the uncertainty regarding investment in a global economic environment is really weighing on all economies.

So, it's not just us who want to resolve this for the sake of our GDP growth, it's other countries as well, and I think that's where Goldman Sachs is coming out, which is there's so much pressure on the world, with potential slowing economy. It has a lot to do with this trade spat between --

MCDOWELL: I said this last week that be careful what you wish for, because us "winning" this trade war, if we send China into recession, that basically could be our downfall.

ROSCHELLE: Correct.

MCDOWELL: And we are already seeing the -- it was really the currency moves last week and us designating China currency manipulator, which by the way, probably won't go anywhere because the IMF and G-7 really aren't on board with that.

But it's that where you basically -- you have foreign currencies collapsing while higher dollar denominated desk going to get paid back.

ROSCHELLE: And when --

MCDOWELL: From the borrowers in this nation.

ROSCHELLE: And when other currencies collapse, they have inflation, and inflation is going to slow down their economic growths, so --

MCDOWELL: Lee, in terms of how people are feeling in this country, because again, we always point to the consumer, and consumer confidence still incredibly high, but do you have any sense, and I know you think about this all the time, what will be the tipping point, because there's so much --

Again, just with the presidential tweet storm every weekend, and it's one thing after another, but again, people seem numb to that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: I think so. And at this point, we've been talking about this -- the impacts on people for so long. This is going to happen, it's not going to happen, is Trump going to make a deal, is there going to be no deal?

And I think until people actually feel it, so there's going to be something symbolic that suddenly is going to be felt in the pocket of the consumer and it's going to become real. Because until that happens, right now, it's just going to be one more thing that it's, you know, Trump's going to blow this up, we're going to have a recession, things --

There's a lot of boy who cried wolf here. I think -- and people are tired of that. So they don' know what it means for them. So, once there's a symbolic, you know, it feels -- it feels in my pocketbook that things are different now. I don't think that people are really going to feel differently.

I think people are incredibly optimistic, right now, the markets seem to be, you know, equalizing for them and for the most part, consumer confidence is at an all-time high. And I don't think we'll see that shift until, like I said, there's something that really we all feel.

MCDOWELL: Richard, what do you make of this China trade fight and the escalation of it, and certainly the market reaction to that and other things going on in the global economy?

FOWLER: Oh, I think Lee has a good point, right? Because I think what China has in its favor, China has the political will to carry this on for as long as they would like, right? They're a state-run government, they can, sort of, do what they want. They'll pump --they'll pump money to back their industries.

Are they going to continue to investigate these crimes? The rest of the people that are involved with all of this, I think there's a lot of questions out there about that.

FOWLER: I think Lee brings up a good point about the, sort of, crisis in the justice system. To be honest, I think the crisis already exists. ROSCHELLE: I saw it on a news channel. And for the second it happened, I said, wasn't shocked at all.

ROSCHELLE: Like, it was no surprise. I was like, not news. I knew it was going to happen.

ROSCHELLE: And that's sad.

RON CARSON, FOUNDER & CEO, CARSON GROUP: Just imagine a world where you're guaranteed a loss on investment. But there's, you know, if there's any good news in this, first of all, the bad news is, for savers, they continue to make next to nothing, they're making even less. This is encouraging additional risk taking, if you look at the 9.6 trillion, we have in corporate debt.

The average credit on that is triple B, so the average, you know, average investors having to take on additional risk to get, in some cases, even less return. So, I think it's unhealthy. I know a lot of people argue that point.

You know, if interest rates were to stay low, by economic conditions were to stay stable and not deter, I think it's a great -- it's great news. But that's not what the market is telling us right now.

MCDOWELL: Mitch, the question is, what could revive yields here in the United States when we were talking in the break, but 1.3 percent is the record low yield on the 10-year treasury, so we're not quite there yet. ROSCHELLE: Yes, some of it is sending a signal, and some of it is just this slight equality, because when you do have $15 trillion in negative yields, you're going to buy where you can get yield. But I go back to what I said earlier.

CARSON: No, I think you're right. I think if we have resolution to that, we can have some confidence. I think the bond market would actually, you know, probably yields would go back up. That would be a good thing. Because, right now, we are in a terrible position with the Fed -- going to be --

They're going to be forced to lower interest rates just because of the spread differential. Otherwise, we're going to have a dollar, U.S. dollar skyrocketing, versus other currencies. And that's not good either.

So, I think you're right. Resolution of the trade dispute with China would provide some confidence, stability, and we could start to work our way higher.

The Dow, Nasdaq, and S&P falling for the second week in a row. Last week, losses across the board there. The hardest-hit being the Dow, the Dow 30.

In Asia overnight, markets mixed. In China, yuan was again set weaker than seven per U.S. dollar for the third day in a row. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong was down as protests continued there, and the Nikkei closed for a holiday.

A U.S. gold medalist takes a knee during the national anthem. The champion fencer kneeling while representing team USA on the world stage. The outrage and the cheers for Simone Biles, we will show you that coming up.

Billionaire tech investor Peter Thiel, targeting Google. Maria sitting down with the PayPal co-founder and Facebook board member for his take on why the FBI should be investigating the tech giant.

Silicon Valley politics and China's use of artificial intelligence.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: You wrote this op-ed in The New York Times recently. And the title was, Good for Google, Bad for America. You talked about how Google has walked away from the Pentagon contract, and now is working with China. In fact, working with the Chinese military. Tell us the crux of the op-ed.

PETER THIEL, CO-FOUNDER OF PAYPAL: Well, the crux of the argument is that the crown jewel of crown jewels of Google's R&D effort are the A.I., artificial intelligence technology. And this A.I. means a lot of different things that can be used in a lot of different ways, but it clearly has a lot of military applications for you.

Processing satellite images, helping create processed data. You know, automating drone warfare, cyber warfare, they're all these ways that A.I. is a dual-use thing. Like nuclear technology has both military and civilian uses. There is a Project Maven contract that Google was a part of.

Where they was supplying this A.I. technology to the U.S. military, it pulled out from that as a result of -- you know, employee protests inside Google. At the same time, Google has its -- you know, a major A.I. research lab in China. Where even though it's not working directly with the Chinese military, in effect to all the technology gets handed on to the Chinese military.

And this is -- this is not a controversial crazy conspiracy theory. This is in black and white in the constitution of the Chinese Communist Party. As of 2017, it got amended to distress that there needs to be civil- military fusion in China, where all things need to be integrated and anything that has civilian uses must also be handed over to the People's Liberation Army, the PLA.

BARTIROMO: More about civil-military fusion, I want to hear. In other words, any technology that comes into China has to be reviewed and used or looked as if it could be helpful to the military.

THIEL: Sure. It's a -- it's a communist one-party state. And so, things are so diffused. It's not like the U.S. where you have different companies and different people. And you have the -- you know, you have a government sector and a private sector. And these things don't always coordinate or work together in China. These things are still tightly coordinated across the board.

BARTIROMO: There's A.I. and then there's AGI artificial general intelligence. Give me the difference between the two, and how is A.I. enabling the Chinese military?

THIEL: Well, they're both sort of catch-all phrases. Artificial general intelligence is sort of like superhuman. It's or what you might have in a science-fiction movie. And this is often the way people talk about A.I. is that -- it's this abstract thing that's going to be very different that may or may not happen decades, centuries from now.

What's actually happening is machine learning, artificial intelligence, and that is it's much more mundane, much more prosaic, and it's things like -- you know, helping process satellite images, helping with -- you know, cyber warfare -- things like that. And that's -- you know, it's the social credit scoring system in China where you have use computers to track people and control the society more, so there's of a police state version, there's a military version, there are all sorts of different applications of this. And in that sense, A.I. is just -- you should think of this, just the cutting edge of the computer revolution today. It's sort of the most advanced computer R&D that we're doing.

BARTIROMO: But right now, computers can't reason the way humans can, they can't necessarily show emotion. But AGI, they will be able to.

THIEL: They will be able to. But this is -- this is not about AGI, it's about what's actually happening today, which is -- which is A.I. where they can't -- they can't reason but they could maybe see that -- you know, you're Maria Bartiromo, and we can track your movements or something like that.

BARTIROMO: So, tell me how this came about where Google decided to walk away from the U.S. government and work with China.

THIEL: Well, you can always speculate on what -- what's actually going on inside Google? I think Google's self-image would be that it's globalist, it's, you know, post-national somehow, cosmopolitan. I think the reality is more that it's incredibly insular. It's you know, people are inside this campus and have, you know, shocking lack of curiosity about the outside world.

And so, the kinds of things you've said about Western China and probably not conversations people have a great deal inside Google. And you can think of it as you know, almost like Asperger's or autism where people are just oblivious to all this stuff.

So, that's I think -- that's the most innocent version -- you know, less innocent versions are where it's hyper ideological and left-wing.

BARTIROMO: You know, secretary Pompeo has been on this program, and he has made the point many times that this is a national security risk. You know, that China represents a national security risk because of this very reason. They may be ahead of us in A.I. These are some of the areas that America wants to be number one in. So, let me ask you about that in terms of where we are versus China in terms of A.I.?

THIEL: Well, I think we are -- we are ahead. I think -- you know, I think Google is probably still the on the leading -- the leading place for A.I. research in not just in the U.S. but worldwide.

We're not ahead by that much, and it doesn't matter that much if it gets -- if all our discoveries get transferred to China in very short order. And so, so I -- you know, I don't think it's -- yes, it's sort of like the -- that we were ahead with the nuclear program, and then, at some point, we weren't.

BARTIROMO: It's quite significant that China's intelligence agencies have been seeding people into American companies. I want to ask you about what's going on in Silicon Valley in terms of espionage, in terms of what's happening with Chinese nationals working within our companies? There are Confucius Institutes in Silicon Valley, right by Stanford University. What's your take on all of that?

THIEL: Well, this is -- this gets very speculative. It certainly would be odd if there wasn't something like this going on. And again, to use to zero in on the Google example where the A.I. deep mind effort was described by its own founder as a Manhattan Project for A.I.

And so, even though this was meant as probably -- you know, marketing hyperbole in a way, I think that -- you know, people outside the U.S. might very well take that literally. And so, if you -- if you go around saying, here's the Manhattan Project for A.I., pay attention world.

I think that would attract the attention of foreign governments, foreign intelligence agencies. And I think, it's, in particular, the question about Chinese interest. And this is one that needs to be looked at much more carefully and that's why, why, I've argued that -- you know, the FBI or the CIA should be -- should be looking at this.

BARTIROMO: Do you get pressure because you've supported President Trump?

THIEL: Well, well, yes, there's a lot of questions. There let's -- so, I think there's always an inside and an outside questions. The outside questions where these companies doing with China, you know, are they -- are they censoring speech? And the Twitter-McConnell thing you know, there's - - you can say it's an innocent accident or is it an intentional act of political sabotage, which of the two is it?

And I think one of the reasons the Republicans are so skeptical of the -- of the excuses big tech has for these repeated accidents is that the inside story is not good. Because on the inside, Twitter is not a company where you have lots of people writing checks to Senator McConnell.

You know, if you had a lot of campaign donations from Senator McConnell, we might say, well -- to Senator McConnell, well, we might say this is sort of an innocent mistake, and we won't complain about it too much. That's not what -- what's actually -- what's actually going on.

And it has -- it has sort of this the feel of a -- of a very unhealthy one- party state in a way that's not good for Silicon Valley or for the politics this country generally.

BARTIROMO: I mean, the president can't even have a fundraiser without -- you know, the people getting bullied about that fundraiser. It's gone. I mean, it's actually -- it's crazy. It's real, Trump derangement syndrome happening.

THIEL: Right. Right. And it is -- it is always -- you know, I'm sort of -- the main outspoken supporter of President Trump inside Silicon Valley. There are many other people in Silicon Valley who support the president, but they're not going to say it.

And so, that's always the problem. Unanimity doesn't mean that everybody agrees. It normally just means that everybody is too scared to speak up.

BARTIROMO: There's also breaches in privacy from big tech. You're worried about Google, and you make a really important case. This is what I wanted our viewers to hear you say it, in terms of civil-military fusion, what Google is doing in terms of working with the Chinese military.

What about this FBI surveillance proposal setting up this clash with Facebook? You know, people are worried about being watched and listen to. And here we have FBI surveillance proposing surveillance of Facebook. What's your reaction to that?

THIEL: Well, that's I think a very different kind of a debate. You have to -- there's debate around encryption, and should -- you know, should messages generally be encrypted. I do believe we should be support of an encryption, may make it harder for law enforcement in certain ways. But on the other hand, it also can mean that you have less privacy to things -- to things get you broken into, and all sorts of other context.

And so, I -- yes, if you -- if you, de-encrypt everything, maybe stuff goes back to our rivals in China and things like that. So, I think -- I think the -- I think the dogmatic backdoor to encryption that the FBI pushes is something I would -- I would disagree with.

BARTIROMO: So, what are the practical risks that we need to understand that exist with China having access to this Google A.I. lab, to the Google technology?

THIEL: Well, I think, it's always helpful to -- at least, understand the Chinese perspective, or the perspective of the Chinese communist party. So, they believe that A.I. is a dual use technology. It has civilian uses, it also has military uses. They see the rivalry with the U.S. as pretty existential, and it's going to be very important for the next few decades.

And that's why it's going to be quite a challenge to get to even some kind of the talk with China in the years ahead. So, I think, you know, I think, how we navigate China is quite a tricky question. But the question about Google strike me as a very different one. That's a -- that's straightforward, that's a relatively easy question. They shouldn't be doing this.

BARTIROMO: Is this treason?

THIEL: I wouldn't go quite that far, but it's --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: But you want an investigation into seeing if it is?

THIEL: Well, I -- well, I want investigation to see if, you know if there is a foreign infiltration at a place like Google. But I don't think it's intentionally treasonous, but it is a -- it is autistically oblivious.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

And Stewart Friesen won and there was, I think, his son was standing on the hood of the truck like doing a butt shake and dancing, and it was the most hilarious video. But can we talk about Simone Biles? There's Kevin Harvick. Can we show that Simone Biles video really quickly? Yes! That's what I did. I jumped -- when I saw that, I jumped off my sofa, hands in the air. She's incredible and I think that we need to give her as much camera time as anybody else.

MAX: And how about the (INAUDIBLE) on that stage? The biggest point, right?

CARTER: Goosebumps!

MAX: I mean, the biggest stage you're saying, you know, I'm going to go for it, I'm going to do it. And she nailed it! She tried also on Friday but she didn't like the way that she landed with her hand and she absolutely stuck it with this.

CARTER: Unbelievable.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Absolutely impressive.

MAX: The 2020 games will be here soon enough and we'll be seeing her again.

MCDOWELL: Where are they?

MAX: Tokyo.

MCDOWELL: Get down! I'm so excited. Jared Max, thank you. Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7, SiriusXM 155. See, things that make you smile, that's what we're here about. So, coming up, "The Hunt" is over. Universal's controversial movie cancels shortly after President Trump tweets about it. Joe Piscopo weighs in next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Every year, a bunch of elites.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Kidnapped.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Normal folks like us.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Where'd they get you from?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wow!

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Mississippi.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Orlando.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And hunt us for sport.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: "The Hunt" is over. Universal says it will not release the controversial film due to massive backlash. The movie features rich elite hunting so-called deplorables. The studio now says, now is not the right time to debut the movie. Joining me now is AM-970 Host, Joe Piscopo. Joe, what do you make of this, it seems to be the timing after horrific shootings in Dayton and in El Paso, but also just the whole notion that you have elites hunting, well, looks like Trump voters at least in the --

JOE PISCOPO, RADIO HOST: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- trailer.

PISCOPO: You know, Dagen, good morning to you. It's incredible that someone actually pitched this idea. That's what I kept thinking about. Somebody said: hey, we'll go out and we'll hunt deplorables and this got to where we got. I got to applaud Universal, I got to applaud Hollywood, they got the message. They're not doing this film. And my gosh, almighty, I'm telling you. It was so -- this is I believe in this, Dagen, that the video games, what the president said and all the violence in the films, I think that does instigates some of these whackos on the fringe. So, this is a good thing that they're not doing this movie.

MCDOWELL: But the fact they got green lit and it has this all-star cast, like they spent an incredible amount of money on it.

PISCOPO: Yes, I can't figure it out. Someone went into a pitch meeting, Dagen. And they said, here it is, we're going to go after all these Trump supporters and we're going to attack them. Who says great idea? Let's do this. Only in Hollywood. Only in Hollywood. And thank god they came to common sense.

MCDOWELL: Yes. So, President Trump raised $12 million at two Hamptons fundraisers on Friday. Adding to his I guess who you're voting for, Joe. His 2020 reelection campaign, you attended one of them at Joe Ferrel's Bridgehampton Estate, how was it?

PISCOPO: Well, I said, where did I put my wallet? I can't seem to find my wallet. It's like they were dropping like 35-grand, a quarter of a million dollars. I went, oh geez, I'll wire the money later. I was so -- I'm so not a Hampton's guy and I'm at Joe Ferrel's house and I'm over there as political observer. And I have to tell you, so I went in there and I was - - I wasn't on the inside, but I'm not dropping names, I'm just telling you as a reporter, Dagen, my friend, who was there. You saw -- Steve Mnuchin was there, Lindsey Graham showed up by the way, Kimberly Guilfoyle, Don, Jr. did a speech before the president came on.

And Geraldo was there, our buddy Geraldo was there, and Bill O'Reilly and Rudy Giuliani. Me, I was with the masses way in the back of the room, you know, and I just liked it like that. But to tell you like that, I watched the president objectively, and again, please don't -- this objective observation, he is a rock star. When he steps out and these folks saw the president step up, Dagen, they go crazy: USA, USA, USA! They love him and he was so funny and he said, he goes like, this president opens like this, President Trump goes -- he goes I don't care if you like me, I don't care if you don't like me, you have no choice but to vote for me. The place went crazy. And you know what, the man is right.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you, Joe Piscopo. Manhattan probably not the same reception. Coming up, Futures extending their declines, down almost 200 -- 160 points at the moment, more when we come back.

urn:contentItem:5WS0-SSX1-JB20-G1X6-00000-00U.S.-China Trade Turmoil; President Trump Heading to Dayton and El Paso Today; Rep. Castro (D-TX) Defends Sharing Names of Trump Donors on Twitter; Report: Agency Investigating Tesla Claims Over Model 3 Safety; Apple Adding Restrictions for Apps that Use VOIP Technology; Futures Slide as Rates Drop; Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI), Presidential Candidate is Interviewed About Google; President Trump Doubles Down On Google & Bias Claims; Gabbard & Harris Spar On Harris' Record As California A.G.; Walgreens To Close 200 U.S. Stores Amid Cost-Cutting Plan2019-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTBrett Velicovich, Lindsey Bell, Mack McLarty, Tom Michaud, Tulsi GabbardNEWSFinancial080703cb.231U.S.-China Trade Turmoil; President Trump Heading to Dayton and El Paso Today; Rep. Castro (D-TX) Defends Sharing Names of Trump Donors on Twitter; Report: Agency Investigating Tesla Claims Over Model 3 Safety; Apple Adding Restrictions for Apps that Use VOIP Technology; Futures Slide as Rates Drop; Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-HI), Presidential Candidate is Interviewed About Google; President Trump Doubles Down On Google & Bias Claims; Gabbard & Harris Spar On Harris' Record As California A.G.; Walgreens To Close 200 U.S. Stores Amid Cost-Cutting PlanMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Blake Burman, Cheryl Casone, Jackie DeAngelis, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, August 7th, your top stories, right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button.

China trade turmoil continuing, China Central Bank setting its Yuan rate above that symbolic seven level but it is still at a low, not seen since 2008. This morning, new numbers show that the U.S. has collected $63 billion in Chinese tariffs through the month of June, that's from the treasury.

Markets this morning are higher, trying to add on to yesterday's gains, but look what's just happened in the last 30 minutes, the Dow Futures have now turned negative, down 13, 17 points, S&P down a quarter point, and the NASDAQ is higher, holding on to a gain of six points.

Market was higher pretty much all morning this morning, and has reversed course. Yesterday, the market was able to gain back some of the losses, suffered during Monday's broad sell-off with the Dow Industrials yesterday, up 311 points, S&P was up 37, and the NASDAQ was up 107.

More signs of a slowdown in Europe, take a look at global markets this morning. European indices are higher across the board, despite the fact that Germany reported industrial production was down, more than expected in the month of June, it was down 1-1/2 percent, month-over-month. Germany's DAX Index right now is up 121 points, almost -- well, just over one percent higher.

In Asia overnight, the markets slight losses except for Hong Kong, as you can see, there, fractional moves, three Central Banks in Asia cut interest rates, more than expected. The one people are talking about this morning is Thailand, down a half point, 50 basis points. We also had a cut in India, as well.

Disney reports record revenue this morning, but profit did take a hit, the theme park attendance declined. The stock is sliding, ready to shave above 40 points off the Dow Industrials at the open, more on that, coming up, that stock down better than four percent.

How Disney plans to make new profits off of old Fox titles, then Tesla's safety claims under fire, a government agency accusing the automaker of lying, more on the controversy, coming up, all those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, former U.S. Army Special Operations and strategic adviser at WhiteFox Defense, Brett Velicovich is here and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell, great show, so far, guys.

BRETT VELICOVICH, STRATEGIC ADVISER, WHITEFOX DEFENSE: Yes, good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we've got a lot happening.

BELL: Yes, I'm not surprised to see the markets turning down a little bit here, especially after what we've seen over the last couple of days between the U.S. and China and trade and currency wars, and everything else.

And the industrial production number that came out of Germany, I know those markets are up today, but that goes to show how the trade spat between the U.S. and China and the slowdown in China, in particular, really is impacting the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point. And then, the fact that we're seeing all these interest rate cuts coming down, happening across the world. The three-rate cut is, sort of, setting the tone. I'm wondering if the market turned because Disney worsened. It is representing 40 points on the Dow.

BELL: You're absolutely right.

BARTIROMO: But it was up three percent even before and the market was up, so things are really worsening now, down 58 points on the Dow Industrials.

BELL: Right. And Central Banks, to your point, they're all -- many of them are easing, I think, more than 20 Central Banks around the world are easing monetary policy, I think they're looking to the Fed to continue to ease policy.

We have some ammo with regards to monetary policy, but I don't think it's necessarily going to spur spending, capital spending, business spending, which, Dagen, I know you were talking about earlier today. That's what we really need to pick up and drive the global economy going forward.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: President Trump wants the Federal Reserve to fix the problems that he's created with this trade fight, right or wrong, if that's been the drag on manufacturing activity this year, it's been the drag on business investment, I don't know if another quarter point cut's going to turn that around.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. All right, we will take a -- we will keep talking about that. Joining the conversation this morning, 2020 Democratic presidential candidate and Hawaii Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard is here, don't miss that, she's coming up this morning, right here, live, to talk about the 2020 race.

Also, our top story this hour, President Trump is headed to Dayton and El Paso today, days after those mass shootings in those cities. Many 2020 Democratic hopefuls are making their feelings known about this trip. Blake Burman is live at the White House with the very latest, Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. President Trump and the First Lady will leave the White House next hour to visit those communities, impacted by the most recent mass shootings in this country.

First, the president and the First Lady will head to Dayton, Ohio, where 9 people were killed and 27 injured after a gunman opened fire, late at night in a busy entertainment district, then, El Paso, Texas, where 22 people were killed and 24 injured when a gunman opened fire in the morning, at a Wal-mart store. The White House says part of the president's trip is meant to bring about unity.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOGAN GIDLEY, DEPUTY WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY,: Go to these communities and grieve with them, pray with them, offer condolences, and quite frankly, offer thank you and appreciation to those who -- the first responders who put their lives on the line were able to take out the shooter so quickly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: However, in the lead up to this trip, the president took to Twitter to criticize the Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke, who says the president should stay away from El Paso, O'Rourke used to represent that district in Congress.

The president tweeting "Beto, phony name to indicate Hispanic heritage, O'Rourke, who is embarrassed by my last visit to the great state of Texas, where I trounced him, and is now even more embarrassed by polling at one percent in the Democratic Primary, should respect victims and law enforcement, and be quiet.

O'Rourke responded by writing on Twitter "22 people in my hometown are dead after an act of terror inspired by your racism. El Paso will not be quiet and neither will I.

Maria, the White House has not released the exact details of where the president and the First Lady will head, once they get to Dayton and El Paso. They normally do not do that, due to security reasons.

When the president does visit those communities today, Maria, it will be the sixth time in the Trump presidency that he will leave the White House to go to a community, impacted by a mass shooting. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, Blake, you're right. And Jack Brewer texted me earlier and said look, we're talking about these shootings, just want to point out that there were 51 shootings in Chicago and Baltimore. On the year, eight people shot, a day, in Chicago, nearly four, a day, in Baltimore. Blake Burman, thank you very much for that.

Joining us right now to talk more about all of the above is former chief of staff under Bill Clinton and the chairman of McLarty Associates, Mack McLarty, Mack, it's good to see you always. Thanks so much for being here.

MACK MCLARTY, CHAIRMAN, MCLARTY ASSOCIATES: Maria, good morning, good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Should the 2020 candidates be criticizing President Trump for going to try to show his condolences to the victims of these shootings?

MCLARTY: We have a long history of presidents engaging with people who have been affected by a national tragedy, dating back, obviously, Ronald Reagan, after the challenger incident Bill Clinton going to Oklahoma City, an important moment in his presidency.

Obviously, the most perhaps riveting was President George W. Bush going to New York, after 9/11 that was certainly an important moment in our history and his presidency, and President Obama going to Charleston after the tragedy there, so there's really a tradition here.

I think it's time to lower the rhetoric, I think Senator Klobuchar, among others, has hit about the right tone here. I think it's fine to express concern and find express views, but it's time to put away tweets. Let's concentrate on this tragedy, and show our sympathy and condolences. I would expect --

BARTIROMO: I think that's what the president is trying to do.

MCLARTY: -- that's what the president will try to do today.

BARTIROMO: That's what the president is trying to do.

MCLARTY: Well, I think that's what he -- that's what he will try to do. I think he would have some difficulty on that day. Let's see how he handles it. But I think there is a tradition, I think he's doing the right things, and I would say lower the rhetoric, let's concentrate on the tragedy and condolences and then talk about solutions.

BARTIROMO: For sure.

VELICOVICH: Mack, Brett Velicovich here. Look, it's just so disheartening to hear basically guys like Beto O'Rourke, who are the problem in this case, to say that the president of the United States is not welcome in that city, I mean he needs to show some leadership here, and the president coming down to city helps, you know, a little bit, to ease some of these people's concerns.

That time and time again, the president has repeatedly and forcefully denounced all forms of hate. He's called on the nation to come together in a bipartisan manner.

And it's interesting to me that news recently tried to pin both shooters as Trump supporters, but yet, we found out that in Ohio, within the last 24 hours, that the shooter was Elizabeth Warren fan, and not a right wing, white supremacists that some of these celebrities were talking.

So, I'm curious, you know, how do we put aside these issues and focus on bipartisan unison and put together strategies that can help stop these attacks in the future.

BARTIROMO: And just to be clear, in terms of the media's responsibility here, now they've stopped talking about it. So, first, they were talking about the shooter being, you know, a Trump supporter, and now that we learned that it's Elizabeth Warren's supporter, we don't see it in the news anymore.

VELICOVICH: Precisely.

MCLARTY: Well, that's a lot to unpack, let me -- let me respond to your questions. Number one, I think, a lot of people would not concur or not agree with the point of view that President Trump has not been a divisive figure in many ways.

So, that's -- there are strong feelings that clearly exist and we can't deny that. So, I think that's why will be more difficult for him than perhaps some other presidents have had, in terms of unity, but your point is a fair one, and I go back to my very -- my very basic point, this is a national tragedy.

We don't have all the answers. Right now, we need to express our grief and concern, and then we need to talk about the solutions, I think, whether the president can demonstrate that kind of empathy, that kind of trust. And leadership remains to be seen. You make a fair point about the country, at least, coming together, at least coming together, on some of these issues, even if we have other disagreements on other policy issues. But, I think, in our country, it is filled with good decent hardworking people. They deserve leadership from both sides of the aisle.

In terms of Congressman O'Rourke, this is very personal with him, he's expressing that, you made your points, and I take your point, but this is very personal, he feels very strongly about it, whether it's the right thing for him to do, I think that's -- that is individual opinion. People can make their own judgments.

MCDOWELL: I just want to point out something really quick, Mack, as a point of fact that in Beto O'Rourke's tweet where he was referencing the murderer in El Paso and President Trump, that murderer, in his manifesto, said that his views predate President Trump, which Beto O'Rourke would even know if he read the New York Times.

They wrote that on Monday, so, again, facts matter, and their paltry few facts coming from a lot of people, about the details of what these two murderers did and their backgrounds.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and then at the same time, Mack, you've got details coming from Congressman Castro, he is facing some serious backlash this morning for his tweet, that it named dozens of Texas voters donating to President Trump's re-election campaign.

Castro, we know, is the twin brother of the 2020 hopeful, Julian Castro, and his campaign chairman. He is refusing to take the tweet down, and he's basically trying to out donors for supporting President Trump. So, I -- well, I mean, I assume he's looking for somebody to pick up ball here and start releasing addresses and phone numbers so that these people, hear from the left.

MCLARTY: Well, Maria, as you know, contributors are public record, and I think probably some information about them is also public record under our campaign laws. But, again, I think this is not the timing of the release of those donors, I don't think is particularly good.

This is not the time to get into politics, in my strong opinion. And I really think, I will leave it at that. And I think that's enough said in terms of how to approach this situation. Now, how others choose to do it, that's their decision, but from my stand -- from my stand point, I feel very, very strongly --

BARTIROMO: I could not agree more.

MCLARTY: This is a national tragedy loss and we've got to approach it in a very human caring way, and then talk about, then talk seriously about what can be done. I think Governor DeWine confronted that in Ohio, who's a good man, and I know Mike, I like him and respect him.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCLARTY: He confronted that in Ohio. People won't -- the Congress, the president, to come together --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCLARTY: -- and address this issue.

BARTIROMO: And the president tried that as well, Dagen, right? I mean, he is talking about increased background checks, the bump stocks, as well, recently.

MCDOWELL: Bound bump stocks, with an Executive Order, improving through congressional action. The database that were used for background checks, I think that Congress --

And I think the president would sign off on this, will do something on red flag orders or domestic violence protection orders related to guns, that lets individuals get guns out of hands who are a danger to themselves or others, and it's actually based on some evidence, reduced suicide rates in states where they've been in place for years like Connecticut and Indiana.

BARTIROMO: Mack, it's good to have you this morning, thanks so much.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, we have breaking news, the markets have taken a turn for the worse Futures now, down about a hundred points, take a look. Dow Futures down 96, S&P down eight and the NASDAQ down 13. This coming as the yield on the 10-year treasury is tumbling. It is now, take a look, at 1.64 percent.

Joining us right now is the CEO of KBW, A Stifel Company, Tom Michaud. And Tom it is great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

TOM MICHAUD, CEO, KBW: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your firm obviously, the expert firm in terms of financial mergers and acquisitions. You have done seven out of 10 bank -- large bank mergers this year.

MICHAUD: Correct. That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations.

MICHAUD: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: I want to get to that in a second but first, your reaction to where the yield is and its impact on banks.

MICHAUD: Well, it's -- it will be a negative on bank earnings growth going forward if it stays here. So I think its two things for the banks. Number one is, it will have negative implications for net interest income and for earnings growth. And then number two is, what is the signal sending about the future and the economy.

In the second quarter, the earnings showed no signs really of distress in the economy. They're actually pretty good, they're slower growth but they were still pretty good.

BARTIROMO: So what did we learn from the second quarter on banks?

MICHAUD: What we learn is that banks are still very profitable, they've got the most capital they've had in 80 years and there are really no signs from an industry of any credit problems. So if you were to take a snapshot of the banking industry in the second quarter, you'd say all is OK. And so all the talk around the yield curve is about what might happen but not what has been happening.

BARTIROMO: And go ahead, Lindsey.

BELL: I'm just going to jump in and say, speaking about what might happen with the yield curve, the inversion between the 10 year and three month is now 40 basis points, which is I think the widest it's been in a long time. What is that saying about what the Fed's going to do, the remainder of this year? I mean, BMO Capital is out earlier today saying they could see -- we could see as much as a hundred basis point cut for the Fed to catch up with the markets are.

MICHAUD: It's really interesting, because I personally believe that a lot of the market has adopted a more bearish view of the economy and has been looking for a more accommodative Fed that we may actually get. If you were just to ask me for my personal opinion, I think a lot of the stocks are baked in for 25 basis point cuts? If we don't get that, that could actually be the surprise.

BARTIROMO: But what does the Fed know that we don't know with these four rate cuts? I mean, here we are talking about an economy that is growing, an unemployment at a 50-year low.

MICHAUD: You know, I read -- I read one of the Fed governor speeches this week, and I thought it was very interesting. They said, the conversation was around, have we bought -- has the Fed bought enough insurance for the 25 basis point cut. I think that the comments maybe some of the criticism was that, the Fed moved too quickly on increases. I wonder if that will cause them to move a little more slowly on the decreases just to be a little bit more data based in terms of their direction.

MCDOWELL: But one of the problems, is that the yield curve between the three month and the 10 year is inverted at the widest margins since the financial -- right before the financial crisis in 2007, right? So just based on that, it makes it not impossible very difficult for banks to make money.

Because, again, you make loans on the long end, you borrow on the short end and when that's inverted, that alone would be enough for the Federal Reserve to act again on short term interest rates, right?

And I want to just point out, it seems like you see real panic buying going on in the treasury market. The -- you see the 1.64 on the 10-year. Long bonds are at 2.16 percent on the yield, the record low for the 30 year is 2.1. So if you watch that, that's a sign of -- well quite frankly, fright in these markets. You can take a look at that. We're only -- very short ways away from the all-time low yield on the 30 year.

MICHAUD: So, there's no question, lower rates flatter yield curve, inverted yield curve, make bank earnings growth harder and over time, it will be grind -- a grind on their -- on their profitability. I personally don't think its overnight trauma for the banking industry. Because I think the banking industry is very liquid, it will adapt, it's got plenty of capital. Will the banks be a little less profitable if that happens? It will. The question is, how long does that condition continue?

So I think the banking industry is extraordinarily sound, and maybe they'll earn a little less money. But the stocks, seeing how they've been trading, I think are pricing in something worse.

BARTIROMO: Yes, what about U.S. versus Europe? Because overnight we had three central banks cut interest rates, India, Thailand. You're looking at this race to the bottom and now there's a conversation happening that the ECB wants Christine Lagarde comes in is going to start buying equities.

What can they do with these rock-bottom levels? They don't have a lot of wiggle room. Talk to us about Europe versus the U.S. and what the ECB should do.

MICHAUD: Well, the first thing is that, to get to the conversation we were just happening, Europe's had a negative interest rate condition for a while. And I understand just even the last week, maybe even a trillion dollars of more government debt has gone into the direction of negative interest rates.

We've been seeing European banks report earnings as recently as today. And the negative interest rate environment is very hostile to banks. And I think my opinion is as you need a strong banking system for economic growth to really continue on a sustained basis. And we're not really a hundred percent there yet with the turn that we've take recently because we thought we were coming out of that period. Now it looks like we've made a turn and go back into something that will be a harsher condition for the banks.

BARTIROMO: All right, I just wonder if you're going to start buying equities which is what Rick Rieder thinks at Black Rock. He was with us a couple of weeks ago, real quick before you go. You've done seven of the law -- the 10 large bank mergers this year, more consolidation in the banking sector. And obviously, it's not going to be probably the larger ones because there at the deposit cap, right?

MICHAUD: Correct, so two things, one is scale is working in the banking industry, the bigger banks are becoming more profitable than the smaller banks which hasn't happened in a really long time. So there are benefits to scale right now, number one.

Number two, is the Crapo Bill that passed last year. Removed a $50 billion cap for more intense regulation. That is really a game changer and we think it's going to allow those banks in that asset size to stand up, create regional champions to try to compete with the bigger banks.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Tom, it's great to have you on the show.

MICHAUD: Maria, great to be here, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

MICHAUD: Yes, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tom Michaud today from KBW.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Futures have reversed direction this morning, they are headed lower. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES (via telephone): Twitter is just terrible, what they do. They don't let you get the word. I've had so many people come to me, "Sir, I can't join you on Twitter." I see what's happening. A hundred percent. It will --

BARTIROMO: So do you -- would you rather see competition or do you want to see legislation coming down to actually --

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Hawaii Congresswoman, 2020 Democratic Presidential Candidate, Tulsi Gabbard.

Congresswoman, it is good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. TULSI GABBARD (D-HI), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: It's great to be here. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations to you on all of your success. You are suing Google right now for $50 million.

GABBARD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell me what happened.

GABBARD: During the first debate, and the hours that came after it, we were prepared with all of our Google ads. We were the most searched candidate and campaign of the night, when all of a sudden our Google ad account was shut down without any clear kind of explanation or how to get it back up. And it was later reinstated after that critical window had closed, again without any real explanation.

So we're suing Google really because of the power that these big tech monopolies have over influencing our public discourse, our freedom of speech, and really, ultimately, our fair elections, because if they can do this to me as a sitting member of Congress, running for the highest office of the land, this means they can do it to anyone running for office at any level in this country or any person if they don't like what you're saying.

And this is -- this is really not about me, it's really about the American people and about standing up for and protecting our freedom of speech. Whether we agree or disagree with that speech, this goes to the core and founding principles of our country. And they shouldn't have the power to be able to do that.

BARTIROMO: So what's the answer here? Because this is an issue I think that brings together both sides.

GABBARD: It should.

BARTIROMO: You've got people like Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz wanting a breakup of some of these companies.

GABBARD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And you see the president, obviously, he's also saying that he's watching Google closely.

GABBARD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: These companies have more power today than they ever had. What do you want to see?

GABBARD: Yes.

BARTIROMO: How is this going to change?

GABBARD: Eighty-eight percent of all Internet searches in the United States take place in Google.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

GABBARD: Ninety-two percent in the world. So when you look at -- at a monopoly like Google, having total control of what pops up when you -- when you search for something, this is what we're talking about. So I think there's two approaches that we need to take. One is to break up these big tech monopolies because that's exactly what they are, and also look legislatively at what kind of transparency oversight and accountability is put in place to make sure that there is not an infringement on our freedom of speech and to make sure things are fair and transparent.

BARTIROMO: There's also a movement -- an upset about Google not working with the Pentagon because of the immigration policies and instead choosing to work with China and inadvertently helping the Chinese military. This is what Peter Thiel has been saying as well. Your thoughts on that, because it's more than just censoring people's opinions on things, it's also privatization breaches and this China situation.

GABBARD: Yes. Yes, look, I think it's important for us, from our government and from our regulatory standpoint is to look at what's in the best interests of the American people, making sure that we're protecting those freedoms and our civil liberties that are enshrined in our Constitution and looking and making sure that our decisions are being made with our national security in the forefront.

BARTIROMO: Would you like to see legislation around this?

GABBARD: I would.

BARTIROMO: OK. A new Quinnipiac poll is out, it shows Joe Biden leading nationally among 2020 Democrats. You've got Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders following. You're polling at 1 percent, with Julian Castro and Amy Klobuchar. Ten percent of voters are still undecided.
